nl_theorem:
\ithm{Euler's}
If $\gcd(x,n)=1$, then
$$
   x^{\vphi(n)} \con 1\pmod{n}.
$$

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

If~$R$ is a complete set of residues modulo~$n$ and $a\in\Z$ with
$\gcd(a,n)=1$, then $aR = \{ax : x \in R\}$
is also a complete set of residues modulo~$n$.
nl_proof:
As mentioned above, Euler's Theorem has the following group-theoretic
\index{Euler's theorem!group-theoretic interpretation}
interpretation.  The set of units in $\zmod{n}$ is a group
\index{group!$(\zmod{m})^*$}
$$
(\zmod{n})^*
= \{ a \in \zmod{n} : \gcd(a,n) = 1\}
$$
that has order~$\vphi(n)$.  The theorem then asserts
that the order of an element of $(\zmod{n})^*$ divides the order
$\vphi(n)$ of $(\zmod{n})^*$.   This is a special case of the more
general fact (Lagrange's Theorem) that if~$G$ is a finite group and
$g\in G$, then the order of~$g$ divides the cardinality of~$G$.
We now give an elementary proof of the theorem.  Let
$$
  P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}.
$$
In the same way that we proved Lemma~\ref{lem:residues},
we see that the reductions modulo~$n$ of the elements of $xP$
are the same as the reductions of the elements of $P$.
Thus
$$
 \prod_{a\in P} (xa) \con \prod_{a \in P} a \pmod{n},
$$
since the products are over the same numbers modulo~$n$.
Now cancel the $a$'s on both sides to get
$$x^{\#P} \con 1\pmod{n},$$
as claimed.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\gcd(x,n)=1$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• x and n are integers such that $\gcd(x,n)=1$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If~$R$ is a complete set of residues modulo~$n$ and $a\in\Z$ with $\gcd(a,n)=1$, then $aR = \{ax : x \in R\}$ is also a complete set of residues modulo~$n$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• It is assumed that if R is a complete set of residues modulo n and a is an integer with $\gcd(a,n)=1$, then the set $aR = \{ax : x \in R\}$ is also a complete set of residues modulo n [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let
$$
  P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let P be the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: In the same way that we proved Lemma~\ref{lem:residues}, we see that the reductions modulo~$n$ of the elements of $xP$ are the same as the reductions of the elements of $P$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• x and n are integers such that $\gcd(x,n)=1$ [tc_1].
• The principle that multiplying a complete residue system by a coprime integer permutes the system [def_1].
• P is the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The set of residues of the elements of $xP$ modulo n is the same as the set of residues of the elements of P modulo n [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the principle from def_1, adapted for a reduced residue system (P), showing that multiplication by x permutes the residues.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Thus
$$
 \prod_{a\in P} (xa) \con \prod_{a \in P} a \pmod{n},
$$
since the products are over the same numbers modulo~$n$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• P is the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].
• The set of residues of the elements of $xP$ modulo n is the same as the set of residues of the elements of P modulo n [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\prod_{a\in P} (xa) \equiv \prod_{a \in P} a \pmod{n}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: If two finite sets of integers are the same modulo n, their products are congruent modulo n. Apply this to the sets of residues from l1.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now cancel the $a$'s on both sides
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• P is the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The product of the elements in P, $\prod_{a \in P} a$, is coprime to n, i.e., $\gcd(\prod_{a \in P} a, n) = 1$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The product of integers coprime to n is also coprime to n. Use induction on the set P, where each element is coprime to n by definition.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Now cancel the $a$'s on both sides to get
$$x^{\#P} \con 1\pmod{n},$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• P is the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].
• $\prod_{a\in P} (xa) \equiv \prod_{a \in P} a \pmod{n}$ [l2].
• $\gcd(\prod_{a \in P} a, n) = 1$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $x^{\#P} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the left side of l2 as $x^{\#P} \cdot \prod_{a \in P} a$. Then, use the property l3 to cancel the term $\prod_{a \in P} a$ from both sides of the congruence.

proof_graph.natural_language: The set of units in $\zmod{n}$ is a group... that has order~$\phi(n)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• P is the set of integers $P = \{ a : 1\leq a \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(a,n) = 1\}$ [def_2].
• By definition, Euler's totient function $\phi(n)$ counts the number of positive integers up to n that are relatively prime to n.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The cardinality of P is equal to Euler's totient function of n, i.e., $\#P = \phi(n)$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Show that the definition of the set P corresponds directly to the definition of Euler's totient function $\phi(n)$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
$$x^{\#P} \con 1\pmod{n},$$
as claimed.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $x^{\#P} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}$ [l4].
• $\#P = \phi(n)$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $x^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the equality from l5 into the congruence from l4.

nl_proof:
The primitive roots modulo~$n$ are the generators of
$(\zmod{n})^*$, which by assumption is cyclic of order~$\vphi(n)$.
Thus they are in bijection with the generators of any cyclic group
of order $\vphi(n)$.  In particular, the number of primitive roots
modulo~$n$ is the same as the number of elements of $\zmod{\vphi(n)}$
with additive order $\vphi(n)$.  An element of $\zmod{\vphi(n)}$ has additive
order $\vphi(n)$ if and only if it is coprime to $\vphi(n)$.  There
are $\vphi(\vphi(n))$ such elements, as claimed.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let~$p^n$ be a power of an odd prime.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let m be an integer of the form p^k, where p is an odd prime and k is a positive integer [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
The primitive roots modulo~$n$ are the generators of
$(\zmod{n})^*$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• A primitive root modulo m is a generator of the multiplicative group of integers modulo m, (Z/mZ)* [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: which by assumption is cyclic
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption:
• The group (Z/mZ)* is cyclic [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: of order~$\phi(n)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (General knowledge of group theory)
Therefore, we conclude:
• The order of the group (Z/mZ)* is φ(m) [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the library result `Nat.card_units_zmod_n`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Thus they are in bijection with the generators of any cyclic group
of order $\phi(n)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• A primitive root modulo m is a generator of (Z/mZ)* [def_1].
• The group (Z/mZ)* is cyclic [def_2].
• The order of the group (Z/mZ)* is φ(m) [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The set of primitive roots modulo m is in bijection with the set of generators of any cyclic group of order φ(m) [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Since (Z/mZ)* is a cyclic group of order φ(m), its generators (the primitive roots) are in bijection with the generators of any other cyclic group of the same order.

proof_graph.natural_language:
In particular, the number of primitive roots
modulo~$n$ is the same as the number of elements of $\zmod{\phi(n)}$
with additive order $\phi(n)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The set of primitive roots modulo m is in bijection with the set of generators of any cyclic group of order φ(m) [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The number of primitive roots modulo m is equal to the number of elements in the additive group Z/φ(m)Z that have additive order φ(m) [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Instantiate the general statement l2 with the specific additive cyclic group Z/φ(m)Z, whose generators are the elements of additive order φ(m).

proof_graph.natural_language:
An element of $\zmod{\phi(n)}$ has additive
order $\phi(n)$ if and only if it is coprime to $\phi(n)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
•  (General knowledge of cyclic groups)
Therefore, we conclude:
• An element k of the additive group Z/φ(m)Z has additive order φ(m) if and only if k is coprime to φ(m) [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the standard library theorem about generators of Z/kZ, which states that an element `a` generates the group if and only if `gcd(a, k) = 1`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
There
are $\phi(\phi(n))$ such elements, as claimed.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The number of primitive roots modulo m is equal to the number of elements in Z/φ(m)Z with additive order φ(m) [l3].
• An element of Z/φ(m)Z has additive order φ(m) if and only if it is coprime to φ(m) [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The number of primitive roots modulo m is φ(φ(m)) [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine l3 and l4 to state that the number of primitive roots is the number of elements coprime to φ(m). By definition of Euler's totient function, this number is φ(φ(m)).

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let~$p^n$ be a power of an odd prime.  Then there
is a primitive root modulo~$p^n$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• m is an integer of the form p^k, where p is an odd prime and k is a positive integer [tc_1].
• The number of primitive roots modulo m is φ(φ(m)) [l5].
• The group (Z/mZ)* is cyclic [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a primitive root modulo m [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: To show existence, prove that the number of primitive roots is greater than 0. Using tc_1, show that for m=p^k, φ(m) > 1, which implies φ(φ(m)) ≥ 1. Note that this proof relies on the unproven assumption def_2, which itself follows from tc_1 by a standard (but omitted) theorem.

proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let a, b, c, n be elements of a field 𝔽, where 2 is invertible.
• a² + b² = c² [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: \frac{1}{2}ab&=&n
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let a, b, c, n be elements of a field 𝔽, where 2 is invertible [tc_1].
• (1/2) * a * b = n [tc_2].

We assume:
• a, b, c, n are elements of a field 𝔽 where 2 is invertible [tc_1].
• a² + b² = c² [tc_1].
• (1/2) * a * b = n [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• a² ± 2ab + b² = c² ± 4n [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From tc_2, derive 2ab = 4n. Then add/subtract this equation to/from tc_1. This can be handled by `linarith` or `ring`.

proof_graph.natural_language: (a\pm b)^2 &=& c^2 \pm 4n
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b are elements of a field 𝔽 [tc_1].
• a² ± 2ab + b² = c² ± 4n [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• (a ± b)² = c² ± 4n [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the left-hand side of l1 using the formula for the square of a sum/difference. `ring` should solve this.

proof_graph.natural_language:
\left(\frac{a\pm b}{2}\right)^2 &=& 
   \left( \frac{c}{2}\right)^2 \pm n
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b, c, n are elements of a field 𝔽 where 2 is invertible [tc_1].
• (a ± b)² = c² ± 4n [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• ((a ± b)/2)² = (c/2)² ± n [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Divide both sides of l2 by 4. Then simplify both sides using properties of squares and division. `field_simp` and `ring` will be useful.

proof_graph.natural_language: &=& A \pm n
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Given c, an element of a field 𝔽 where 2 is invertible [tc_1].
• We define A = (c/2)² [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: &=& A \pm n
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• ((a ± b)/2)² = (c/2)² ± n [l3].
• A = (c/2)² [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• ((a ± b)/2)² = A ± n [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definition of A from def_1 into the right-hand side of l3.

nl_theorem:
For any integers $a$ and $b$, we have
$$
   \gcd(a,b)= \gcd(b,a) = \gcd(\pm a, \pm b) = \gcd(a,b-a) = \gcd(a,b+a).
$$
nl_proof:
We only prove that $\gcd(a,b) = \gcd(a,b-a)$, since the other cases
are proved in a similar way. Suppose $d\mid a$ and
  $d\mid b$, so there exist integers $c_1$ and $c_2$ such that $dc_1 =
  a$ and $dc_2 = b$.  Then $b - a = dc_2 - dc_1 = d(c_2-c_1)$, so
  $d\mid b-a$.  Thus $\gcd(a,b)\leq \gcd(a,b-a)$, since the set over
  which we are taking the max for $\gcd(a,b)$ is a subset of the set
  for $\gcd(a,b-a)$.  The same argument with $a$ replaced by $-a$
  and $b$ replaced by $b-a$, shows that $\gcd(a,b-a)=\gcd(-a,b-a)\leq
  \gcd(-a,b)=\gcd(a,b)$, which proves that $\gcd(a,b)=\gcd(a,b-a)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: For any integers $a$ and $b$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• a and b are integers [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: gcd(a,b) = gcd(±a, ±b)
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• For any integers x and y, gcd(x, y) = gcd(±x, ±y) [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose $d\mid a$ and $d\mid b$, so there exist integers $c_1$ and $c_2$ such that $dc_1 = a$ and $dc_2 = b$. Then $b - a = dc_2 - dc_1 = d(c_2-c_1)$, so $d\mid b-a$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b, and d are integers [tc_1].
• d divides a [l1_assump1].
• d divides b [l1_assump2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• d divides (b-a) [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Unfold the definition of divisibility. Since d|a and d|b, there exist integers c1, c2 such that a = d*c1 and b = d*c2. Substitute these into b-a and factor out d.

proof_graph.natural_language: Thus $\gcd(a,b)\leq \gcd(a,b-a)$, since the set over which we are taking the max for $\gcd(a,b)$ is a subset of the set for $\gcd(a,b-a)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are integers [tc_1].
• For any integer d, if d divides a and d divides b, then d divides (b-a) [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The set of common divisors of a and b is a subset of the set of common divisors of a and (b-a), which implies gcd(a,b) ≤ gcd(a,b-a) [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: To show gcd(a,b) ≤ gcd(a,b-a), it suffices to show that the set of common divisors of (a,b) is a subset of the common divisors of (a,b-a). Let d be a common divisor of a and b. Then d|a is given. By l1, we have d|(b-a). Thus d is a common divisor of a and (b-a).

proof_graph.natural_language: The same argument with $a$ replaced by $-a$ and $b$ replaced by $b-a$, shows that $\gcd(a,b-a)=\gcd(-a,b-a)\leq \gcd(-a,b)=\gcd(a,b)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are integers [tc_1].
• For any integers x and y, gcd(x, y) = gcd(±x, ±y) [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• gcd(a, b-a) ≤ gcd(a, b) [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Prove the chain gcd(a,b-a) = gcd(-a,b-a) ≤ gcd(-a,b) = gcd(a,b). The equalities gcd(a,b-a) = gcd(-a,b-a) and gcd(-a,b) = gcd(a,b) follow from tc_2. The inequality gcd(-a,b-a) ≤ gcd(-a,b) follows by applying the same reasoning as in l1 and l2, but with inputs x=-a and y=b-a, which proves gcd(-a, b-a) ≤ gcd(-a, (b-a)-(-a)) = gcd(-a, b).

proof_graph.natural_language: which proves that $\gcd(a,b)=\gcd(a,b-a)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• gcd(a,b) ≤ gcd(a,b-a) [l2].
• gcd(a, b-a) ≤ gcd(a, b) [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• gcd(a,b) = gcd(a,b-a) [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the antisymmetry property of the ≤ relation (le_antisymm).

nl_theorem:
Suppose $a,b,n\in\Z$ are such that $n\mid a$ and $n\mid b$.  Then
  $n\mid \gcd(a,b)$.

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

For any integers $a,b,n$, we have
$$\gcd(an,bn) = \gcd(a,b)\cdot |n|.$$
nl_proof:
Since $n\mid a$ and $n\mid b$, there are integers
$c_1$ and $c_2$, such that $a=n c_1$ and $b=n c_2$.
Then, 
$\gcd(a,b) = \gcd(n c_1, nc_2) = n\gcd(c_1, c_2)$,
so $n$ divides $\gcd(a,b)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose $a,b,n\in\Z$ are such that $n\mid a$ and $n\mid b$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $a, b, n$ are integers, $n$ divides $a$, and $n$ divides $b$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
For any integers $a,b,n$, we have
$$\gcd(an,bn) = \gcd(a,b)\cdot |n|.$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• For any integers $x,y,z$, $\gcd(zx,zy) = |z| \cdot \gcd(x,y)$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $n\mid a$ and $n\mid b$, there are integers
$c_1$ and $c_2$, such that $a=n c_1$ and $b=n c_2$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $a, b, n$ are integers, $n$ divides $a$, and $n$ divides $b$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exist integers $c_1, c_2$ such that $a = n \cdot c_1$ and $b = n \cdot c_2$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of divisibility (`dvd_def`) to the premises `n | a` and `n | b` from [tc_1] to obtain witnesses $c_1$ and $c_2$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Then, 
$\gcd(a,b) = \gcd(n c_1, nc_2) = n\gcd(c_1, c_2)$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $a, b, n, c_1, c_2$ are integers, with $a = n \cdot c_1$ and $b = n \cdot c_2$ [l1].
• For any integers $x,y,z$, we have $\gcd(zx,zy) = |z| \cdot \gcd(x,y)$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\gcd(a,b) = n \cdot \gcd(c_1, c_2)$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite `a` and `b` in `gcd(a,b)` using the equalities from [l1]. Then, apply the axiom from [def_1]. Note that the proof uses `n` instead of `|n|`, which is a potential error if `n` is negative; follow the proof's conclusion and use `n`.

proof_graph.natural_language: so $n$ divides $\gcd(a,b)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exist integers $c_1, c_2$ such that $a = n \cdot c_1$ and $b = n \cdot c_2$ [l1].
• $\gcd(a,b) = n \cdot \gcd(c_1, c_2)$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $n$ divides $\gcd(a,b)$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [l2], we have the equality `gcd(a,b) = n * gcd(c1, c2)`. Since $c_1$ and $c_2$ from [l1] are integers, their gcd is also an integer. This satisfies the definition of divisibility (`use Dvd.intro`).

nl_theorem:
If~$R$ is a complete set of residues modulo~$n$ and $a\in\Z$ with
$\gcd(a,n)=1$, then $aR = \{ax : x \in R\}$
is also a complete set of residues modulo~$n$.

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

If $\gcd(c,n)=1$ and
$$
   ac\con bc\pmod{n},
$$
then $a \con b\pmod{n}$.
nl_proof:
If $ax\con ax'\pmod{n}$ with $x, x'\in R$, then $x\con{}x'\pmod{n}$.
Because $R$ is a complete set of residues, this implies
that $x=x'$.  Thus the elements of
$aR$ have distinct reductions modulo~$n$.
It follows, since $\#aR=n$, that $aR$ is a
complete set of residues modulo~$n$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If R is a complete set of residues modulo n
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• R is a complete set of residues modulo n, which implies that R contains n integers and for any two distinct elements x, y ∈ R, x is not congruent to y modulo n (x <binary data, 2 bytes> y mod n) [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: a∈Z with gcd(a,n)=1
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• a is an integer such that gcd(a, n) = 1 [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
If gcd(c,n)=1 and
$$
   ac\con bc\pmod{n},
$$
then a \con b\pmod{n}.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The cancellation law for modular congruence holds: For any integers a, b, c and a positive integer n, if gcd(c, n) = 1 and ac ≡ bc (mod n), then a ≡ b (mod n) [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If ax\con ax'\pmod{n} with x, x'\in R, then x\con{}x'\pmod{n}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a is an integer such that gcd(a, n) = 1 [tc_2].
• The cancellation law for modular congruence holds: For any integers k, l, m, if gcd(m, n) = 1 and km ≡ lm (mod n), then k ≡ l (mod n) [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any integers x, x' ∈ R, if ax ≡ ax' (mod n), then x ≡ x' (mod n) [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the cancellation law from def_1. Let c from def_1 be a from the current context. Let a and b from def_1 be x and x'. The condition gcd(c, n) = 1 is satisfied by tc_2 (gcd(a, n) = 1). The conclusion a ≡ b (mod n) becomes x ≡ x' (mod n).

proof_graph.natural_language: Because R is a complete set of residues, this implies that x=x'.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• R is a complete set of residues modulo n, which implies for any x, x' ∈ R, if x ≡ x' (mod n), then x = x' [tc_1].
• For any integers x, x' ∈ R, if ax ≡ ax' (mod n), then x ≡ x' (mod n) [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any integers x, x' ∈ R, if ax ≡ ax' (mod n), then x = x' [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Chain the implications. From l1, we have ax ≡ ax' (mod n) → x ≡ x' (mod n). From the definition of a complete set of residues in tc_1, we have x ≡ x' (mod n) → x = x'. Combining these gives the conclusion.

proof_graph.natural_language: Thus the elements of aR have distinct reductions modulo n.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any integers x, x' ∈ R, if ax ≡ ax' (mod n), then x = x' [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The elements of the set aR = {ax : x ∈ R} have distinct reductions modulo n. (This means that for any distinct x, x' ∈ R, it holds that ax is not congruent to ax' modulo n) [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The statement is the contrapositive of the implication in l2. l2 states `ax ≡ ax' (mod n) → x = x'`. The contrapositive is `x ≠ x' → ax <binary data, 2 bytes> ax' (mod n)`, which is the definition of having distinct reductions.

proof_graph.natural_language: since #aR=n
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• R is a complete set of residues modulo n, which implies #R = n [tc_1].
• For any integers x, x' ∈ R, if ax ≡ ax' (mod n), then x = x' [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The cardinality of the set aR = {ax : x ∈ R} is n (#aR = n) [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The implication in l2, `ax ≡ ax' (mod n) → x = x'`, proves that the map f(x) = ax is injective on the set R. (If f(x) = f(x'), then ax = ax', which implies ax ≡ ax' (mod n), which by l2 implies x=x'). Since R is a finite set, an injective map from R to its image aR means that #aR = #R. From tc_1, #R = n. Thus, #aR = n.

proof_graph.natural_language: It follows, since #aR=n, that aR is a complete set of residues modulo n.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The elements of the set aR have distinct reductions modulo n [l3].
• The cardinality of the set aR is n (#aR = n) [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The set aR = {ax : x ∈ R} is a complete set of residues modulo n [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows directly from the definition of a complete set of residues. A set is a complete set of residues modulo n if it contains exactly n elements and these elements are pairwise incongruent modulo n. These two conditions are established by l4 and l3, respectively.

nl_theorem:
Suppose $a,b\in(\zmod{n})^*$ have orders~$r$ and~$s$, respectively,
  and that $\gcd(r,s)=1$.  Then $ab$ has order $rs$.
nl_proof:
This is a general fact about commuting elements of any group; our proof
only uses that $ab=ba$ and nothing special about $(\zmod{n})^*$.  Since
$$
  (ab)^{rs} = a^{rs}b^{rs}=1,
$$
the order of $ab$ is a divisor of $rs$.
Write this divisor as $r_1 s_1$ where $r_1\mid r$
and $s_1\mid s$.
Raise both sides of the equation
$$
  a^{r_1 s_1}b^{r_1 s_1} = (ab)^{r_1 s_1} = 1
$$
to the power $r_2 = r/r_1$ to obtain
$$
   a^{r_1 r_2 s_1} b^{r_1 r_2 s_1} = 1.
$$
Since $a^{r_1 r_2 s_1} = (a^{r_1 r_2})^{s_1} = 1$,  we have
$$
  b^{r_1 r_2 s_1} = 1,
$$
so $s\mid r_1 r_2 s_1$.
Since $\gcd(s,r_1 r_2)=\gcd(s,r) = 1$, it follows that $s=s_1$.
Similarly $r=r_1$, so the order of $ab$ is $rs$.

proof_graph.natural_language: This is a general fact about commuting elements of any group; our proof only uses that ab=ba
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let G be a group, and let a, b ∈ G be commuting elements, i.e., ab=ba [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose a,b... have orders r
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• The element a has order r, where r is a positive integer [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose a,b... have orders... s, respectively
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• The element b has order s, where s is a positive integer [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: and that gcd(r,s)=1
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• The orders r and s are coprime, i.e., gcd(r,s)=1 [tc_4].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since (ab)^{rs} = a^{rs}b^{rs}=1
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b are commuting elements of a group G [tc_1]
• The order of a is r [tc_2]
• The order of b is s [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• (ab)^(rs) = 1 [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use `(ab)^n = a^n * b^n` for commuting elements. Then use `a^r=1` and `b^s=1` to show `a^(rs) = (a^r)^s = 1` and `b^(rs) = (b^s)^r = 1`.

proof_graph.natural_language: the order of ab is a divisor of rs.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (ab)^(rs) = 1 [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The order of ab, let's call it k, divides rs (i.e., k | rs) [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a direct application of the definition of order in a group: if g^n = 1, then order(g) divides n.

proof_graph.natural_language: Write this divisor as r_1 s_1 where r_1∣r and s_1∣s.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let k be the order of ab. Since k | rs [l2] and gcd(r,s)=1 [tc_4], we can decompose k as k = r₁s₁ where r₁ and s₁ are positive integers such that r₁ | r and s₁ | s [def_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This decomposition relies on number theory, specifically that any divisor of a product of two coprime numbers can be uniquely factored into divisors of those numbers. Define r₁ = gcd(k, r) and s₁ = gcd(k, s) and show k = r₁s₁.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The order of ab is r₁s₁ [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• (ab)^(r₁s₁) = 1 [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: By definition, raising an element to its order yields the identity element.

proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Given that r₁ | r [def_1], we define the integer r₂ such that r = r₁ * r₂ [def_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This defines r₂ as the result of integer division r / r₁.

proof_graph.natural_language: Raise both sides of the equation ... to the power r_2 = r/r_1 to obtain a^{r_1 r_2 s_1} b^{r_1 r_2 s_1} = 1.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (ab)^(r₁s₁) = 1 [l3]
• a and b commute [tc_1]
• r = r₁ * r₂ [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• a^(r₁r₂s₁) * b^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Raise both sides of `l3` to the power r₂. Then use `(g^m)^n = g^(mn)` and `(ab)^n = a^n * b^n`.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The order of a is r [tc_2]
• r = r₁ * r₂ [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• a^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the exponent as `(r₁r₂) * s₁ = r * s₁`. Since `order(a)=r`, `a^r=1`, and thus `(a^r)^s₁ = 1^s₁ = 1`.

proof_graph.natural_language: we have b^{r_1 r_2 s_1} = 1
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a^(r₁r₂s₁) * b^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l4]
• a^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l5]
Therefore, we conclude:
• b^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute l5 into l4 and cancel the term `a^(r₁r₂s₁)` which is the identity element.

proof_graph.natural_language: so s∣r_1 r_2 s_1.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• b^(r₁r₂s₁) = 1 [l6]
• The order of b is s [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• s | r₁r₂s₁ [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From the definition of order, if g^n=1, then order(g) divides n. Apply this to element b.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since gcd(s,r_1 r_2)=gcd(s,r) = 1, it follows that s=s_1.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• s | r₁r₂s₁ [l7]
• gcd(r,s) = 1 [tc_4]
• s₁ | s [def_1]
• r = r₁ * r₂ [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• s = s₁ [l8].
proof_graph.lean_hint: First, show gcd(s, r₁r₂) = 1 by rewriting `r₁r₂` as `r` using `def_2` and applying `tc_4`. Then, use Euclid's lemma (or `Nat.Coprime.dvd_of_dvd_mul_left`) on `l7` to get `s | s₁`. Finally, use this with `s₁ | s` from `def_1` and `Nat.dvd_antisymm` to prove equality.

proof_graph.natural_language: Similarly r=r_1
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The initial premises [tc_1], [tc_2], [tc_3], [tc_4] and the decomposition of the order of ab [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• r = r₁ [l9].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The proof is symmetric to the one for `l8` (s=s₁). Swap the roles of (a, r, r₁) with (b, s, s₁), define s₂=s/s₁, and follow the same logic.

proof_graph.natural_language: so the order of ab is rs.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The order of ab is r₁s₁ [def_1]
• s = s₁ [l8]
• r = r₁ [l9]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The order of ab is rs [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the results from l8 and l9 into the definition of the order from def_1.

nl_theorem:
Let $a, b\in\Q$.  Then for any integer~$n$,
$$\#\left((a,b)\intersect \Z\right) \con \#\left((a,b+2n)\intersect \Z\right) \pmod{2}$$
and
$$
\#\left((a,b)\intersect \Z\right) \con \#\left((a-2n,b)\intersect \Z\right) \pmod{2},
$$
provided that each interval involved in the congruence is nonempty.
nl_proof:
Let $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes
the least integer $\geq x$.
Since $n>0$,
$$(a,b+2n) = (a,b) \union [b,b+2n),$$
where the union is disjoint.  There are $2n$ integers
$$
\lceil b\rceil, \lceil b\rceil+1, \ldots, \lceil b\rceil +2n-1
$$
in the interval $[b,b+2n)$, so the first congruence of the lemma
is true in this case.  We also have
$$
(a,b-2n) = (a,b)\text{ minus } [b-2n,b)
$$
and $[b-2n,b)$ contains exactly $2n$ integers, so the lemma is
also true when~$n$ is negative.  The statement about
$\#\left((a-2n,b)\intersect \Z\right)$ is proved in a similar manner.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $a, b\in\Q$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let a and b be rational numbers [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: for any integer~$n$,
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let n be an integer [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: provided that each interval involved in the congruence is nonempty.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let a and b be rational numbers [tc_1]
• Let n be an integer [tc_2]
• The intervals (a,b), (a,b+2n), and (a-2n,b) are nonempty [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let $\lceil xceil$ denotes
the least integer $\geq x$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• For any rational number x, $\lceil xceil$ denotes the least integer greater than or equal to x [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $n>0$,
$$(a,b+2n) = (a,b) \union [b,b+2n),$$
where the union is disjoint.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are rational numbers [tc_1]
• n is a positive integer [tc_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For n > 0, the interval (a, b+2n) is the disjoint union of (a,b) and [b, b+2n), i.e., $(a,b+2n) = (a,b) \cup [b,b+2n)$ and $(a,b) \cap [b,b+2n) = \emptyset$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Prove the set equality and disjointness based on the properties of intervals and the condition n > 0.

proof_graph.natural_language:
There are $2n$ integers
$$
\lceil bceil, \lceil bceil+1, \ldots, \lceil bceil +2n-1
$$
in the interval $[b,b+2n)$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• b is a rational number [tc_1]
• n is a positive integer [tc_2]
• $\lceil xceil$ is the least integer $\geq x$ [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For n > 0, the number of integers in the interval [b, b+2n), denoted $\#([b,b+2n) \cap \mathbb{Z})$, is 2n [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The integers in the interval are from `ceil b` to `ceil(b+2n)-1` or `floor((b+2n)-epsilon)`. The number of integers in `[m, k)` is `k-m`. Here the integers are from `ceil b` to `ceil b + 2n -1`. The number is `(ceil b + 2n - 1) - (ceil b) + 1 = 2n`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
so the first congruence of the lemma
is true in this case.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For n > 0, $(a,b+2n) = (a,b) \cup [b,b+2n)$ is a disjoint union [l1]
• For n > 0, the number of integers in [b, b+2n) is 2n [l2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For n > 0, $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \equiv \#((a,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \pmod{2}$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From the disjoint union in l1, we have $\#((a,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z}) = \#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) + \#([b,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z})$. Substitute the count from l2 to get $\#((a,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z}) = \#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) + 2n$. The result follows by taking the equation modulo 2.

proof_graph.natural_language:
We also have
$$
(a,b-2n) = (a,b)\text{ minus } [b-2n,b)
$$
and $[b-2n,b)$ contains exactly $2n$ integers, so the lemma is
also true when~$n$ is negative.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b are rational numbers [tc_1]
• n is a negative integer [tc_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For n < 0, $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \equiv \#((a,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \pmod{2}$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The proof's reasoning for this case is flawed as written. A correct argument is to let m = -n > 0. The goal is to show $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \equiv \#((a,b-2m)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \pmod{2}$. This can be done by applying the logic for the positive case (l3) to the interval (a, b-2m). Alternatively, one can use the decomposition $(a,b) = (a,b+2n) \cup [b+2n, b)$, where for n<0 the interval $[b+2n, b)$ contains -2n integers, which is an even number.

proof_graph.natural_language: #\left((a,b)\intersect \Z\right) \con #\left((a,b+2n)\intersect \Z\right) \pmod{2}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a,b are rational numbers [tc_1]
• n is an integer [tc_2]
• The intervals involved are nonempty [tc_3]
• For n > 0, the congruence holds [l3]
• For n < 0, the congruence holds [l4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any integer n, $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \equiv \#((a,b+2n)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \pmod{2}$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine the results from the cases n>0 (l3), n<0 (l4), and the trivial case n=0 where both sides of the congruence are equal.

proof_graph.natural_language:
The statement about
$$
\#\left((a-2n,b)\intersect \Z\right)
$$
is proved in a similar manner.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a, b are rational numbers [tc_1]
• n is an integer [tc_2]
• The intervals involved are nonempty [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any integer n, $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \equiv \#((a-2n,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) \pmod{2}$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The proof is by analogy to the first congruence. For n>0, decompose (a-2n, b) into a disjoint union of (a-2n, a) and [a,b). The interval [a-2n, a) contains 2n integers. This implies $\#((a-2n,b)\cap\mathbb{Z}) = 2n + \#([a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z})$. As $\#((a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z})$ and $\#([a,b)\cap\mathbb{Z})$ differ by at most one, this approach requires more careful handling of endpoints. A more robust symmetric argument on the left endpoint 'a' mirrors the one for 'b'.

nl_proof:
If $a\con 0\pmod{p}$, then $\zeta^a=1$, so the sum equals the number of summands,
which is~$p$.  If $a\not\con 0\pmod{p}$, then we use the
identity $$x^p - 1 = (x-1)(x^{p-1} + \cdots + x + 1)$$ with $x = \zeta^a$. We have
 $\zeta^a\neq 1$, so $\zeta^a - 1 \neq 0$ and
$$
\sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \zeta^{an} = \frac{\zeta^{ap}-1}{\zeta^a-1} =
\frac{1-1}{\zeta^a-1} = 0.
$$

proof_graph.natural_language:
For any integer~$a$,
$$
\sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \zeta^{an}
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• p is a prime number
• ζ = e^(2πi/p) is a primitive p-th root of unity
• a is an integer [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If $a\con 0\pmod{p}$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• p is a prime number, ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, and a is an integer [tc_1]
• a ≡ 0 (mod p) [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: then $\zeta^a=1$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p is a prime number, ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, and a is an integer [tc_1]
• a ≡ 0 (mod p) [tc_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ζ^a = 1 [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From a ≡ 0 (mod p), it follows that a = k*p for some integer k. Then ζ^a = ζ^(kp) = (ζ^p)^k. Since ζ is a p-th root of unity, ζ^p = 1, so the expression becomes 1^k = 1.

proof_graph.natural_language: so the sum equals the number of summands,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• ζ^a = 1 [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} ζ^(an) = ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} 1 [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the summand as (ζ^a)^n, then substitute ζ^a = 1 using [l1]. The sum becomes ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} 1^n, which simplifies to ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} 1.

proof_graph.natural_language: which is~$p$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} ζ^(an) = ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} 1 [l2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} ζ^(an) = p [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The sum of 1 over the finite set {0, 1, ..., p-1} has p terms, so the sum is p. Use `Finset.sum_const`.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $a\not\con 0\pmod{p}$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• p is a prime number, ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, and a is an integer [tc_1]
• a ≢ 0 (mod p) [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: We have $\zeta^a\neq 1$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p is a prime number, ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, and a is an integer [tc_1]
• a ≢ 0 (mod p) [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ζ^a ≠ 1 [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Since ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, ζ^k = 1 if and only if p divides k. The condition a ≢ 0 (mod p) means that p does not divide a. Therefore, ζ^a ≠ 1.

proof_graph.natural_language: so $\zeta^a - 1 \neq 0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• ζ^a ≠ 1 [l3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ζ^a - 1 ≠ 0 [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a direct algebraic rearrangement of ζ^a ≠ 1. Use `sub_ne_zero_of_ne`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
$$
\sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \zeta^{an} = \frac{\zeta^{ap}-1}{\zeta^a-1} =
\frac{1-1}{\zeta^a-1} = 0.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p is a prime number, ζ is a primitive p-th root of unity, and a is an integer [tc_1]
• ζ^a ≠ 1 [l3]
• ζ^a - 1 ≠ 0 [l4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} ζ^(an) = 0 [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: First, apply the formula for a finite geometric series, ∑_{n=0}^{p-1} x^n = (x^p - 1)/(x - 1), with x = ζ^a. This is valid because ζ^a ≠ 1 [l3]. The sum becomes (ζ^(ap) - 1)/(ζ^a - 1). Next, simplify the numerator: ζ^(ap) = (ζ^p)^a = 1^a = 1, using the property of ζ from [tc_1]. The expression becomes (1-1)/(ζ^a-1). Since the denominator is non-zero [l4], the fraction evaluates to 0.

nl_theorem:
We have $g_0=0$.

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

  The map $\psi:(\zmod{p})^*\to \{\pm 1\}$ given by
$\psi(a) = \kr{a}{p}$ is a surjective group homomorphism.
nl_proof:
By definition
\begin{equation}\label{eqn:lem_gauss_3}
g_0 = \sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p}.
\end{equation}
By Lemma~\ref{lem:qrhom}, the map
$$
\kr{\cdot}{p} : (\zmod{p})^* \ra \{\pm 1\}
$$
is a surjective homomorphism of groups.  Thus,  half the
elements of $(\zmod{p})^*$ map to $+1$ and half map to $-1$ (the
subgroup that maps to $+1$ has index $2$).  Since $\kr{0}{p}=0$, the
sum (\ref{eqn:lem_gauss_3}) is~$0$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
By Lemma~\ref{lem:qrhom}, the map
$$
\kr{\cdot}{p} : (\zmod{p})^* \ra \{\pm 1\}
$$
is a surjective homomorphism of groups.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• For a prime p, the map a ↦ \kr{a}{p} is a surjective group homomorphism from the multiplicative group of units `(ℤ/pℤ)^*` to the multiplicative group `{+1, -1}` [tc_1].

Definition:
• Let p be a prime. We define $g_0 = \sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p}$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Thus,  half the
elements of $(\zmod{p})^*$ map to $+1$ and half map to $-1$ (the
subgroup that maps to $+1$ has index $2$).
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For a prime p, the map a ↦ \kr{a}{p} is a surjective group homomorphism from `(ℤ/pℤ)^*` to `{+1, -1}` [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The sum of the Legendre symbol over the non-zero elements of `ℤ/pℤ` is zero: $\sum_{n=1}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p} = 0$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From the surjective homomorphism property [tc_1], the number of quadratic residues (where the symbol is 1) is equal to the number of quadratic non-residues (where the symbol is -1), and this number is (p-1)/2. The sum is therefore (p-1)/2 * 1 + (p-1)/2 * (-1) = 0. This involves splitting the sum over `(Z/pZ)^*` into two sums based on the value of the Legendre symbol.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $\kr{0}{p}=0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p is a prime.
Therefore, we conclude:
• By definition of the Legendre symbol, $\kr{0}{p} = 0$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is by definition of `legendre_sym`. Use a library lemma like `legendre_sym.zero`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $\kr{0}{p}=0$, the
sum (\ref{eqn:lem_gauss_3}) is~$0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $g_0 = \sum_{n=0}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p}$ [def_1]
• $\sum_{n=1}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p} = 0$ [l1]
• $\kr{0}{p} = 0$ [l2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $g_0 = 0$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the sum in the definition of g_0 [def_1] by separating the n=0 term: `g_0 = \kr{0}{p} + \sum_{n=1}^{p-1} \kr{n}{p}`. Then substitute the results from [l2] and [l1] into this expression.

nl_theorem:
For every $n$ such that $a_n$ is defined, we have
$$x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n}+t_n],$$
and if $t_{n}\neq 0$, then
$
  x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n}, \frac{1}{t_n}].
$
nl_proof:
We use induction.  The statements are both true when $n=0$.
If the second statement is true for $n-1$, then
\begin{align*}
x &= \left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},\frac{1}{t_{n-1}}\right]\\
  &=\left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},a_n + t_n\right]\\
  &=\left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},a_n, \frac{1}{t_n}\right].
\end{align*}
Similarly, the first statement is true for~$n$ if
it is true for $n-1$.

proof_graph.natural_language: For every $n$ such that $a_n$ is defined, we have...
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $x$ be a real number. The sequences $(a_n)_{n\ge 0}$ and $(t_n)_{n\ge 0}$ are defined by the continued fraction algorithm: $x_0 = x$, and for $n \ge 0$, $a_n = \lfloor x_n \rfloor$, $t_n = x_n - a_n$, and $x_{n+1} = 1/t_n$ (for $t_n \neq 0$) [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n}+t_n]
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The notation for a finite continued fraction is defined recursively as $[c_0] = c_0$ and $[c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_k] = c_0 + 1/[c_1, \ldots, c_k]$ for $k > 0$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: The statements are both true when $n=0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The definitions of sequences $(a_n), (t_n)$ from $x$ [tc_1].
• The definition of continued fraction notation [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The two theorem statements hold for $n=0$: we have $x = [a_0+t_0]$, and if $t_0 \neq 0$, then $x = [a_0, \frac{1}{t_0}]$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For the first part, by definition, $[a_0+t_0]$ evaluates to $a_0+t_0$. From [tc_1], $t_0 = x_0 - a_0 = x - a_0$, so $a_0+t_0 = x$. For the second part, $[a_0, 1/t_0] = a_0 + 1/(1/t_0) = a_0+t_0 = x$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
x &= \left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},\frac{1}{t_{n-1}}\right]\\ 
  &=\left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},a_n + t_n\right]
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The definitions of sequences $(a_n), (t_n)$ from $x$ [tc_1].
• The definition of continued fraction notation [def_1].
• The condition $t_{n-1} \neq 0$ holds.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $[a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}, \frac{1}{t_{n-1}}] = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}, a_n + t_n]$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This equality holds by substituting the last term of the continued fraction. From the definitions in [tc_1], we have $x_n = 1/t_{n-1}$ and $x_n = a_n + t_n$. Therefore, $1/t_{n-1} = a_n + t_n$. The equality follows by congruence (`congr_arg`).

proof_graph.natural_language:
&=\left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},a_n + t_n\right]\\ 
  &=\left[a_0,a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1},a_n, \frac{1}{t_n}\right].
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The definition of continued fraction notation [def_1].
• The condition $t_n \neq 0$ holds.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $[a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}, a_n + t_n] = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n, \frac{1}{t_n}]$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is due to the general property of continued fractions: $[c_0, \dots, c_{k-1}, c_k + y] = [c_0, \dots, c_{k-1}, c_k, 1/y]$ for $y \neq 0$. Apply this with $k=n$ and $y=t_n$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The second statement is true for $n-1$: if $t_{n-1} \neq 0$, then $x = [a_0, \ldots, a_{n-1}, \frac{1}{t_{n-1}}]$.
• $[a_0, \ldots, \frac{1}{t_{n-1}}] = [a_0, \ldots, a_n + t_n]$ [l2].
• $[a_0, \ldots, a_n + t_n] = [a_0, \ldots, a_n, \frac{1}{t_n}]$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The inductive step for the second statement is proven: For $n > 0$, if the statement holds for $n-1$ (with $t_{n-1} \neq 0$), then it holds for $n$ (with $t_n \neq 0$) [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Assume the inductive hypothesis for $n-1$. Then, by transitivity of equality, rewrite the hypothesis using [l2] and then [l3] to obtain the desired conclusion for $n$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Similarly, the first statement is true for~$n$ if it is true for $n-1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The definitions of sequences $(a_n), (t_n)$ [tc_1] and continued fractions [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The inductive step for the first statement holds: For $n>0$, if $x = [a_0, \ldots, a_{n-1} + t_{n-1}]$ is true, then $x = [a_0, \ldots, a_n + t_n]$ is also true [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The proof is asserted by analogy and not detailed. A formal proof would assume the hypothesis for $n-1$, substitute $t_{n-1} = 1/x_n = 1/(a_n+t_n)$, and use continued fraction identities to derive the goal for $n$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
For every $n$ such that $a_n$ is defined, we have
$$x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n}+t_n]$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The base case for $n=0$ holds [l1].
• The inductive step holds for the first statement [l5].
Therefore, we conclude by induction:
• For every $n$ for which $a_n$ is defined, $x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n + t_n]$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows by the principle of mathematical induction, using the base case from [l1] and the inductive step from [l5].

proof_graph.natural_language:
and if $t_{n}\neq 0$, then
$ x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n}, \frac{1}{t_n}]. $
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The base case for $n=0$ holds [l1].
• The inductive step holds for the second statement [l4].
Therefore, we conclude by induction:
• For every $n$ for which $a_n$ is defined, if $t_n \neq 0$, then $x = [a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n, \frac{1}{t_n}]$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows by the principle of mathematical induction, using the base case from [l1] and the inductive step from [l4].

nl_theorem:
If $x\in\R$ and $n\in\N$, then there is a fraction $\ds\frac{a}{b}$
in lowest terms such that $0<b\leq n$ and
$$\left| x - \frac{a}{b} \right| \leq \frac{1}{b(n+1)}.$$

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

\iprop{convergence of continued fraction}%
Let $a_0,a_1,\ldots$ define a simple continued
fraction, and let $x=[a_0,a_1,\ldots]\in\R$ be its value.
Then for all~$m$,
$$
  \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
  < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}.
$$
nl_proof:
Consider the continued fraction\index{continued fraction}
$[a_0,a_1,\ldots]$ of~$x$.
By Corollary~\ref{cor:cfconv}, for each~$m$
$$
 \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
  < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}.
$$
Since $q_{m+1}\geq q_m + 1$ and $q_0=1$,
either there exists an~$m$ such that $q_m\leq n < q_{m+1}$, or the
continued fraction\index{continued fraction} expansion of~$x$ is finite and $n$ is larger
than the denominator of the rational number~$x$, in which case
we take $\frac{a}{b}=x$ and are done.  In the first
case,
$$
  \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
   < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}
      \leq \frac{1}{q_m \cdot (n+1)},$$
so $\ds\frac{a}{b} = \frac{p_m}{q_m}$ satisfies the conclusion of
the lemma.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $x\in\R$ and $n\in\N$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• x is a real number and n is a natural number [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let $a_0,a_1,\ldots$ define a simple continued
fraction, and let $x=[a_0,a_1,\ldots]\in\R$ be its value.
Then for all~$m$,
$$
  \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
  < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $y=[a_0,a_1,\ldots]$ be a simple continued fraction with convergents $p_m/q_m$. Then for all m, $|y - p_m/q_m| < 1/(q_m q_{m+1})$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Consider the continued fraction
$[a_0,a_1,\ldots]$ of~$x$. Since $q_{m+1}\geq q_m + 1$ and $q_0=1$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let x be a real number [tc_1].
• Let $[a_0,a_1,\ldots]$ be the simple continued fraction of x, with convergents $p_m/q_m$ [def_2a].
• The denominators $q_m$ are integers with $q_0=1$, $q_m>0$ for all m, and the sequence is strictly increasing for $m \geq 1$ [def_2b].
• Each convergent $p_m/q_m$ is a fraction in lowest terms [def_2c].

proof_graph.natural_language:
By Corollary~\ref{cor:cfconv}, for each~$m$
$$
 \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
  < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any simple continued fraction $y$ with convergents $p_m/q_m$, $|y - p_m/q_m| < 1/(q_m q_{m+1})$ [def_1].
• x has a continued fraction with convergents $p_m/q_m$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each m, $|x - p_m/q_m| < 1/(q_m q_{m+1})$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the general property from [def_1] to the specific continued fraction of x from [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
either there exists an~$m$ such that $q_m\leq n < q_{m+1}$, or the
continued fraction expansion of~$x$ is finite and $n$ is larger
than the denominator of the rational number~$x$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number [tc_1].
• The sequence of denominators $q_m$ is a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers starting with $q_0=1$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• Either (A) there exists an integer m such that $q_m \leq n < q_{m+1}$, or (B) the continued fraction expansion of x is finite, ending with $x = p_k/q_k$ for some k, and $q_k \leq n$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a property of the integer sequence $q_m$ relative to the integer n. Since the sequence starts at 1 and is strictly increasing, it must either eventually surpass n or terminate at a value less than or equal to n.

proof_graph.natural_language:
in which case
we take $\frac{a}{b}=x$ and are done.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Case (B) from [l2] holds: The continued fraction of x is finite, $x=a/b$, where $a/b$ is the final convergent in lowest terms, and its denominator b satisfies $b \leq n$ [l2].
• n is a natural number [tc_1].
• Denominators of convergents are positive integers [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a fraction (namely $a/b=x$) that is in lowest terms, has denominator $b'$ satisfying $0 < b' \leq n$, and meets the inequality $|x - a/b'| \leq 1/(b'(n+1))$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The conditions 'lowest terms' and '$0 < b \leq n$' are given by the assumptions. The inequality $|x - a/b| \leq 1/(b(n+1))$ holds because the left side is 0 and the right side is non-negative, as $b>0$ and $n \geq 0$.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right| < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}} \leq \frac{1}{q_m \cdot (n+1)}$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists an m such that $q_m \leq n < q_{m+1}$ (this corresponds to Case A of [l2]) [l2].
• For all m, $|x - p_m/q_m| < 1/(q_m q_{m+1})$ [l1].
• $q_m$ and $q_{m+1}$ are positive integers [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For the m identified in the assumption, $|x - p_m/q_m| \leq 1/(q_m(n+1))$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use transitivity. First inequality is from [l1]. For the second inequality, `1/(q_m * q_{m+1}) <= 1/(q_m * (n+1))`, use the fact that $n < q_{m+1}$ implies $n+1 \leq q_{m+1}$ for integers. Then take reciprocals.

proof_graph.natural_language:
so $\ds\frac{a}{b} = \frac{p_m}{q_m}$ satisfies the conclusion of
the lemma.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists an m such that $q_m \leq n < q_{m+1}$ (this corresponds to Case A of [l2]) [l2].
• For this m, the fraction $p_m/q_m$ is in lowest terms and $q_m > 0$ [def_2].
• For this m, $|x - p_m/q_m| \leq 1/(q_m(n+1))$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a fraction $a/b$ (namely $p_m/q_m$) that is in lowest terms, has denominator $b$ satisfying $0 < b \leq n$, and meets the inequality $|x - a/b| \leq 1/(b(n+1))$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let $a=p_m$ and $b=q_m$. The 'lowest terms' property is from [def_2]. The inequality is from [l4]. The bounds $0 < b \leq n$ are from [def_2] (for $b>0$) and the case condition $q_m \leq n$ from [l2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Consider the continued fraction
$[a_0,a_1,\ldots]$ of~$x$. By Corollary~\ref{cor:cfconv}, for each~$m$
$$
 \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
  < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}.
$$
Since $q_{m+1}\geq q_m + 1$ and $q_0=1$,
either there exists an~$m$ such that $q_m\leq n < q_{m+1}$, or the
continued fraction expansion of~$x$ is finite and $n$ is larger
than the denominator of the rational number~$x$, in which case
we take $\frac{a}{b}=x$ and are done.  In the first
case,
$$
  \left| x - \frac{p_m}{q_m}\right|
   < \frac{1}{q_m \cdot q_{m+1}}
      \leq \frac{1}{q_m \cdot (n+1)},$$
so $\ds\frac{a}{b} = \frac{p_m}{q_m}$ satisfies the conclusion of
the lemma.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any x and n, one of two cases must hold (described in [l2]) [l2].
• In the case that x is rational with a denominator $b \leq n$, there exists a suitable fraction [l3].
• In the case that there exists an m with $q_m \leq n < q_{m+1}$, there exists a suitable fraction [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x\in\R$ and $n\in\N$, there is a fraction $a/b$ in lowest terms such that $0<b\leq n$ and $|x - a/b| \leq 1/(b(n+1))$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use `cases` on the disjunction provided by [l2]. The first goal is discharged by [l5], the second by [l3].

nl_theorem:
If $[a_0,a_1,\ldots,a_m]$ is a simple continued fraction,
so each $a_i$ is an integer,
then the $p_n$ and $q_n$ are integers and
the fraction $p_n/q_n$ is in lowest terms.
nl_proof:
It is clear that the $p_n$ and $q_n$ are integers, from the formula
  that defines them.  If~$d$ is a positive divisor of both $p_n$ and
  $q_n$, then $d\mid (-1)^{n-1}$, so $d=1$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $[a_0,a_1,\ldots,a_m]$ is a simple continued fraction, so each $a_i$ is an integer
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $[a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_m]$ be a simple continued fraction, which means $a_i$ is an integer for each $i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, m\}$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: from the formula that defines them
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The convergents $p_n/q_n$ of the continued fraction are defined by the recurrence relations:
  • $p_n = a_n p_{n-1} + p_{n-2}$ for $n \ge 1$, with initial values $p_{-1} = 1, p_0 = a_0$.
  • $q_n = a_n q_{n-1} + q_{n-2}$ for $n \ge 1$, with initial values $q_{-1} = 0, q_0 = 1$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: It is clear that the $p_n$ and $q_n$ are integers, from the formula that defines them.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Each $a_i$ is an integer [tc_1].
• The convergents $p_n, q_n$ are defined by recurrence relations with integer initial values ($p_{-1}=1, p_0=a_0, q_{-1}=0, q_0=1$) [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For all $n$ from $-1$ to $m$, $p_n$ and $q_n$ are integers [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Prove by strong induction on n. The base cases $p_{-1}, q_{-1}, p_0, q_0$ are integers. The inductive step $p_n = a_n p_{n-1} + p_{n-2}$ preserves the integer property, as it is a sum/product of integers ($a_n, p_{n-1}, p_{n-2}$ are integers by [tc_1] and the induction hypothesis).

proof_graph.natural_language: If~$d$ is a positive divisor of both $p_n$ and $q_n$, then $d\mid (-1)^{n-1}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The convergents $p_n, q_n$ are defined by the recurrence relations in [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The determinant identity holds: $p_n q_{n-1} - p_{n-1} q_n = (-1)^{n-1}$ for $n \ge 0$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a standard theorem about continued fraction convergents (often called Cassini's Identity for continued fractions). It can be proven by induction on n using the recurrence relations.

proof_graph.natural_language: If~$d$ is a positive divisor of both $p_n$ and $q_n$, then $d\mid (-1)^{n-1}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p_n, q_n, p_{n-1}, q_{n-1}$ are all integers [ts_1].
• The identity $p_n q_{n-1} - p_{n-1} q_n = (-1)^{n-1}$ holds [l1].
• $d$ is an integer that divides both $p_n$ and $q_n$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $d$ divides $(-1)^{n-1}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: By the property of integer division, if $d|p_n$ and $d|q_n$, then $d$ divides any integer linear combination of them. Thus, $d$ must divide $q_{n-1}p_n + (-p_{n-1})q_n$. Using the identity from [l1], this means $d$ divides $(-1)^{n-1}$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $d$ is a positive integer.
• $d$ divides $(-1)^{n-1}$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $d = 1$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The integer divisors of $(-1)^{n-1}$ (which is 1 or -1) are only 1 and -1. Since $d$ is a positive integer, it must be 1.

proof_graph.natural_language: If~$d$ is a positive divisor of both $p_n$ and $q_n$, then $d\mid (-1)^{n-1}$, so $d=1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p_n$ and $q_n$ are integers [ts_1].
• Any positive common divisor $d$ of $p_n$ and $q_n$ must be 1 [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The fraction $p_n/q_n$ is in lowest terms (i.e. $\text{gcd}(p_n, q_n) = 1$) [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The definition of a fraction being in lowest terms is that the greatest common divisor (gcd) of the numerator and denominator is 1. The result from [l3] shows that the only positive common divisor is 1, which implies that the gcd is 1.

nl_theorem: Every natural number is a product of primes.
nl_proof:
Let~$n$ be a natural number.  If $n=1$, then~$n$ is the empty
product of primes.
If $n$ is prime, we are done.
If $n$ is composite, then $n=ab$ with $a,b<n$. By induction,~$a$
and~$b$ are products of primes, so~$n$ is also a product of primes.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let~n be a natural number.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• n is a natural number such that n ≥ 1 [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: ...a product of primes.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• A natural number m ≥ 1 is a 'product of primes' if either m=1 (representing an empty product), or m can be written as a product of one or more prime numbers [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: By induction...
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption (Inductive Hypothesis for n):
• Let n be a natural number ≥ 1 [tc_1]. We assume that for all natural numbers k such that 1 ≤ k < n, k is a product of primes [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: If n=1, then~n is the empty product of primes.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number such that n ≥ 1 [tc_1]
• A natural number m ≥ 1 is a 'product of primes' if either m=1 (representing an empty product), or m can be written as a product of one or more prime numbers [def_1]
• n = 1
Therefore, we conclude:
• n is a product of primes [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The conclusion follows directly from the definition of 'product of primes' [def_1], which includes the case for n=1.

proof_graph.natural_language: If n is prime, we are done.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number such that n ≥ 1 [tc_1]
• A natural number m ≥ 1 is a 'product of primes' if either m=1 (representing an empty product), or m can be written as a product of one or more prime numbers [def_1]
• n is a prime number
Therefore, we conclude:
• n is a product of primes [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: A prime number is a product of a single prime (itself), which fits the definition of 'product of primes' [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If n is composite, then n=ab with a,b<n.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number ≥ 1 [tc_1]
• n is a composite number
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exist natural numbers a, b such that n = a * b, 1 < a < n, and 1 < b < n [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of a composite number. Note that while the proof text states `a,b<n`, the formal definition ensures factors `a,b` exist between 1 and `n`.

proof_graph.natural_language: By induction, a and b are products of primes...
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let n be a natural number ≥ 1. We assume that for all natural numbers k such that 1 ≤ k < n, k is a product of primes [def_2]
• There exist natural numbers a, b such that n = a * b, 1 < a < n, and 1 < b < n [l3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• a is a product of primes, and b is a product of primes [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [l3], we have 1 ≤ a < n and 1 ≤ b < n. Apply the inductive hypothesis [def_2] to both a and b.

proof_graph.natural_language: ...so~n is also a product of primes.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• A natural number m ≥ 1 is a 'product of primes' if either m=1 (representing an empty product), or m can be written as a product of one or more prime numbers [def_1]
• There exist natural numbers a, b such that n = a * b, 1 < a < n, and 1 < b < n [l3]
• a is a product of primes, and b is a product of primes [l4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• n is a product of primes [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Since a and b are products of primes [l4], their product n = a * b is also a product of primes by concatenating their lists of prime factors, which satisfies definition [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: (Implied by the case structure: 'If n=1...', 'If n is prime...', 'If n is composite...')
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number ≥ 1 [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• n = 1 OR n is prime OR n is composite [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the law of trichotomy for natural numbers greater than or equal to 1 based on the definitions of prime and composite.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let~n be a natural number. If n=1, ..., so~n is also a product of primes.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• n is a natural number ≥ 1 [tc_1]
• For all natural numbers k such that 1 ≤ k < n, k is a product of primes [def_2]
• If n = 1, then n is a product of primes [l1]
• If n is prime, then n is a product of primes [l2]
• If n is composite, then n is a product of primes (which is derived from the inductive hypothesis) [l5]
• n = 1 OR n is prime OR n is composite [l6]
Therefore, we conclude:
• n is a product of primes [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This step completes the induction. Perform a case analysis on `n` using [l6]. The goal is proven in each case by [l1], [l2], and [l5] respectively. The overall proof would wrap this logic in a strong induction.

nl_theorem:
\iprop{infinitely many primes}
There are infinitely many primes of the form $4x-1$.
nl_proof:
Suppose $p_1, p_2,\ldots, p_n$ are distinct primes of the form $4x-1$.  Consider
the number
$$
      N = 4p_1 p_2  \cdots  p_n - 1.
$$
Then $p_i \nmid N$ for any~$i$.  Moreover, not every prime $p\mid N$
is of the form $4x+1$; if they all were, then $N$ would be of the form
$4x+1$.  Since $N$ is odd, each prime divisor $p_i$ is odd so
there is a $p\mid N$ that is of the form $4x-1$.  Since
$p\not= p_i$ for any~$i$, we have found a new prime of the form
$4x-1$.  We can repeat this process indefinitely, so the set of primes
of the form $4x-1$ cannot be finite.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose $p_1, p_2,\ldots, p_n$ are distinct primes of the form $4x-1$.
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption for Contradiction:
• Let {$p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n$} be the finite set of all distinct primes `p` such that `p \equiv 3 (mod 4)` [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Consider the number
$$
      N = 4p_1 p_2  \cdots  p_n - 1.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Given the finite set of all primes {$p_1, \ldots, p_n$} such that `p \equiv 3 (mod 4)` [def_1], we define the integer $N = 4 \cdot p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdots p_n - 1$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Then $p_i 
mid N$ for any~$i$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• {$p_1, \ldots, p_n$} is a set of primes [def_1].
• $N = 4 \cdot p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdots p_n - 1$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $i \in \{1, \ldots, n\}$, $p_i$ does not divide $N$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Proof by contradiction. Assume $p_i$ divides $N$. Since $p_i$ also divides $4 \cdot p_1 \cdots p_n$, it must divide their difference, which is $N - (4 \cdot p_1 \cdots p_n) = -1$. No prime divides -1.

proof_graph.natural_language: $$N = 4p_1 p_2  \cdots  p_n - 1.$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $N = 4 \cdot p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdots p_n - 1$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $N \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use modular arithmetic. $4 \cdot p_1 \cdots p_n$ is divisible by 4, so $4k - 1 \equiv -1 \equiv 3 \pmod 4$.

proof_graph.natural_language: if they all were, then $N$ would be of the form $4x+1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (General knowledge of modular arithmetic).
Therefore, we conclude:
• The product of any set of integers congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ is also congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let $a = 4k+1$ and $b=4j+1$. Then $ab = (4k+1)(4j+1) = 16kj + 4k + 4j + 1 = 4(4kj+k+j) + 1$. Generalize by induction.

proof_graph.natural_language: not every prime $p\mid N$ is of the form $4x+1$; if they all were, then $N$ would be of the form $4x+1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $N \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l2].
• The product of integers congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ is also congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• Not every prime factor of $N$ can be congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Proof by contradiction. Assume all prime factors of $N$ are congruent to $1 \pmod 4$. Then their product, $N$, must also be congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ by `l3`. This contradicts `l2`, which states $N \equiv 3 \pmod 4$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $N$ is odd, each prime divisor $p_i$ is odd
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $N \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $N$ is odd, and thus any prime factor of $N$ must be odd [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: $N = 4k-1 = 2(2k-1)+1$, which is odd. The only even prime is 2. If 2 were a factor of N, N would be even, which is a contradiction.

proof_graph.natural_language: so there is a $p\mid N$ that is of the form $4x-1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Not every prime factor of $N$ is congruent to $1 \pmod 4$ [l4].
• Every prime factor of $N$ is odd [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists at least one prime factor $p$ of $N$ such that $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: An odd prime $p$ must satisfy $p \equiv 1 \pmod 4$ or $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$. By `l5`, any prime factor of $N$ is odd. By `l4`, at least one of them is not congruent to $1 \pmod 4$. Therefore, it must be congruent to $3 \pmod 4$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $p
ot= p_i$ for any~$i$, we have found a new prime of the form $4x-1$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $i \in \{1, \ldots, n\}$, the prime $p_i$ from the initial list does not divide $N$ [l1].
• There exists a prime factor $p$ of $N$ such that $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• This prime factor $p$ is not equal to any of the primes $p_i$ in the original list [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: By `l6`, $p$ divides $N$. By `l1`, none of the $p_i$ divide $N$. Therefore, $p$ cannot be any of the $p_i$.

proof_graph.natural_language: We can repeat this process indefinitely, so the set of primes of the form $4x-1$ cannot be finite.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The set {$p_1, \ldots, p_n$} is the finite and complete set of all primes `p` such that `p \equiv 3 (mod 4)` [def_1].
• There exists a prime $p$ such that $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ [l6].
• This prime $p$ is not in the set {$p_1, \ldots, p_n$} [l7].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The assumption that the set of primes of the form $4x-1$ is finite leads to a contradiction. Thus, there are infinitely many such primes [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The existence of a prime $p$ which is of the form $4x-1$ [l6] but is not in the supposedly complete list of such primes [l7] contradicts the initial assumption [def_1]. Use `absurd`.

nl_theorem:
A number $n\in\Z$ is divisible by~$3$ if and only if
the sum of the digits of~$n$ is divisible by~$3$.
nl_proof:
Write
 $$n=a+10b+100c+\cdots,$$
where the digits of~$n$ are $a$, $b$, $c$, etc.
Since $10\con 1\pmod{3}$,
$$
  n = a + 10b + 100c+\cdots \con a + b + c+\cdots \pmod{3},
$$
from which the proposition follows.

proof_graph.natural_language: A number $n\in\Z$ is divisible by~$3$ if and only if the sum of the digits of~$n$ is divisible by~$3$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $n$ is an integer [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Write
 $$n=a+10b+100c+\cdots,$$
where the digits of~$n$ are $a$, $b$, $c$, etc.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $n$ is an integer [tc_1].
Definition:
• Let $n$ be written in its base-10 expansion as $n = \sum_{i=0}^k d_i \cdot 10^i$, where $d_i$ are the digits of $n$ (with $d_0=a, d_1=b, \dots$). Let the sum of the digits be $S_n = \sum_{i=0}^k d_i$. [def_1]

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $10\con 1\pmod{3}$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (General knowledge of arithmetic)
Therefore, we conclude:
• $10 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Can be proven by `norm_num`.

proof_graph.natural_language: n = a + 10b + 100c+\cdots \con a + b + c+\cdots \pmod{3}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $n$ is an integer written in its base-10 expansion as $n = \sum_{i=0}^k d_i \cdot 10^i$, and its sum of digits is $S_n = \sum_{i=0}^k d_i$ [def_1].
• $10 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $n \equiv S_n \pmod{3}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite n using its base-10 expansion from [def_1]. Use `Int.modeq_sum`. To prove that each term $d_i \cdot 10^i \equiv d_i \pmod 3$, use the property that $10^i \equiv 1 \pmod 3$. This latter fact can be proven by induction on $i$ using the premise $10 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ [l1].

proof_graph.natural_language: from which the proposition follows.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $S_n$ is the sum of the digits of an integer $n$ [def_1].
• $n \equiv S_n \pmod{3}$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $n$ is divisible by 3 if and only if the sum of its digits, $S_n$, is divisible by 3. [ts_1]
proof_graph.lean_hint: The statement '$x$ is divisible by $3$' is equivalent to '$x \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$'. Apply this equivalence to both sides of the 'if and only if' clause. The goal becomes $n \equiv 0 \pmod{3} \iff S_n \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$, which follows directly from the assumption $n \equiv S_n \pmod{3}$ [l2].

nl_theorem:
\iprop{root bound}
Let $f\in k[x]$ be a nonzero polynomial
over a field $k$.  Then there are at most
$\deg(f)$ elements $\alpha\in k$ such that $f(\alpha)=0$.
nl_proof:
We prove the proposition by induction on $\deg(f)$.  The cases in
which
$\deg(f)\leq 1$ are clear.  Write
$f = a_n x^n + \cdots a_1 x + a_0$.  If
$f(\alpha)=0$, then
\begin{align*}
 f(x) &= f(x) - f(\alpha)\\
      &= a_n(x^n-\alpha^n) + \cdots + a_1(x-\alpha) + a_0(1-1)\\
      &= (x-\alpha)(a_n(x^{n-1}+\cdots + \alpha^{n-1}) + \cdots + a_2(x+\alpha) + a_1)\\
      &= (x-\alpha)g(x),
\end{align*}
for some polynomial $g(x)\in k[x]$.
Next, suppose that $f(\beta)=0$ with $\beta\neq \alpha$.  Then
$(\beta-\alpha) g(\beta) = 0$, so, since $\beta-\alpha\neq 0$ and $k$
is a field,  we have $g(\beta)=0$.
By our inductive hypothesis,~$g$ has at most $n-1$ roots, so
there are at most $n-1$ possibilities for~$\beta$.
It follows that~$f$ has at most~$n$ roots.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $f\in k[x]$ be a nonzero polynomial over a field $k$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $f$ is a nonzero polynomial in $k[x]$ where $k$ is a field [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: We prove the proposition by induction on $\deg(f)$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The proof proceeds by induction on $n = \deg(f)$. The Inductive Hypothesis (IH) is that for any polynomial $h \in k[x]$ with $\deg(h) < n$, $h$ has at most $\deg(h)$ roots in $k$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: The cases in which $\deg(f)\leq 1$ are clear.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is a nonzero polynomial in $k[x]$ where $k$ is a field [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• If $\deg(f) \le 1$, then $f$ has at most $\deg(f)$ roots [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Handle two cases. If $\deg(f) = 0$, $f$ is a non-zero constant, hence 0 roots. If $\deg(f) = 1$, $f=ax+b$ with $a \ne 0$, which has exactly one root. In both cases, the number of roots is at most $\deg(f)$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
If $f(\alpha)=0$, then
\begin{align*}
 f(x) &= f(x) - f(\alpha)\\
      &= a_n(x^n-\alpha^n) + \cdots + a_1(x-\alpha) + a_0(1-1)\\
      &= (x-\alpha)(a_n(x^{n-1}+\cdots + \alpha^{n-1}) + \cdots + a_2(x+\alpha) + a_1)\\
      &= (x-\alpha)g(x),
\end{align*}
for some polynomial $g(x)\in k[x]$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is a nonzero polynomial in $k[x]$ of degree $n = \deg(f)$ [tc_1].
• $\alpha \in k$ is a root of $f$, so $f(\alpha)=0$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a polynomial $g(x) \in k[x]$ such that $f(x) = (x-\alpha)g(x)$ and $\deg(g) = n-1$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the property that if $\alpha$ is a root of a polynomial $f$, then $(x-\alpha)$ divides $f$. This can be shown by writing $f(x) = f(x) - f(\alpha)$ and using the factorization of $x^k - \alpha^k$ for each term. The degree of $g$ is $n-1$ because the leading term of $f$, $a_nx^n$, when divided by $x-\alpha$, yields a leading term $a_nx^{n-1}$ for $g$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Next, suppose that $f(\beta)=0$ with $\beta\neq \alpha$.  Then $(\beta-\alpha) g(\beta) = 0$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a polynomial $g(x) \in k[x]$ such that $f(x) = (x-\alpha)g(x)$ [l2].
• $\beta \in k$ is a root of $f$ and $\beta \neq \alpha$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $(\beta-\alpha) g(\beta) = 0$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $x=\beta$ into the equation $f(x) = (x-\alpha)g(x)$ from [l2]. Since $f(\beta)=0$, we get $0 = (\beta-\alpha)g(\beta)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: so, since $\beta-\alpha\neq 0$ and $k$ is a field,  we have $g(\beta)=0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $k$ is a field [tc_1].
• $(\beta-\alpha) g(\beta) = 0$ [l3].
• $\beta \neq \alpha$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $g(\beta)=0$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Since $k$ is a field, it is an integral domain. As $\beta \neq \alpha$, $\beta - \alpha \neq 0$. In an integral domain, if a product is zero, one of the factors must be zero. Therefore, $g(\beta)=0$.

proof_graph.natural_language: By our inductive hypothesis,~$g$ has at most $n-1$ roots,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The Inductive Hypothesis (IH) holds for polynomials of degree less than $n$ [def_1].
• The polynomial $g(x)$ has degree $n-1$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The polynomial $g$ has at most $n-1$ roots in $k$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the inductive hypothesis [def_1] to the polynomial $g$, since its degree is $n-1 < n$.

proof_graph.natural_language: so there are at most $n-1$ possibilities for~$\beta$. It follows that~$f$ has at most~$n$ roots.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For a given root $\alpha$ of $f$, any other root $\beta$ of $f$ must also be a root of $g$ [l4].
• The polynomial $g$ has at most $n-1$ roots [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The polynomial $f$ has at most $n$ roots [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The set of roots of $f$ is a subset of $\{\alpha\} \cup \{\text{roots of } g\}$. The size of this set is at most $1 + (\text{number of roots of } g)$. Using the bound from [l5], the number of roots of $f$ is at most $1 + (n-1) = n$. This reasoning covers the case where $f$ has at least one root. If $f$ has no roots, the count is 0, which is also $\le n$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $f\in k[x]$ be a nonzero polynomial over a field $k$.  Then there are at most $\deg(f)$ elements $\alpha\in k$ such that $f(\alpha)=0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The proposition holds for polynomials of degree $\le 1$ [l1].
• The proposition holds for a polynomial of degree $n$ if it is assumed to hold for all polynomials of degree less than $n$. (This is the inductive step, proven by [l6]).
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any nonzero polynomial $f \in k[x]$ over a field $k$, the number of roots of $f$ in $k$ is at most $\deg(f)$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The proof is by induction on the degree of the polynomial, $n=\deg(f)$. The base cases ($n=0, 1$) are established in [l1]. The inductive step (for $n>1$) is established in [l6]. By the principle of mathematical induction, the statement holds for all $n \ge 0$.

nl_proof:
The primitive roots modulo~$n$ are the generators of
$(\zmod{n})^*$, which by assumption is cyclic of order~$\vphi(n)$.
Thus they are in bijection with the generators of any cyclic group
of order $\vphi(n)$.  In particular, the number of primitive roots
modulo~$n$ is the same as the number of elements of $\zmod{\vphi(n)}$
with additive order $\vphi(n)$.  An element of $\zmod{\vphi(n)}$ has additive
order $\vphi(n)$ if and only if it is coprime to $\vphi(n)$.  There
are $\vphi(\vphi(n))$ such elements, as claimed.

proof_graph.natural_language: If there is a primitive root modulo~$n$,
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $n$ is a positive integer such that there exists a primitive root modulo $n$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: The primitive roots modulo~$n$ are the generators of $(\zmod{n})^*$,
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The set of primitive roots modulo $n$ is defined as the set of generators of the multiplicative group of integers modulo $n$, $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: which by assumption is cyclic
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a primitive root modulo $n$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The group $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ is a cyclic group [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The existence of a generator (a primitive root) for a group implies the group is cyclic. Use `is_primitive_root.is_cyclic`.

proof_graph.natural_language: of order~$\phi(n)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $n$ is a positive integer [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The order (cardinality) of the group $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ is $\phi(n)$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a standard result from number theory, corresponding to `ZMod.card_units`.

proof_graph.natural_language: Thus they are in bijection with the generators of any cyclic group of order $\phi(n)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The set of primitive roots modulo $n$ is the set of generators of $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ [def_1].
• The group $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ is cyclic [l1].
• The order of $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$ is $\phi(n)$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The number of primitive roots modulo $n$ is equal to the number of generators of any cyclic group of order $\phi(n)$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [def_1], we count generators of $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*$. From [l1] and [l2], this is a cyclic group of order $\phi(n)$. The number of generators in a cyclic group depends only on its order, as all cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic, and isomorphisms preserve generators.

proof_graph.natural_language: In particular, the number of primitive roots modulo~$n$ is the same as the number of elements of $\zmod{\phi(n)}$ with additive order $\phi(n)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The number of primitive roots modulo $n$ is equal to the number of generators of any cyclic group of order $\phi(n)$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The number of primitive roots modulo $n$ is equal to the number of elements in the additive group $\mathbb{Z}/\phi(n)\mathbb{Z}$ that have additive order $\phi(n)$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The additive group $\mathbb{Z}/k\mathbb{Z}$ is a canonical cyclic group of order $k$. Its generators are precisely the elements with additive order $k$. Specialize the general statement [l3] to this group with $k = \phi(n)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: An element of $\zmod{\phi(n)}$ has additive order $\phi(n)$ if and only if it is coprime to $\phi(n)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $k$ is a positive integer.
Therefore, we conclude:
• An element $x$ in the additive group $\mathbb{Z}/k\mathbb{Z}$ has order $k$ if and only if $x$ is coprime to $k$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a standard group theory result. The order of an element `x` in `ZMod k` is `k / gcd(x, k)`. This equals `k` if and only if `gcd(x, k) = 1`. Use a library lemma like `ZMod.orderOf_eq_card_iff_isCoprime`.

proof_graph.natural_language: There are $\phi(\phi(n))$ such elements, as claimed.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
