\end{equation}
Suppose that  $\epsilon>0$. Since $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$
on $S$, we can choose $n$ so that $\|F_n-F\|_S<\epsilon$. For this
fixed  $n$, \eqref{eq:4.4.8} implies that
\begin{equation} \label{eq:4.4.9}
|F(x)-F(x_0)|<|F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)|+2\epsilon,\quad x\in S.
\end{equation}
Since $F_n$ is continuous at $x_0$, there is a $\delta>0$ such that
$$
|F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)|<\epsilon\mbox{\quad if\quad} |x-x_0|<\delta,
$$
so, from \eqref{eq:4.4.9},
$$
|F(x)-F(x_0)|<3\epsilon,\mbox{\quad if\quad} |x-x_0|<\delta.
$$
Therefore, $F$ is continuous at $x_0$. Similar
arguments apply to the assertions on
continuity from the right and left.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $S$ be a metric space. Let $\{F_n\}_{n=1}^\infty$ be a sequence of functions where each $F_n: S \to \mathbb{C}$, and let $F: S \to \mathbb{C}$ be a function. The sequence $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$. This means that for every $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n \ge N$, $\|F_n - F\|_S < \epsilon$, where $\|g\|_S = \sup_{x \in S} |g(x)|$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: and each $F_n$ is continuous at a point $x_0$ in $S,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $S$ be a metric space and $\{F_n\}$ be a sequence of functions $F_n: S \to \mathbb{C}$. There is a point $x_0 \in S$ at which every function $F_n$ in the sequence is continuous. This means that for each $n$, for any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for all $x \in S$, if $|x - x_0| < \delta$, then $|F_n(x) - F_n(x_0)| < \epsilon$ [tc_2].

We assume:
• $\{F_n\}$ is a sequence of functions from $S$ to $\mathbb{C}$, $F$ is a function from $S$ to $\mathbb{C}$ [tc_1].
• $x_0 \in S$ [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x \in S$ and any $n \in \mathbb{N}$, by the triangle inequality, $|F(x)-F(x_0)| \le |F(x)-F_n(x)| + |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + |F_n(x_0)-F(x_0)|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the triangle inequality twice by adding and subtracting the terms $F_n(x)$ and $F_n(x_0)$ inside the absolute value, i.e., $|F(x) - F(x_0)| = |(F(x)-F_n(x)) + (F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)) + (F_n(x_0)-F(x_0))|$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $x \in S$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$, $|F(x)-F(x_0)| \le |F(x)-F_n(x)| + |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + |F_n(x_0)-F(x_0)|$ [l1].
• The supremum norm is defined as $\|g\|_S = \sup_{y \in S} |g(y)|$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x \in S$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$, it holds that $|F(x)-F(x_0)| \le |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + 2\|F_n-F\|_S$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the definition of the supremum norm, which implies $|F(x)-F_n(x)| \le \|F-F_n\|_S$ and $|F_n(x_0)-F(x_0)| \le \|F_n-F\|_S$. Substitute these bounds into the inequality from [l1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that  $\epsilon>0$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• To prove continuity, we start by considering an arbitrary positive real number $\epsilon > 0$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$, we can choose $n$ so that $\|F_n-F\|_S<\epsilon$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The sequence $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$ [tc_1].
• Let $\epsilon > 0$ be a given positive real number [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an integer $n$ such that $\|F_n - F\|_S < \epsilon$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows directly from the definition of uniform convergence stated in [tc_1]. We can choose any integer $n$ greater than or equal to the $N$ provided by the definition.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $x \in S$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$, $|F(x)-F(x_0)| \le |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + 2\|F_n-F\|_S$ [l2].
• For a given $\epsilon>0$, an integer $n$ is chosen such that $\|F_n - F\|_S < \epsilon$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For this specific integer $n$, we have $|F(x)-F(x_0)| < |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + 2\epsilon$ for all $x \in S$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the inequality $\|F_n - F\|_S < \epsilon$ from [l3] into the inequality from [l2]. A strict inequality results because of the strict inequality in [l3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $F_n$ is continuous at $x_0$, there is a $\delta>0$ such that
$$
|F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)|<\epsilon\mbox{\quad if\quad} |x-x_0|<\delta,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For the integer $n$ chosen in [l3], the function $F_n$ is continuous at $x_0$ [tc_2].
• Let $\epsilon > 0$ be a given positive real number [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For this integer $n$ and given $\epsilon>0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $x \in S$, if $|x - x_0| < \delta$, then $|F_n(x) - F_n(x_0)| < \epsilon$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of continuity for the specific function $F_n$ (where $n$ is fixed by [l3]) at the point $x_0$, using the $\epsilon$ from [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
so, from \eqref{eq:4.4.9},
$$
|F(x)-F(x_0)|<3\epsilon,\mbox{\quad if\quad} |x-x_0|<\delta.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For a specific integer $n$ and $\epsilon > 0$, for all $x \in S$, we have $|F(x)-F(x_0)| < |F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| + 2\epsilon$ [l4].
• For the same integer $n$ and $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that if $|x - x_0| < \delta$, then $|F_n(x) - F_n(x_0)| < \epsilon$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For the chosen $\delta > 0$, if $|x - x_0| < \delta$, then $|F(x)-F(x_0)| < 3\epsilon$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Assume $|x-x_0| < \delta$. From [l5], this implies $|F_n(x)-F_n(x_0)| < \epsilon$. Substitute this bound into the inequality from [l4]. Then, $|F(x)-F(x_0)| < \epsilon + 2\epsilon = 3\epsilon$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Therefore, $F$ is continuous at $x_0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for all $x \in S$, if $|x-x_0|<\delta$, then $|F(x)-F(x_0)| < 3\epsilon$ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The function $F$ is continuous at $x_0$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The premise [l6] establishes the epsilon-delta condition for continuity. For any target `ε'`, choose `ε = ε'/3` in the premise. The `δ` that exists for this `ε` will then satisfy $|F(x) - F(x_0)| < 3 * (ε'/3) = ε'$, fulfilling the definition of continuity.

nl_proof:
Since
\begin{eqnarray*}
\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|\ar\le \int_a^b
|F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx\\
\ar\le  (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S
\end{eqnarray*}
and $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$, the conclusion follows.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that  $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S=[a,b]$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• The sequence of functions $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to a function $F$ on the interval $S=[a,b]$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Assume that $F$ and all $F_n$ are integrable on $[a,b]$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• The functions $F$ and $F_n$ for all $n$ are integrable on the interval $[a,b]$ [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|\ar\le \int_a^b
|F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The functions $F$ and $F_n$ for all $n$ are integrable on the interval $[a,b]$ [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $n$, $\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right| \le \int_a^b |F_n(x) - F(x)|\,dx$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the linearity of the integral (`integral_sub`) to write the difference of integrals as the integral of the difference. Then apply the integral modulus inequality (`norm_integral_le_integral_norm`), which states that the absolute value of an integral is less than or equal to the integral of the absolute value of the function.

proof_graph.natural_language:
\int_a^b
|F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx\ar\le  (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The sequence of functions $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to a function $F$ on the interval $S=[a,b]$ [tc_1].
• The functions $F$ and $F_n$ for all $n$ are integrable on the interval $[a,b]$ [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $n$, $\int_a^b |F_n(x) - F(x)|\,dx \le (b-a) \|F_n - F\|_S$, where $\|g\|_S = \sup_{x \in S} |g(x)|$ is the supremum norm [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For any $x \in S = [a,b]$, the definition of the supremum norm implies $|F_n(x) - F(x)| \le \|F_n - F\|_S$. Since this holds for all $x$, we can integrate both sides of the inequality over $[a,b]$. The integral of the constant right-hand side is $(b-a) \|F_n - F\|_S$.

proof_graph.natural_language: and $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The sequence of functions $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to a function $F$ on the interval $S=[a,b]$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{n\to\infty} \|F_n - F\|_S = 0$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the definition of uniform convergence, which is given as a premise.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since
\begin{eqnarray*}
\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|\ar\le \int_a^b
|F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx\\
\ar\le  (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S
\end{eqnarray*}
and $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$, the conclusion follows.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For each $n$, $\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right| \le \int_a^b |F_n(x) - F(x)|\,dx$ [l1].
• For each $n$, $\int_a^b |F_n(x) - F(x)|\,dx \le (b-a) \|F_n - F\|_S$ [l2].
• $\lim_{n\to\infty} \|F_n - F\|_S = 0$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\int_a^b F(x)\,dx=\lim_{n\to\infty}\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine [l1] and [l2] using transitivity of inequality to get $0 \le \left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right| \le (b-a) \|F_n - F\|_S$. Take the limit as $n \to \infty$. By [l3], the limit of the right-hand side is 0. By the Squeeze Theorem, $\lim_{n\to\infty} \left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right| = 0$. This is equivalent to the definition of $\lim_{n\to\infty}\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx = \int_a^b F(x)\,dx$.

nl_theorem:
Suppose that  $f$ is infinitely differentiable on an interval $I$ and
\begin{equation}\label{eq:4.5.18}
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{r^n}{ n!}\|f^{(n)}\|_I=0.
\end{equation}
Then$,$ if $x_0\in I^0,$ the Taylor series
$$
\sum^\infty_{n=0}\frac{f^{(n)}(x_0)}{ n!} (x-x_0)^n
$$
 converges uniformly to $f$ on
$$
I_r=I\cap [x_0-r,x_0+r].
$$
nl_proof:
From \eqref{eq:4.5.17},
$$
\|f-T_n\|_{I_r}\le\frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_{I_r}\le
\frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_I,
$$
so \eqref{eq:4.5.18} implies the conclusion.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that f is infinitely differentiable on an interval I
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $f$ is a function from $\mathbb{R}$ to $\mathbb{R}$ that is infinitely differentiable on an interval $I$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{r^n}{ n!}\|f^{(n)}\|_I=0.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• For a given $r > 0$, $\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{r^n}{ n!}\|f^{(n)}\|_I=0$, where $\|g\|_S = \sup_{x \in S} |g(x)|$ [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: if $x_0\in I^0,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $x_0$ is a point in the interior of the interval $I$ ($x_0 \in I^0$) [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
the Taylor series
$$
\sum^\infty_{n=0}\frac{f^{(n)}(x_0)}{ n!} (x-x_0)^n
$$
 converges uniformly to $f$ on
$$
I_r=I\cap [x_0-r,x_0+r].
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definitions:
• The n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ centered at $x_0$ is $T_n(x; x_0) = \sum^n_{k=0}\frac{f^{(k)}(x_0)}{ k!} (x-x_0)^k$ [def_1a].
• The interval of convergence $I_r$ is defined as $I_r = I \cap [x_0-r, x_0+r]$ [def_1b].

We assume:
• $f$ is infinitely differentiable on an interval $I$ [tc_1].
• $x_0$ is a point in the interior of $I$ [tc_3].
• The n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ centered at $x_0$ is $T_n(x; x_0) = \sum^n_{k=0}\frac{f^{(k)}(x_0)}{ k!} (x-x_0)^k$ [def_1a].
• The interval $I_r$ is defined as $I_r = I \cap [x_0-r, x_0+r]$ [def_1b].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $n \ge 0$, the supremum norm of the remainder satisfies $\|f-T_n(x;x_0)\|_{I_r} \le \frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_I$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Chain two inequalities. First, use Taylor's remainder theorem (the referenced eq. 4.5.17) to get $\|f-T_n\|_{I_r} \le \frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_{I_r}$. Second, use the fact that $I_r \subseteq I$ (from [def_1b]) implies $\|f^{(n+1)}\|_{I_r} \le \|f^{(n+1)}\|_I$. Combine using transitivity of '≤'.

proof_graph.natural_language: so \eqref{eq:4.5.18} implies the conclusion.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{r^n}{ n!}\|f^{(n)}\|_I=0$ [tc_2].
• For any $n \ge 0$, $\|f-T_n(x;x_0)\|_{I_r} \le \frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_I$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The Taylor series of $f$ at $x_0$ converges uniformly to $f$ on $I_r$. Formally, this means $\lim_{n\to\infty} \|f - T_n(x; x_0)\|_{I_r} = 0$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: To show uniform convergence, we show the supremum norm of the remainder tends to zero. We have $0 \le \|f-T_n\|_{I_r}$. From [l1], we have an upper bound. The limit of this upper bound as $n \to \infty$ is 0, which follows from [tc_2] by a change of index ($k=n+1$). By the Squeeze Theorem, $\lim_{n\to\infty} \|f - T_n\|_{I_r} = 0$.

nl_proof:
By definition,
\begin{equation} \label{eq:5.1.7}
\begin{array}{rcl}
|\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{Y}|^2\ar=\dst\sum^n_{i=1} (x_i+y_i)^2=\sum^n_{i=1} x^2_i+
2\sum^n_{i=1} x_iy_i+\sum^n_{i=1}y^2_i\\[4\jot]
\ar=|\mathbf{X}|^2+2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})+|\mathbf{Y}|^2\\[2\jot]
\ar\le  |\mathbf{X}|^2+2|\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|+|\mathbf{Y}|^2\mbox{\quad (by
Schwarz's inequality)}\\[2\jot]
\ar=(|\mathbf{X}|+|\mathbf{Y}|)^2.
\end{array}
\end{equation}
Hence,
$$
|\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{Y}|^2\le (|\mathbf{X}|+|\mathbf{Y}|)^2.
$$
Taking square roots yields \eqref{eq:5.1.6}.
From the third line of \eqref{eq:5.1.7},
equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.6} if and
only  if $\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}=|\mathbf{X}||\mathbf{Y}|$, which is true if
and
only if one of the vectors $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ is a nonnegative
scalar multiple of the other (Lemma~\ref{thmtype:5.1.5}).

Premise:

proof_graph.natural_language:

\ar=|\mathbf{X}|^2+2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})+|\mathbf{Y}|^2

Therefore, we conclude:

proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the algebraic identity $a^2 + 2ab + b^2 = (a+b)^2$.

• The norm of a vector is a non-negative real number.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{Y}| \le |\mathbf{X}|+|\mathbf{Y}|$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Take the square root of both sides of the inequality from l4. Since the square root function is monotonically increasing for non-negative inputs, the inequality is preserved.

proof_graph.natural_language:
equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.6} if and

and

scalar multiple of the other (Lemma~\ref{thmtype:5.1.5}).

We assume:

Therefore, we conclude:

nl_theorem:
If $\mathbf{X},$ $\mathbf{Y},$ and
$\mathbf{Z}$ are members of $\R^n$ and $a$ is a scalar, then
\begin{alist}
\item % (a)
 $|a\mathbf{X}|=|a|\,|\mathbf{X}|.$
\item % (b)
 $|\mathbf{X}|\ge0,$ with equality if and only if $\mathbf{X}=
\mathbf{0}.$
\item % (c)
 $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|\ge0,$ with equality if and only if
$\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{Y}.$
\item % (d)
$\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{Y}\cdot\mathbf{X}.$
\item % (e)
 $\mathbf{X}\cdot (\mathbf{Y}+\mathbf{Z})=\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}+
\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Z}.$
\item % (f)
 $(c\mathbf{X})\cdot\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{X}\cdot (c\mathbf{Y})=
c(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}).$
\end{alist}
nl_proof:
The line segment is given by
$$
\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1,\quad 0<t<1.
$$
Suppose that $r>0$. If
$$
|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,\quad |\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,
$$
and $0<t<1$, then
\begin{eqnarray*}
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|\ar=|t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-t\mathbf{X}_0-(1-t)\mathbf{X}_0|\\
\ar=|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|\\
\ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|\\
\ar< tr+(1-t)r=r.
\end{eqnarray*}
\vskip-2em

$\mathbf{Z}$ are members of $\R^n$ and $a$ is a scalar

• The vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ are members of $\R^n$ and $t, r, a, c$ are real scalars [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $r>0$.

proof_graph.natural_language: $|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$

proof_graph.natural_language: $|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$

proof_graph.natural_language:
The line segment is given by

Definition:

proof_graph.natural_language: $|a\mathbf{X}|=|a|\,|\mathbf{X}|.$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}$ is a member of $\R^n$ and $a$ is a scalar [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The norm of a scaled vector is $|a\mathbf{X}|=|a|\,|\mathbf{X}|$ [l_bg_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a known property of the Euclidean norm, `norm_smul`.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}$ are members of $\R^n$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The triangle inequality holds: $|\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}| \le |\mathbf{A}| + |\mathbf{B}|$ [l_bg_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the triangle inequality for the Euclidean norm, `norm_add_le`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
$|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|\ar=|t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-t\mathbf{X}_0-(1-t)\mathbf{X}_0|\\
\ar=|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2, \mathbf{X}$ are members of $\R^n$ and $t$ is a real scalar [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{X} = t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0| = |t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definition of X [def_1] into |X-X₀|. Then, rewrite X₀ as `1*X₀ = (t + (1-t))*X₀` and use vector algebra to group terms. The expression `(1-t)X₁-X₀` in the natural language text is a typo for `(1-t)(X₁-X₀)`.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ are members of $\R^n$ and $t$ is a real scalar [tc_1].
• $0 < t < 1$ [tc_5].
• The norm property $|a\mathbf{V}|=|a|\,|\mathbf{V}|$ holds for any vector V and scalar a [l_bg_1].
• The triangle inequality $|\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}| \le |\mathbf{A}| + |\mathbf{B}|$ holds for any vectors A, B [l_bg_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)| \le t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the triangle inequality [l_bg_2] with A = t(X₂-X₀) and B = (1-t)(X₁-X₀). Then apply the scalar property [l_bg_1] to each term. Use `0 < t < 1` [tc_5] to show that |t| = t and |1-t| = 1-t.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\ar< tr+(1-t)r$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ are members of $\R^n$ and $t,r$ are real scalars [tc_1].
• $r>0$ [tc_2].
• $|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ [tc_3].
• $|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ [tc_4].
• $0 < t < 1$ [tc_5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0| < tr+(1-t)r$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From `0 < t < 1` [tc_5], we know `t > 0` and `1-t > 0`. Multiply `|X₂-X₀| < r` [tc_4] by `t` to get `t|X₂-X₀| < tr`. Multiply `|X₁-X₀| < r` [tc_3] by `1-t` to get `(1-t)|X₁-X₀| < (1-t)r`. Add the two resulting inequalities.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $t, r$ are real scalars [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $tr+(1-t)r = r$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the `ring` tactic to simplify the expression.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0| = |t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|$ [l1].
• $|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)| \le t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$ [l2].
• $t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0| < tr+(1-t)r$ [l3].
• $tr+(1-t)r = r$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0| < r$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine the equality [l1], inequalities [l2], [l3], and the final equality [l4] using transitivity, for example in a `calc` block.

nl_theorem:
Let $f$ be a real-valued function defined on a subset of $\R^n,$
 and let the
vector-valued function $\mathbf{G}=(g_1,g_2, \dots,g_n)$ be defined on a
domain $D_\mathbf{G}$ in $\R^m.$ Let the set
$$
T=\set{\mathbf{U}}{\mathbf{U}\in D_{\mathbf{G}}\mbox{\quad and \quad}
\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})\in D_f}
$$
$($Figure~\ref{figure:5.2.3}$)$,
 be
nonempty$,$ and define the real-valued composite function
$$
h=f\circ\mathbf{G}
$$
on $T$ by
$$
h(\mathbf{U})=f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})),\quad \mathbf{U}\in T.
$$
Now suppose that  $\mathbf{U}_0$ is in $T$ and is a limit point of $T,$
$\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0,$ and $f$ is continuous at
$\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0).$ Then $h$ is continuous at
$\mathbf{U}_0.$
nl_proof:
Suppose that  $\epsilon>0$. Since $f$ is continuous at
$\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)$, there is an $\epsilon_1>0$
such that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.2.17}
|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))|<\epsilon
\end{equation}
if
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.2.18}
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)|<\epsilon_1\mbox{\quad and\quad}
\mathbf{X}\in D_f.
\end{equation}
Since $\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0$, there is a $\delta>0$
such that
$$
|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)|<\epsilon_1
\mbox{\quad if\quad} |\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0|<
\delta\mbox{\quad and\quad}\mathbf{U}\in D_\mathbf{G}.
$$
By taking $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})$ in \eqref{eq:5.2.17} and
\eqref{eq:5.2.18}, we see that
$$
|h(\mathbf{U})-h(\mathbf{U}_0)|=|f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})
-f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))|<\epsilon
$$
if
$$
|\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0|<\delta\mbox{\quad and\quad}\mathbf{U}\in T.
$$

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $f$ be a real-valued function defined on a subset of $\R^n,$ and let the vector-valued function $\mathbf{G}=(g_1,g_2, \dots,g_n)$ be defined on a domain $D_\mathbf{G}$ in $\R^m.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $f: D_f \subseteq \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}$ is a real-valued function with domain $D_f$.
• $\mathbf{G}: D_{\mathbf{G}} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^m \to \mathbb{R}^n$ is a vector-valued function with domain $D_{\mathbf{G}}$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let the set
$$
T=\set{\mathbf{U}}{\mathbf{U}\in D_{\mathbf{G}}\mbox{\quad and \quad}
\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})\in D_f}
$$
be
nonempty
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Given a function $f$ with domain $D_f$ and a function $\mathbf{G}$ with domain $D_{\mathbf{G}}$ [tc_1].
• The set $T = \{\mathbf{U} \in D_{\mathbf{G}} \mid \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}) \in D_f\}$ is nonempty [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
define the real-valued composite function
$$
h=f\circ\mathbf{G}
$$
on $T$ by
$$
h(\mathbf{U})=f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})),\quad \mathbf{U}\in T.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Given functions $f$, $\mathbf{G}$ and the domain $T$ [tc_1, tc_2].
• The composite function $h: T \to \mathbb{R}$ is defined by $h(\mathbf{U}) = f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}))$ for $\mathbf{U} \in T$ [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: Now suppose that  $\mathbf{U}_0$ is in $T$ and is a limit point of $T,$ $\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0,$ and $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0).$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• We have functions $f$, $\mathbf{G}$, and $h=f \circ \mathbf{G}$ with domains $D_f, D_{\mathbf{G}}, T$ [tc_1, tc_2, tc_3].
• $\mathbf{U}_0 \in T$ and $\mathbf{U}_0$ is a limit point of $T$.
• $\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0_$.
• $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0 = \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)$ [tc_4].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)$, there is an $\epsilon_1>0$ such that
|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))|<\epsilon
if
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)|<\epsilon_1\mbox{\quad and\quad}
\mathbf{X}\in D_f.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0 = \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)$ [tc_4].
• $\epsilon > 0$ is a given positive real number.
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an $\epsilon_1 > 0$ such that for any $\mathbf{X} \in D_f$ satisfying $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)| < \epsilon_1$, we have $|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))| < \epsilon$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the epsilon-delta definition of continuity for function f at point X₀.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0$, there is a $\delta>0$ such that
$$
|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)|<\epsilon_1
\mbox{\quad if\quad} |\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0|<\delta\mbox{\quad and\quad}\mathbf{U}\in D_\mathbf{G}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0$ [tc_4].
• For a given $\epsilon>0$, there exists an $\epsilon_1 > 0$ from the continuity of $f$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For this $\epsilon_1$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $\mathbf{U} \in D_{\mathbf{G}}$ satisfying $|\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0| < \delta$, we have $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)| < \epsilon_1$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the epsilon-delta definition of continuity for function G at point U₀, using ε₁ from l1 as the specified positive number.

proof_graph.natural_language:
By taking $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})$ in \eqref{eq:5.2.17} and \eqref{eq:5.2.18}, we see that
$$
|h(\mathbf{U})-h(\mathbf{U}_0)|=|f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})) -f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))|<\epsilon
$$
if
$$
|\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0|<\delta\mbox{\quad and\quad}\mathbf{U}\in T.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The composite function $h: T \to \mathbb{R}$ is defined by $h(\mathbf{U}) = f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}))$ for $\mathbf{U} \in T$ [tc_3].
• The set $T = \{\mathbf{U} \in D_{\mathbf{G}} \mid \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}) \in D_f\}$ [tc_2].
• For a given $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an $\epsilon_1 > 0$ such that for any $\mathbf{X} \in D_f$ with $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)| < \epsilon_1$, we have $|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0))| < \epsilon$ [l1].
• For this $\epsilon_1$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $\mathbf{U} \in D_{\mathbf{G}}$ with $|\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0| < \delta$, we have $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0)| < \epsilon_1$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For the given $\epsilon > 0$ and the derived $\delta > 0$, any $\mathbf{U} \in T$ satisfying $|\mathbf{U}-\mathbf{U}_0| < \delta$ also satisfies $|h(\mathbf{U})-h(\mathbf{U}_0)| < \epsilon$. This shows $h$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U_0}$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let U ∈ T with |U - U₀| < δ. From tc_2, U ∈ D_G and G(U) ∈ D_f. From U ∈ D_G and |U - U₀| < δ, use l2 to get |G(U) - G(U₀)| < ε₁. Let X = G(U). Now, X ∈ D_f and |X - G(U₀)| < ε₁. Use l1 to get |f(X) - f(G(U₀))| < ε. By definition tc_3, this is |h(U) - h(U₀)| < ε.

nl_theorem:
If $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0=(x_{10},x_{20}, \dots,x_{n0}),$
then $f_{x_1}(\mathbf{X}_0),$ $f_{x_2}(\mathbf{X}_{0}),$
\dots$,$ $f_{x_n}(\mathbf{X}_0)$ exist and
the constants
 $m_1,$ $m_2,$ \dots$,$ $m_n$ in $\eqref{eq:5.3.16}$
are given by
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.3.18}
m_i=f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0),\quad 1\le i\le n;
\end{equation}
that is$,$
$$
\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-
\dst{\sum^n_{i=1}}\, f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) (x_i-x_{i0})}
{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0.
$$
nl_proof:
Let
 $i$ be a given integer in $\{1,2, \dots,n\}$.
Let $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i$, so that $x_i=x_{i0}+t$,
$x_j =x_{j0}$ if $j\ne i$, and $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|=|t|$. Then
\eqref{eq:5.3.16}
and the differentiability of $f$ at $\mathbf{X}_0$ imply that
$$
\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-m_it}{ t}=0.
$$
\newpage
\noindent
Hence,
$$
\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}=m_i.
$$
\vskip6pt
\noindent
This proves \eqref{eq:5.3.18}, since the limit on the left is
$f_{x_i}
(\mathbf{X}_0)$, by definition.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0=(x_{10},x_{20}, \dots,x_{n0}),$ ... the constants $m_1,$ $m_2,$ \dots$,$ $m_n$ in $\eqref{eq:5.3.16}$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $f: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function. $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0 \in \mathbb{R}^n$ means there exist constants $m_1, m_2, \dots, m_n$ such that $\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)- \sum^n_{i=1} m_i (x_i-x_{i0})}{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0$. This property is denoted as (5.3.16) [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let
 $i$ be a given integer in $\{1,2, \dots,n\}$.
Let $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i$, so that $x_i=x_{i0}+t$,
$x_j =x_{j0}$ if $j\ne i$, and $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|=|t|$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let $i$ be a fixed integer in $\{1, 2, \dots, n\}$. Let $\mathbf{E}_i$ be the $i$-th standard basis vector in $\mathbb{R}^n$. Define a path $\mathbf{X}(t) = \mathbf{X}_0 + t\mathbf{E}_i$ for $t \in \mathbb{R}$. This implies that the components of $\mathbf{X}$ are $x_i = x_{i0} + t$ and $x_j = x_{j0}$ for $j \neq i$. Furthermore, the distance is $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0| = |t|$. As $\mathbf{X} \to \mathbf{X}_0$, we have $t \to 0$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Then
\eqref{eq:5.3.16}
and the differentiability of $f$ at $\mathbf{X}_0$ imply that
$$
\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-m_it}{ t}=0.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0$, meaning there exist constants $m_1, \dots, m_n$ such that $\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)- \sum^n_{i=1} m_i (x_i-x_{i0})}{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0$ [tc_1].
• A path is defined as $\mathbf{X}(t) = \mathbf{X}_0 + t\mathbf{E}_i$, which implies $x_i = x_{i0} + t$, $x_j = x_{j0}$ for $j \neq i$, and $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0| = |t|$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-m_it}{ t}=0$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the path definition from `def_1` into the limit expression of differentiability `tc_1`. Note that the sum $\sum^n_{j=1} m_j (x_j - x_{j0})$ simplifies to $m_i(x_i - x_{i0}) = m_it$. The limit $\mathbf{X} \to \mathbf{X}_0$ becomes $t \to 0$. The fact that the limit of the expression with denominator $|t|$ is 0 implies the limit with denominator $t$ is also 0.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Hence,
$$
\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}=m_i.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-m_it}{ t}=0$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}=m_i$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply limit properties to the equation in `l1`. Split the fraction: $\frac{A-B}{C} = \frac{A}{C} - \frac{B}{C}$. The limit of a sum is the sum of the limits. The term $\frac{m_it}{t}$ simplifies to $m_i$, which is a constant. Then, move the constant term to the other side of the equation.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• (general mathematical knowledge)
Therefore, we conclude:
• The partial derivative of $f$ with respect to $x_i$ at $\mathbf{X}_0$ is defined as $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) = \lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the definition of a partial derivative along a coordinate axis.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For a fixed $i \in \{1, ..., n\}$, we have $\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}=m_i$ [l2].
• The partial derivative is defined as $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) = \lim_{t\to 0}\frac{f(\mathbf{X}_0+t\mathbf{E}_i)-f(\mathbf{X}_0)}{ t}$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $i \in \{1, \dots, n\}$, the partial derivative $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)$ exists and $m_i=f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From `l2`, the limit exists and is equal to the finite constant $m_i$. By definition `l3`, this limit is the partial derivative $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)$. Therefore, the partial derivative exists and equals $m_i$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
that is$,$
$$
\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)-
\dst{\sum^n_{i=1}}\, f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) (x_i-x_{i0})}
{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0$, meaning $\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)- \sum^n_{i=1} m_i (x_i-x_{i0})}{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0$ for some constants $m_i$ [tc_1].
• For each $i$, the constant $m_i$ is equal to the partial derivative $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)$ [ts_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{\mathbf{X}\to\mathbf{X}_0} \frac{f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)- \sum^n_{i=1} f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) (x_i-x_{i0})}{ |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|}=0$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $m_i$ with $f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)$ (from `ts_1`) in the differentiability definition from `tc_1`.

nl_theorem:
If $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0,$ then $f$
is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0$.
nl_proof:
From \eqref{eq:5.3.19} and Schwarz's inequality,
$$
|L(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0)|\le M|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|,
$$
where
$$
M=(m^2_1+m^2_2+\cdots+m^2_n)^{1/2}.
$$
This and \eqref{eq:5.3.20} imply that
$$
|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)|\le(M+|E(\mathbf{X})|)
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|,
$$
which, with \eqref{eq:5.3.21}, implies that $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $f$ is differentiable at $\mathbf{X}_0,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let f be a function from a domain D ⊆ ℝⁿ to ℝ, and let X₀ be an interior point of D. f is differentiable at X₀. [tc_1]

proof_graph.natural_language: From \eqref{eq:5.3.19}
proof_graph.statement:
Definition (inferred context for (5.3.19)):
• The premise that f is differentiable at X₀ [tc_1] implies the existence of a linear map L. This map is represented by a constant vector m = (m₁, ..., mₙ) (the gradient of f at X₀) such that L(H) = m ⋅ H. For H = X - X₀, we have L(X - X₀) = Σᵢ mᵢ(xᵢ - x₀ᵢ). [def_1]

proof_graph.natural_language: and \eqref{eq:5.3.20}
proof_graph.statement:
Definition (inferred context for (5.3.20)):
• The premise that f is differentiable at X₀ [tc_1] means that f(X) - f(X₀) can be written as f(X) - f(X₀) = L(X - X₀) + E(X)|X - X₀|, where L is the linear map from [def_1] and E(X) is an error function. [def_2]

proof_graph.natural_language: with \eqref{eq:5.3.21}
proof_graph.statement:
Definition (inferred context for (5.3.21)):
• The error function E(X) from the definition of differentiability [def_2] satisfies the condition lim_{X → X₀} E(X) = 0. [def_3]

Definition:
• Given the vector m = (m₁, ..., mₙ) from the definition of the linear map L [def_1], we define the scalar M as its Euclidean norm: M = (Σᵢ mᵢ²)^{1/2}. [def_4]

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \eqref{eq:5.3.19} and Schwarz's inequality,
$$
|L(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0)|\le M|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The linear map L is given by L(X - X₀) = m ⋅ (X - X₀) [def_1].
• M is the Euclidean norm of the vector m [def_4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• |L(X - X₀)| ≤ M |X - X₀| [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Represent L(X - X₀) as the dot product m ⋅ (X - X₀). Apply the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality |a ⋅ b| ≤ |a| |b|. Substitute |m| with M from [def_4] and identify |X - X₀| as the Euclidean norm of the vector (X - X₀).

proof_graph.natural_language:
This and \eqref{eq:5.3.20} imply that
$$
|f(\mathbf{X})-f(\mathbf{X}_0)|\le(M+|E(\mathbf{X})|)
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The definition of differentiability states f(X) - f(X₀) = L(X - X₀) + E(X)|X - X₀| [def_2].
• The term |L(X - X₀)| is bounded by M |X - X₀| [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• |f(X) - f(X₀)| ≤ (M + |E(X)|) |X - X₀| [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Take the absolute value of the equation in [def_2]. Apply the triangle inequality |a+b| ≤ |a|+|b| to the right-hand side. Substitute the bound for |L(X - X₀)| from [l1]. Factor out the common term |X - X₀|.

proof_graph.natural_language: which, with \eqref{eq:5.3.21}, implies that $f$ is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For all X in a neighborhood of X₀, the inequality |f(X) - f(X₀)| ≤ (M + |E(X)|) |X - X₀| holds [l2].
• The error function satisfies lim_{X → X₀} E(X) = 0 [def_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• f is continuous at X₀ (which is defined as lim_{X → X₀} f(X) = f(X₀)). [ts_1]
proof_graph.lean_hint: To prove continuity, show that lim_{X → X₀} |f(X) - f(X₀)| = 0. Use the Squeeze Theorem. The expression is bounded below by 0. From [l2], it is bounded above by (M + |E(X)|)|X - X₀|. Show this upper bound tends to 0 as X → X₀ by using [def_3] (which implies lim |E(X)| = 0) and the fact that lim |X - X₀| = 0.

nl_theorem:
Let $f$ be continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1=(x_{11},x_{21}, \dots, x_{n1})$
and $\mathbf{X}_2=(x_{12},x_{22}, \dots,x_{n2})$ and differentiable on the
line segment $L$ from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2.$ Then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:5.4.21}
f(\mathbf{X}_2)-f(\mathbf{X}_1)=\sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i} (\mathbf{X}_0)(x_{i2}-x_{i1})=(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{X}_2
-\mathbf{X}_1)
\end{equation}
for some $\mathbf{X}_0$ on $L$ distinct
from $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$.

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

If $f$ is continuous on the closed interval $[a,b]$ and differentiable
on the open interval $(a,b),$ then
$$
f'(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{ b-a}
$$
for some $c$ in $(a,b).$
nl_proof:
An equation of $L$ is
$$
\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{X}(t)=t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1,\quad 0\le t\le1.
$$
Our hypotheses imply that the function
$$
h(t)=f(\mathbf{X}(t))
$$
is continuous on $[0,1]$ and differentiable on $(0,1)$.  Since
$$
x_i(t)=tx_{i2}+(1-t)x_{i1},
$$
\eqref{eq:5.4.20} implies that
$$
h'(t)=\sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}(t))(x_{i2}-x_{i1}),\quad 0<t<1.
$$
From the mean value theorem for functions of one variable
(Theorem~\ref{thmtype:2.3.11}),
$$
h(1)-h(0)=h'(t_0)
$$
for some $t_0\in (0,1)$.  Since $h(1)=f(\mathbf{X}_2)$ and
$h(0)=f(\mathbf{X}_1)$, this implies \eqref{eq:5.4.21} with
$\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{X}(t_0)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $f$ be continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1=(x_{11},x_{21}, \dots, x_{n1})$ and $\mathbf{X}_2=(x_{12},x_{22}, \dots,x_{n2})$ and differentiable on the line segment $L$ from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ are points in $\mathbb{R}^n$.
• $L$ is the line segment from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2$.
• $f: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}$ is a function that is continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$, and differentiable on $L$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If $f$ is continuous on the closed interval $[a,b]$ and differentiable on the open interval $(a,b),$ then $f'(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{ b-a}$ for some $c$ in $(a,b).$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The Mean Value Theorem for a single-variable function $g$ states that if $g$ is continuous on $[a,b]$ and differentiable on $(a,b)$, then there exists some $c \in (a,b)$ such that $g(b) - g(a) = (b-a)g'(c)$ [def_mvt].

proof_graph.natural_language:
An equation of $L$ is
$$
\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{X}(t)=t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1,\quad 0\le t\le1.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ are points in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].
Definition:
• The line segment $L$ is parameterized by the function $\mathbf{X}(t) = (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1 + t\mathbf{X}_2$ for $t \in [0,1]$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Our hypotheses imply that the function
$$
h(t)=f(\mathbf{X}(t))
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is a function from $\mathbb{R}^n$ to $\mathbb{R}$ [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{X}(t)$ is a path in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [def_1].
Definition:
• A single-variable function $h(t)$ is defined as the composition $h(t) = f(\mathbf{X}(t))$ for $t \in [0,1]$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Our hypotheses imply that the function
$$
h(t)=f(\mathbf{X}(t))
$$
is continuous on $[0,1]$ and differentiable on $(0,1)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is continuous and differentiable on the line segment $L$ [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{X}(t)$ parameterizes $L$ for $t \in [0,1]$ [def_1].
• $h(t) = f(\mathbf{X}(t))$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The function $h(t)$ is continuous on the interval $[0,1]$ and differentiable on $(0,1)$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The composition of a differentiable function and a linear function is differentiable. The composition of continuous functions is continuous.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since
$$
x_i(t)=tx_{i2}+(1-t)x_{i1},
$$
\eqref{eq:5.4.20} implies that
$$
h'(t)=\sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}(t))(x_{i2}-x_{i1}),\quad 0<t<1.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $f$ is differentiable on $L$ with partial derivatives $f_{x_i}$ [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{X}(t) = (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1 + t\mathbf{X}_2$ [def_1].
• $h(t) = f(\mathbf{X}(t))$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• By the multivariable chain rule, the derivative of $h(t)$ for $t \in (0,1)$ is $h'(t) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}(t))(x_{i2}-x_{i1})$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the chain rule for vector functions. The derivative of the i-th component of $\mathbf{X}(t)$, which is $x_i(t) = (1-t)x_{i1} + tx_{i2}$, is $x_{i2}-x_{i1}$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
From the mean value theorem for functions of one variable
(Theorem~\ref{thmtype:2.3.11}),
$$
h(1)-h(0)=h'(t_0)
$$
for some $t_0\in (0,1)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $h(t)$ is continuous on $[0,1]$ and differentiable on $(0,1)$ [l1].
• The Mean Value Theorem holds for single-variable functions [def_mvt].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists some $t_0 \in (0,1)$ such that $h(1) - h(0) = (1-0)h'(t_0) = h'(t_0)$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the Mean Value Theorem to the function h(t) on the interval [0,1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $h(1)=f(\mathbf{X}_2)$ and
$h(0)=f(\mathbf{X}_1)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}(t) = (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1 + t\mathbf{X}_2$ [def_1].
• $h(t) = f(\mathbf{X}(t))$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• At the endpoints, $h(0) = f(\mathbf{X}(0)) = f(\mathbf{X}_1)$ and $h(1) = f(\mathbf{X}(1)) = f(\mathbf{X}_2)$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Evaluate $\mathbf{X}(t)$ at $t=0$ and $t=1$ and substitute into the definition of $h(t)$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
=(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{X}_2
-\mathbf{X}_1)
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• The differential of a function $f$ at a point $\mathbf{X}_0$, applied to a vector $\mathbf{V} = (v_1, \dots, v_n)$, is given by $(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{V}) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) v_i$ [def_3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $h(1)=f(\mathbf{X}_2)$ and
$h(0)=f(\mathbf{X}_1)$, this implies \eqref{eq:5.4.21} with
$\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{X}(t_0)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists $t_0 \in (0,1)$ such that $h(1) - h(0) = h'(t_0)$ [l3].
• $h(0) = f(\mathbf{X}_1)$ and $h(1) = f(\mathbf{X}_2)$ [l4].
• The derivative is $h'(t) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}(t))(x_{i2}-x_{i1})$ [l2].
• The line is $\mathbf{X}(t) = (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1 + t\mathbf{X}_2$ [def_1].
• The differential is $(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{V}) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0) v_i$ [def_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a point $\mathbf{X}_0 = \mathbf{X}(t_0)$ on the line segment $L$ distinct from $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ such that $f(\mathbf{X}_2) - f(\mathbf{X}_1) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\mathbf{X}_0)(x_{i2}-x_{i1})$ and this sum is equal to $(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_1)$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute [l4] into [l3] to get $f(\mathbf{X}_2) - f(\mathbf{X}_1) = h'(t_0)$. Let $\mathbf{X}_0 = \mathbf{X}(t_0)$. Use [l2] to substitute the expression for $h'(t_0)$. The property of $\mathbf{X}_0$ follows from $t_0 \in (0,1)$. The final equality follows by applying the definition of the differential [def_3] with vector $\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_1$.

nl_theorem:
Suppose that $u$ is continuous and $v$ is integrable and nonnegative
on a rectangle $R.$ Then
$$
\int_R u(\mathbf{X})v(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=
u(\mathbf{X}_0)\int_R v(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}
$$
for some $\mathbf{X}_0$ in $R.$
nl_proof:
Exercise~\ref{exer:7.1.25}.
\begin{lemma}\label{thmtype:7.1.29}
Suppose that $S$ is contained in a bounded set $T$ and $f$ is integrable
on $S.$ Then
 $f_S$ $($see $\eqref{eq:7.1.36})$ is integrable on $T,$ and
$$
\int_T f_S(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=\int_S f(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}.
$$
\end{lemma}
\nopagebreak

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that u is continuous and v is integrable and nonnegative on a rectangle R.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• R is a rectangle in ℝⁿ [tc_1]
• u: R → ℝ is a continuous function [tc_1]
• v: R → ℝ is an integrable function [tc_1]
• For all X in R, v(X) ≥ 0 [tc_1]

proof_graph.natural_language:
Then
$$
\int_R u(\mathbf{X})v(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=
u(\mathbf{X}_0)\int_R v(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}
$$
for some $\mathbf{X}_0$ in $R.$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• R is a rectangle in ℝⁿ [tc_1]
• u: R → ℝ is a continuous function [tc_1]
• v: R → ℝ is an integrable function [tc_1]
• For all X in R, v(X) ≥ 0 [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an element X₀ in R such that ∫_R u(X)v(X) dX = u(X₀) * ∫_R v(X) dX [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The provided text does not contain a proof for this theorem; it refers to an external exercise. A formal proof would require constructing the argument from first principles, likely involving properties of continuous functions on compact sets (min/max values) and the Intermediate Value Theorem.

nl_proof:
From \part{a} with $u=x-y$, $\rho(x,y)=N(x-y)\ge0$, with equality
if and only if $x=y$.  From \part{b} with $u=x-y$   and $a=-1$,
$$
\rho(y,x)=N(y-x)=N(-(x-y))=N(x-y)=\rho(x,y).
$$
From \part{c} with $u=x-z$ and $v=z-y$,
$$
\rho(x,y)=N(x-y)\le N(x-z)+N(z-y)=\rho(x,z)+\rho(z,y).
$$
\vskip-2em

proof_graph.natural_language: If $(A,N)$ is a normed vector space
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $(A, N)$ is a normed vector space, where $A$ is a vector space over a field $\mathbb{K}$ (e.g., $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{C}$) and $N: A \to \mathbb{R}$ is a norm satisfying:
  (a) For all $u \in A$, $N(u) \ge 0$, and $N(u) = 0 \iff u = 0$.
  (b) For all $u \in A$ and $a \in \mathbb{K}$, $N(a \cdot u) = |a| \cdot N(u)$.
  (c) For all $u, v \in A$, $N(u+v) \le N(u) + N(v)$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: $\rho(x,y)=N(x-y)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $(A,N)$ is a normed vector space [tc_1].
Definition:
• A function $\rho: A \times A \to \mathbb{R}$ is defined for all $x, y \in A$ as $\rho(x,y) = N(x-y)$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \part{a} with $u=x-y$, $\rho(x,y)=N(x-y)\ge0$, with equality
if and only if $x=y$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $(A, N)$ is a normed vector space, where for all $u \in A$, $N(u) \ge 0$, and $N(u) = 0 \iff u = 0$ (axiom (a)) [tc_1].
• The function $\rho$ is defined as $\rho(x,y) = N(x-y)$ for all $x, y \in A$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x, y \in A$, $\rho(x,y) \ge 0$, and $\rho(x,y) = 0 \iff x=y$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Unfold the definition of `ρ` using [def_1]. The goal becomes proving $N(x-y) \ge 0$ and $N(x-y) = 0 \iff x=y$. This follows from the positive definiteness axiom of a norm (axiom (a)) from [tc_1] by substituting $u = x-y$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \part{b} with $u=x-y$ and $a=-1$,
$$
\rho(y,x)=N(y-x)=N(-(x-y))=N(x-y)=\rho(x,y).
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $(A, N)$ is a normed vector space, where for all $u \in A$ and scalar $a$, $N(a \cdot u) = |a| \cdot N(u)$ (axiom (b)) and $A$ is a vector space [tc_1].
• The function $\rho$ is defined as $\rho(x,y) = N(x-y)$ for all $x, y \in A$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x, y \in A$, $\rho(y,x) = \rho(x,y)$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use a calculation block. Start with `ρ(y,x)`. Use [def_1] to get `N(y-x)`. In the vector space $A$, rewrite `y-x` as `-(x-y)`. Use the norm's absolute homogeneity axiom (axiom (b)) from [tc_1] with `a = -1` and `u = x-y` to show `N(-(x-y)) = N(x-y)`. Use [def_1] again to get `ρ(x,y)`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \part{c} with $u=x-z$ and $v=z-y$,
$$
\rho(x,y)=N(x-y)\le N(x-z)+N(z-y)=\rho(x,z)+\rho(z,y).
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $(A, N)$ is a normed vector space, where for all $u, v \in A$, $N(u+v) \le N(u) + N(v)$ (axiom (c)) and $A$ is a vector space [tc_1].
• The function $\rho$ is defined as $\rho(x,y) = N(x-y)$ for all $x, y \in A$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $x, y, z \in A$, $\rho(x,y) \le \rho(x,z) + \rho(z,y)$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use a calculation block. Start with `ρ(x,y)`. Use [def_1] to get `N(x-y)`. In the vector space $A$, rewrite `x-y` as `(x-z) + (z-y)`. Apply the norm's triangle inequality (axiom (c)) from [tc_1] with `u = x-z` and `v = z-y`. This gives `N(x-z) + N(z-y)`. Apply [def_1] to each term to get `ρ(x,z) + ρ(z,y)`.

proof_graph.natural_language: is a metric on $A.$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $x, y \in A$, $\rho(x,y) \ge 0$, and $\rho(x,y) = 0 \iff x=y$ [l1].
• For any $x, y \in A$, $\rho(y,x) = \rho(x,y)$ [l2].
• For any $x, y, z \in A$, $\rho(x,y) \le \rho(x,z) + \rho(z,y)$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The function $\rho$ is a metric on $A$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: To prove that `ρ` is a metric, we must show it satisfies the three metric space axioms. These are exactly the facts established in [l1] (positive definiteness), [l2] (symmetry), and [l3] (triangle inequality).

nl_proof:
Let $u_1$, $u_2$, \dots, $u_n$  be
nonnegative and $M=\max\set{u_i}{1\le i\le n}$. Define
$$
\sigma(p)=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}.
$$
Since $u_i/\sigma(p)\le1$ and $p_2>p_1$,
$$
\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_1}\ge
\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_2};
$$
 therefore,
$$
\frac{\sigma(p_1)}{\sigma(p_2)}
=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n\left(\frac{
u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_1}\right)^{1/p_1}
\ge\left(\sum_{i=1}^n\left(\frac{
u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_2}\right)^{1/p_1}=1,
$$
so $\sigma(p_1)\ge\sigma(p_2)$.
Since $M\le\sigma(p)\le Mn^{1/p}$,
$\lim_{p\to\infty}\sigma(p)= M$.
Letting  $u_i=|x_i|$  yields \eqref{eq:8.1.12} and \eqref{eq:8.1.13}.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{X}\in\R^n$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\mathbf{X}$ is a vector in $\R^n$ with components $x_i$ for $i=1, ..., n$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: and $p_2>p_1\ge1,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $p_1, p_2$ are real numbers such that $p_2 > p_1 \ge 1$ [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $u_1$, $u_2$, \dots, $u_n$  be nonnegative and $M=\max\set{u_i}{1\le i\le n}$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let $u_1, u_2, \dots, u_n$ be a sequence of $n$ nonnegative real numbers [def_1a].
• Let $M = \max\set{u_i}{1\le i\le n}$ [def_1b].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Define
$$
\sigma(p)=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• For $p \ge 1$ and for a sequence of non-negative numbers $u_1, ..., u_n$ [def_1a], define the function $\sigma(p) = \left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $u_i/\sigma(p_2)\le1$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $u_1, ..., u_n$ be nonnegative numbers [def_1a].
• For $p \ge 1$, $\sigma(p) = (\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p)^{1/p}$ [def_2].
• $p_2 \ge 1$ [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $i \in \{1, ..., n\}$, $u_i / \sigma(p_2) \le 1$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Show that for any i, $u_i^ {p_2} \le \sum_{j=1}^n u_j^{p_2} = \sigma(p_2)^{p_2}$. Then take the $p_2$-th root of both sides.

proof_graph.natural_language:
and $p_2>p_1$,
$$
\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_1}\ge
\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_2};
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p_2 > p_1 \ge 1$ [tc_2].
• For each $i$, $u_i / \sigma(p_2) \le 1$ [l1].
• The numbers $u_i$ are non-negative [def_1a].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $i$, $\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_1} \ge \left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_2}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the property that for $x \in [0, 1]$ and $b > a \ge 1$, $x^a \ge x^b$. Let $x = u_i / \sigma(p_2)$, $a = p_1$, and $b = p_2$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p_2 > p_1 \ge 1$ [tc_2].
• For all $i$, $\left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_1} \ge \left(\frac{u_i}{\sigma(p_2)}\right)^{p_2}$ [l2].
• $\sigma(p) = (\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p)^{1/p}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\sigma(p_1) \ge \sigma(p_2)$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Start from $\sigma(p_1)/\sigma(p_2)$, rewrite using [def_2]. Apply the term-wise inequality from [l2] to the sum. Show that the new sum simplifies to 1 using the definition of $\sigma(p_2)$ [def_2]. Conclude $\sigma(p_1)/\sigma(p_2) \ge 1$ and thus $\sigma(p_1) \ge \sigma(p_2)$ since $\sigma(p_2) > 0$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $M\le\sigma(p)\le Mn^{1/p}$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $u_1, ..., u_n$ are nonnegative numbers and $M = \max\{u_i\}$ [def_1].
• $\sigma(p) = (\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p)^{1/p}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $p \ge 1$, $M \le \sigma(p) \le M n^{1/p}$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Prove both inequalities. For $M \le \sigma(p)$, use $M^p = (\max u_i)^p \le \sum u_i^p$. For $\sigma(p) \le Mn^{1/p}$, use $u_i \le M$ for all $i$, so $\sum u_i^p \le \sum M^p = n M^p$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
$
\lim_{p\to\infty}\sigma(p)= M$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any $p \ge 1$, $M \le \sigma(p) \le M n^{1/p}$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{p\to\infty} \sigma(p) = M$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the Squeeze Theorem to the inequality in [l4]. Use the fact that $\lim_{p\to\infty} M = M$ and $\lim_{p\to\infty} M n^{1/p} = M \cdot 1 = M$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Letting  $u_i=|x_i|$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Given a vector $\mathbf{X}\in\R^n$ with components $x_i$ [tc_1], let $u_i = |x_i|$ for $i=1, ..., n$. This satisfies the non-negativity condition for $u_i$ [def_1a].
• With this substitution, $\sigma(p)$ as defined in [def_2] becomes the p-norm $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p} = (\sum_{i=1}^n |x_i|^p)^{1/p}$.
• And $M$ as defined in [def_1b] becomes $\max\set{|x_i|}{1\le i\le n}$ [def_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: Letting  $u_i=|x_i|$  yields \eqref{eq:8.1.12}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For non-negative $u_i$ and $p_2 > p_1 \ge 1$, $\sigma(p_1) \ge \sigma(p_2)$ [l3].
• Letting $u_i = |x_i|$ maps $\sigma(p)$ to $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p}$ [def_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p_2} \le \|\mathbf{X}\|_{p_1}$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $\sigma(p)$ with $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p}$ in the inequality $\sigma(p_1) \ge \sigma(p_2)$ from [l3] using the mapping from [def_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: and \eqref{eq:8.1.13}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For non-negative $u_i$, $\lim_{p\to\infty} \sigma(p) = M$ [l5], where $M = \max\{u_i\}$.
• Letting $u_i = |x_i|$ maps $\sigma(p)$ to $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p}$ and $M$ to $\max\set{|x_i|}{1\le i\le n}$ [def_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{p\to\infty}\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p}=\max\set{|x_i|}{1\le i\le n}$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $\sigma(p)$ with $\|\mathbf{X}\|_{p}$ and $M$ with $\max\{|x_i|\}$ in the limit equation from [l5] using the mapping from [def_3].

nl_theorem:
If a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in a metric space $(A,\rho)$ is convergent$,$
then it is a Cauchy sequence.
nl_proof:
Suppose that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=u$. If $\epsilon>0$, there is an integer
$N$ such that
$\rho(u_n,u)<\epsilon/2$ if $n>N$. Therefore, if $m$, $n>N$, then
$$
\rho(u_n,u_m)\le\rho(u_n,u)+\rho(u,u_m)<\epsilon.
$$
\vskip-2em

proof_graph.natural_language: If a sequence ${u_n}$ in a metric space $(A,\rho)$ is convergent
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $\{u_n\}$ be a sequence of points in a metric space $(A, \rho)$ which is convergent [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=u$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\{u_n\}$ is a convergent sequence in a metric space $(A, \rho)$ [tc_1].
Definition:
• Let $u \in A$ be the limit of the sequence $\{u_n\}$, such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=u$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\epsilon>0$, there is an integer N such that $\rho(u_n,u)<\epsilon/2$ if $n>N$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The sequence $\{u_n\}$ converges to a limit $u$ in the metric space $(A, \rho)$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• By the definition of a limit, for any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for any integer $k > N$, we have $\rho(u_k, u) < \epsilon/2$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of convergence (`tendsto_def`) with `ε' := ε/2`. This is valid since `ε > 0` implies `ε/2 > 0`.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\rho(u_n,u_m)\le\rho(u_n,u)+\rho(u,u_m)$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\{u_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a sequence of points and $u$ is a point in a metric space $(A, \rho)$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $n, m \in \mathbb{N}$, the triangle inequality holds: $\rho(u_n, u_m) \le \rho(u_n, u) + \rho(u, u_m)$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the triangle inequality property of the metric `ρ`. It can be accessed via a library lemma like `dist_triangle`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Therefore, if $m$, $n>N$, then
$$
\rho(u_n,u_m)\le\rho(u_n,u)+\rho(u,u_m)<\epsilon.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\{u_n\}$ is a sequence in a metric space $(A, \rho)$ with limit $u \in A$ [def_1].
• For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for any integer $k > N$, we have $\rho(u_k, u) < \epsilon/2$ [l1].
• For any $n, m \in \mathbb{N}$, $\rho(u_n, u_m) \le \rho(u_n, u) + \rho(u, u_m)$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The sequence $\{u_n\}$ is a Cauchy sequence. That is, for any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $m, n > N$, we have $\rho(u_n, u_m) < \epsilon$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let $\epsilon > 0$. Use `l1` to obtain the corresponding `N`. Take any `m, n > N`. Use `l2` to state $\rho(u_n, u_m) \le \rho(u_n, u) + \rho(u, u_m)$. By symmetry of the metric (from `def_1`), this is $\le \rho(u_n, u) + \rho(u_m, u)$. Apply `l1` for `n` and `m` to get $\rho(u_n, u) < \epsilon/2$ and $\rho(u_m, u) < \epsilon/2$. Combine these inequalities: $\rho(u_n, u_m) < \epsilon/2 + \epsilon/2 = \epsilon$. Use `linarith` or a `calc` block.

nl_theorem:
If $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are equivalent  metrics on a set $A,$ then
 $(A,\rho)$ and $(A,\sigma)$ have the same open sets.
nl_proof:
Suppose that \eqref{eq:8.1.18} holds. Let $S$ be an open set in
$(A,\rho)$ and let $x_0\in S$. Then there is an $\epsilon>0$ such
that $x\in S$ if $\rho(x,x_0)<\epsilon$, so the second
inequality in \eqref{eq:8.1.18}
implies  that $x_0\in S$ if $\sigma(x,x_0)\le\epsilon/\beta$.
Therefore, $S$ is open in $(A,\sigma)$.
Conversely, suppose that $S$ is open in $(A,\sigma)$
and let $x_0\in S$. Then there is an $\epsilon>0$ such
that $x\in S$ if $\sigma(x,x_0)<\epsilon$, so the first
inequality in \eqref{eq:8.1.18}
implies  that $x_0\in S$ if $\rho(x,x_0)\le\epsilon\alpha$.
Therefore, $S$ is open in $(A,\rho)$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are ... metrics on a set $A,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• A is a set, and $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are metrics on A [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that \eqref{eq:8.1.18} holds.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• A is a set, and $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are metrics on A [tc_1].
• $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are equivalent, meaning there exist positive constants $\alpha, \beta$ such that for all $x,y \in A$, $\alpha\sigma(x,y) \le \rho(x,y) \le \beta\sigma(x,y)$ [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $S$ be an open set in $(A,\rho)$ and let $x_0\in S$. Then there is an $\epsilon>0$ such that $x\in S$ if $\rho(x,x_0)<\epsilon$, so the second inequality in \eqref{eq:8.1.18} implies that $x_0\in S$ if $\sigma(x,x_0)\le\epsilon/\beta$. Therefore, $S$ is open in $(A,\sigma)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The metrics $\rho$ and $\sigma$ on set A are equivalent [tc_2].
• S is an open set in the metric space $(A, \rho)$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• S is an open set in the metric space $(A, \sigma)$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Assume S is open in (A, ρ). To show it is open in (A, σ), take an arbitrary `x₀ ∈ S`. By ρ-openness, there exists `ε > 0` such that the ball `B_ρ(x₀, ε) ⊆ S`. Use the equivalence inequality `ρ(x,y) ≤ β·σ(x,y)` from [tc_2] to show that `B_σ(x₀, ε/β) ⊆ B_ρ(x₀, ε)`. It follows that `B_σ(x₀, ε/β) ⊆ S`. Since `x₀` was arbitrary, S is σ-open.

proof_graph.natural_language: Conversely, suppose that $S$ is open in $(A,\sigma)$ and let $x_0\in S$. Then there is an $\epsilon>0$ such that $x\in S$ if $\sigma(x,x_0)<\epsilon$, so the first inequality in \eqref{eq:8.1.18} implies that $x_0\in S$ if $\rho(x,x_0)\le\epsilon\alpha$. Therefore, $S$ is open in $(A,\rho)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The metrics $\rho$ and $\sigma$ on set A are equivalent [tc_2].
• S is an open set in the metric space $(A, \sigma)$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• S is an open set in the metric space $(A, \rho)$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Assume S is open in (A, σ). To show it is open in (A, ρ), take an arbitrary `x₀ ∈ S`. By σ-openness, there exists `ε > 0` such that `B_σ(x₀, ε) ⊆ S`. Use the equivalence inequality `α·σ(x,y) ≤ ρ(x,y)` from [tc_2] to show that `B_ρ(x₀, α·ε) ⊆ B_σ(x₀, ε)`. It follows that `B_ρ(x₀, α·ε) ⊆ S`. Since `x₀` was arbitrary, S is ρ-open.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are equivalent metrics on a set $A,$ then $(A,\rho)$ and $(A,\sigma)$ have the same open sets.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any set S, if S is open in $(A, \rho)$, then S is open in $(A, \sigma)$ [l1].
• For any set S, if S is open in $(A, \sigma)$, then S is open in $(A, \rho)$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The collection of open sets of $(A, \rho)$ is equal to the collection of open sets of $(A, \sigma)$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The goal is to prove equality between two sets of sets (the topologies). Use the `ext` tactic, which reduces the goal to showing that for any set S, S is in the first collection if and only if it's in the second. This `iff` statement is proven by using the implications from [l1] and [l2].

nl_theorem:
A subset $T$ of a metric $A$ is compact if and only if
every infinite sequence $\{t_n\}$ of members of  $T$  has a
subsequence that converges to a member of $T.$
nl_proof:
Suppose that  $T$ is compact and $\{t_n\}\subset T$. If $\{t_n\}$
has only finitely many distinct terms, there is a $\overline t$
in $T$ such that $t_n=\overline t$ for infinitely many values of $n$;
if this is so for $n_1<n_2<\cdots$, then
$\lim_{j\to\infty}t_{n_j}=\overline t$. If $\{t_n\}$ has infinitely
many distinct terms, then $\{t_n\}$ has a limit point $\overline t$ in
$T$, so there are integers $n_1<n_2<\cdots$  such that
$\rho(t_{n_j},\overline t)<1/j$; therefore,
$\lim_{j\to\infty}t_{n_j}=\overline t$.
Conversely, suppose that  every sequence in $T$ has a
subsequence that converges to a limit in $T$.
If $S$ is an infinite subset of $T$, we can choose a sequence
$\{t_n\}$ of distinct points in $S$.  By assumption,
$\{t_n\}$ has a subsequence that converges to a member  $\overline t$
of $T$. Since $\overline t$ is a limit point of $\{t_n\}$, and
therefore of $T$, $T$ is compact.

proof_graph.natural_language: A subset $T$ of a metric $A$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $(A, \rho)$ be a metric space, and $T$ be a subset of $A$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: (The proof implicitly uses the Bolzano-Weierstrass property as the definition of compactness for a metric space.)
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• A set $K$ in a metric space is compact if and only if every infinite subset of $K$ has a limit point in $K$. This is the Bolzano-Weierstrass property [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that  $T$ is compact
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $(A, \rho)$ be a metric space, and $T$ be a subset of $A$ [tc_1].
• $T$ is compact [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: If {t_n} has only finitely many distinct terms, there is a $\overline t$ in $T$ such that $t_n=\overline t$ for infinitely many values of $n$;
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $\{t_n\}$ be an infinite sequence of members of $T \subseteq A$ [tc_1].
• The set of values $\{t_n \mid n \in \mathbb{N}\}$ is finite.
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a point $\overline{t} \in T$ and a strictly increasing sequence of natural numbers $(n_j)_{j \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that $t_{n_j} = \overline{t}$ for all $j$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows from the pigeonhole principle for an infinite sequence with a finite number of values.

proof_graph.natural_language: if this is so for $n_1<n_2<\cdots$, then $\lim_{j\to\infty}t_{n_j}=\overline t$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a point $\overline{t} \in T$ and a strictly increasing sequence of natural numbers $(n_j)_{j \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that $t_{n_j} = \overline{t}$ for all $j$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The subsequence $\{t_{n_j}\}$ converges to $\overline{t}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The limit of a constant sequence is the constant value itself. Use the definition of convergence.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\{t_n\}$ has infinitely many distinct terms, then $\{t_n\}$ has a limit point $\overline t$ in $T$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $T$ is a compact subset of a metric space $A$ [tc_2].
• A set is compact iff every infinite subset has a limit point in the set [def_1].
• $\{t_n\}$ is an infinite sequence in $T$ with infinitely many distinct terms.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The set of values $V = \{t_n \mid n \in \mathbb{N}\}$ is an infinite subset of $T$ and thus has a limit point $\overline{t} \in T$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The set of values of the sequence is an infinite subset of a compact set T. By the Bolzano-Weierstrass property (def_1), it must have a limit point in T.

proof_graph.natural_language: so there are integers $n_1<n_2<\cdots$  such that $\rho(t_{n_j},\overline t)<1/j$;
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The set of values of a sequence $\{t_n\}$ has a limit point $\overline{t} \in T$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a subsequence $\{t_{n_j}\}$ (with $n_1 < n_2 < \dots$) such that for every natural number $j \ge 1$, the distance $\rho(t_{n_j}, \overline{t}) < 1/j$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a direct application of the definition of a limit point. We can construct such a subsequence inductively.

proof_graph.natural_language: therefore, $\lim_{j\to\infty}t_{n_j}=\overline t$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a subsequence $\{t_{n_j}\}$ and a point $\overline{t}$ such that for every natural number $j \ge 1$, $\rho(t_{n_j}, \overline{t}) < 1/j$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The subsequence $\{t_{n_j}\}$ converges to $\overline{t}$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the definition of convergence. For any $\epsilon > 0$, choose $J$ such that $1/J < \epsilon$. Then for all $j > J$, $\rho(t_{n_j}, \overline{t}) < 1/j < 1/J < \epsilon$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that  $T$ is compact and $\{t_n\}\subset T$. If $\{t_n\}$ has only finitely many distinct terms, ... If $\{t_n\}$ has infinitely many distinct terms, ...
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $T$ is a compact subset of a metric space $A$ [tc_2].
• For any infinite sequence in $T$ with finitely many distinct terms, there exists a convergent subsequence [l2].
• For any infinite sequence in $T$ with infinitely many distinct terms, there exists a convergent subsequence [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• Every infinite sequence $\{t_n\}$ of members of $T$ has a subsequence that converges to a member of $T$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This combines the two cases. An infinite sequence must have either finitely or infinitely many distinct terms. In both cases, a convergent subsequence exists.

proof_graph.natural_language: suppose that  every sequence in $T$ has a subsequence that converges to a limit in $T$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $(A, \rho)$ be a metric space, and $T$ be a subset of $A$ [tc_1].
• Every sequence in $T$ has a subsequence that converges to a limit in $T$ [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: If $S$ is an infinite subset of $T$, we can choose a sequence $\{t_n\}$ of distinct points in $S$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $S$ is an infinite subset of $T$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• We can construct a sequence $\{t_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that all $t_n$ are in $S$ and $t_n \neq t_m$ for $n \neq m$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows from the axiom of countable choice on an infinite set.

proof_graph.natural_language: By assumption, $\{t_n\}$ has a subsequence that converges to a member  $\overline t$ of $T$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Every sequence in $T$ has a subsequence that converges to a limit in $T$ [tc_3].
• $\{t_n\}$ is a sequence of distinct points in $S \subseteq T$ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a subsequence $\{t_{n_j}\}$ of $\{t_n\}$ and a point $\overline{t} \in T$ such that $\{t_{n_j}\}$ converges to $\overline{t}$ [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the hypothesis (tc_3) to the sequence constructed in l6.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $\overline t$ is a limit point of $\{t_n\}$, and therefore of $T$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\{t_{n_j}\}$ is a subsequence of a sequence of distinct points $\{t_n\}$ from a set $S$ [l6].
• $\{t_{n_j}\}$ converges to a point $\overline{t} \in T$ [l7].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\overline{t}$ is a limit point of the set $S$ [l8].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The limit of a sequence of distinct points from a set S is a limit point of S. For any neighborhood of t_bar, it contains infinitely many points of the subsequence, which are also points of S.

proof_graph.natural_language: $T$ is compact.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Every sequence in $T$ has a subsequence that converges to a limit in $T$ [tc_3].
• A set is compact if every infinite subset has a limit point in the set [def_1].
• For any infinite subset $S \subseteq T$, $S$ has a limit point $\overline{t} \in T$ [l8].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $T$ is compact [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: We have shown that any arbitrary infinite subset S of T has a limit point in T (l8). By the Bolzano-Weierstrass property (def_1), this implies T is compact.

nl_proof:
Suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is true, and let $\{u_n\}$  be a sequence in
$D_f$ that satisfies \eqref{eq:8.3.5}. Let $\epsilon>0$ and choose
$\delta>0$  to satisfy \eqref{eq:8.3.1}. From \eqref{eq:8.3.5}, there is
an integer $N$  such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<\delta$ if $n\ge N$.
Therefore, $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)<\epsilon$ if $n\ge N$, which implies
\eqref{eq:8.3.4}.
For the converse, suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is false.
Then there is an $\epsilon_0>0$  and a sequence $\{u_n\}$
in $D_f$ such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<1/n$ and $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat
v)\ge\epsilon_0$, so \eqref{eq:8.3.4} is false.
\mbox{}\hfill

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $\widehat u\in\overline D_f.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $(U, \rho)$ and $(V, \sigma)$ be metric spaces. Let $f: D_f \to V$ be a function where $D_f \subseteq U$. Let $\widehat u \in \overline D_f$ and $\widehat v \in V$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is true
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption (for forward implication):
• $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: and let $\{u_n\}$  be a sequence in $D_f$ that satisfies \eqref{eq:8.3.5}.
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption (for forward implication):
• Let $\{u_n\}$ be a sequence in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $\epsilon>0$ and choose $\delta>0$  to satisfy \eqref{eq:8.3.1}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $u \in D_f$, if $\rho(u, \widehat{u}) < \delta$, then $\sigma(f(u), \widehat{v}) < \epsilon$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the metric space definition of `tendsto` (limit of a function).

proof_graph.natural_language: From \eqref{eq:8.3.5}, there is an integer $N$  such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<\delta$ if $n\ge N$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$ [def_2].
• A real number $\delta > 0$ is given.
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n \ge N$, we have $\rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < \delta$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the metric space definition of `tendsto` (limit of a sequence).

proof_graph.natural_language: Therefore, $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)<\epsilon$ if $n\ge N$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For a given $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $u \in D_f$, if $\rho(u, \widehat{u}) < \delta$, then $\sigma(f(u), \widehat{v}) < \epsilon$ [l1].
• For this $\delta$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n \ge N$, we have $\rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < \delta$ [l2].
• $\{u_n\}$ is a sequence in $D_f$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For the given $\epsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n \ge N$, we have $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) < \epsilon$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let $\epsilon > 0$. Use `l1` to get $\delta$. Use `l2` with this $\delta$ to get $N$. For $n \geq N$, $\rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < \delta$. Since $u_n \in D_f$, `l1` applies, yielding $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) < \epsilon$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is true, and let $\{u_n\}$  be a sequence in
$D_f$ that satisfies \eqref{eq:8.3.5}. Let $\epsilon>0$ and choose
$\delta>0$  to satisfy \eqref{eq:8.3.1}. From \eqref{eq:8.3.5}, there is
an integer $N$  such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<\delta$ if $n\ge N$.
Therefore, $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)<\epsilon$ if $n\ge N$, which implies
\eqref{eq:8.3.4}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• We start with the assumption $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ [def_1].
• We take an arbitrary sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$ [def_2].
• We have shown that for any $\epsilon > 0$, an integer $N$ exists such that for $n \ge N$, $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) < \epsilon$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• If $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$, then for every sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$, we have $\lim_{n\to\infty}f(u_n)=\widehat v$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The result [l3] is the definition of $\lim_{n\to\infty}f(u_n)=\widehat v$. Since this holds for an arbitrary sequence [def_2] given the initial assumption [def_1], the implication is proven.

proof_graph.natural_language: For the converse, suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is false.
proof_graph.statement:
Assumption (for contraposition):
• $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ is false [def_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: Then there is an $\epsilon_0>0$...
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ is false [def_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an $\epsilon_0 > 0$ such that for all $\delta > 0$, there exists a $u \in D_f$ such that $\rho(u, \widehat{u}) < \delta$ and $\sigma(f(u), \widehat{v}) \ge \epsilon_0$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Unfold the negation of the definition of the limit of a function.

proof_graph.natural_language: ...and a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<1/n$ and $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)\ge\epsilon_0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists an $\epsilon_0 > 0$ such that for all $\delta > 0$, there exists a $u \in D_f$ s.t. $\rho(u, \widehat{u}) < \delta$ and $\sigma(f(u), \widehat{v}) \ge \epsilon_0$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ and an $\epsilon_0 > 0$ such that for all integers $n \ge 1$, we have $\rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < 1/n$ and $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) \ge \epsilon_0$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For each integer $n \ge 1$, set $\delta = 1/n$. The assumption [l4] guarantees the existence of an element $u_n \in D_f$ with the required properties. The axiom of choice allows the construction of the sequence $\{u_n\}$.

proof_graph.natural_language: (implied by $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<1/n$)
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• A sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ exists such that for all $n \ge 1$, $\rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < 1/n$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{n\to\infty} u_n = \widehat u$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the squeeze theorem: $0 \le \rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) < 1/n$. Since $\lim_{n\to\infty} 1/n = 0$, it follows that $\lim_{n\to\infty} \rho(u_n, \widehat{u}) = 0$, which is the definition of convergence.

proof_graph.natural_language: ...and $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)\ge\epsilon_0$, so \eqref{eq:8.3.4} is false.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a sequence $\{f(u_n)\}$ and an $\epsilon_0 > 0$ such that for all $n \ge 1$, $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) \ge \epsilon_0$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The statement '$\lim_{n\to\infty} f(u_n) = \widehat v$' is false [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the negation of sequence convergence. For $\epsilon = \epsilon_0$, for any $N$, we can find $n > N$ such that $\sigma(f(u_n), \widehat{v}) \ge \epsilon_0$ is true (in fact, it's true for all $n$).

proof_graph.natural_language: ...a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<1/n$ and $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat v)\ge\epsilon_0$, so \eqref{eq:8.3.4} is false.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ [l5].
• For this sequence, $\lim_{n\to\infty} u_n = \widehat u$ [l6].
• For this sequence, '$\lim_{n\to\infty} f(u_n) = \widehat v$' is false [l7].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$ and $\lim_{n\to\infty}f(u_n) \neq \widehat v$ [l8].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine the established properties into an existence statement.

proof_graph.natural_language:
For the converse, suppose that \eqref{eq:8.3.3} is false.
Then there is an $\epsilon_0>0$  and a sequence $\{u_n\}$
in $D_f$ such that $\rho(u_n,\widehat u)<1/n$ and $\sigma(f(u_n),\widehat
v)\ge\epsilon_0$, so \eqref{eq:8.3.4} is false.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The assumption that '$\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$' is false [def_3] implies that there exists a sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$ but $\lim_{n\to\infty}f(u_n) \neq \widehat v$ [l8].
Therefore, we conclude:
• If for every sequence $\{u_n\}$ in $D_f$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}u_n=\widehat u$, we have $\lim_{n\to\infty}f(u_n)=\widehat v$, then $\lim_{u\to \widehat u}f(u)=\widehat v$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows by contraposition. The premise shows that $\neg(\text{function limit}) \implies \neg(\text{sequential criterion})$. This is logically equivalent to $(\text{sequential criterion}) \implies (\text{function limit})$.

nl_theorem:
If $f^{(n)}(x_0)$ exists$,$ then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:2.5.7}
f(x)=\sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r+E_n(x)(x-x_0)^n,
\end{equation}
where
$$
\lim_{x\to x_0} E_n(x)=E_n(x_0)=0.
$$
nl_proof:
Define
$$
E_n(x)=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{ll}
\dst\frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n},&x\in D_f-\{x_0\},\\
0,&x=x_0.\end{array}\right.
$$
Then  \eqref{eq:2.5.5} implies that $\lim_{x\to x_0}E_n(x)=E_n(x_0)=0$,
and it is straightforward to verify \eqref{eq:2.5.7}.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $f^{(n)}(x_0)$ exists
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $f$ be a real-valued function defined on a domain $D_f$, let $x_0$ be a point in $D_f$, and assume the n-th derivative of $f$ at $x_0$, denoted $f^{(n)}(x_0)$, exists [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Define
$$
E_n(x)=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{ll}
\dst\frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n},&x\in D_f-\{x_0\},\
