0,&x=x_0.\end{array}\right.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $f$ be a real-valued function defined on a domain $D_f$, let $x_0$ be a point in $D_f$, and assume the n-th derivative of $f$ at $x_0$ exists [tc_1].
Definition:
• Let $T_n(x)$ denote the n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ at $x_0$, defined as $T_n(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r$. 
• We define the function $E_n(x)$ for $x \in D_f$ as: $E_n(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} & \text{if } x \neq x_0 \\ 0 & \text{if } x = x_0 \end{cases}$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Then  \eqref{eq:2.5.5} implies that $\lim_{x\to x_0}E_n(x)=E_n(x_0)=0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The n-th derivative of $f$ at $x_0$, $f^{(n)}(x_0)$, exists [tc_1].
• $T_n(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r$ is the n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ at $x_0$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• (Implicit premise from (2.5.5)) The limit of the scaled difference between the function and its Taylor polynomial is zero: $\lim_{x\to x_0} \frac{f(x) - T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} = 0$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is Taylor's theorem with the Peano remainder, which is a direct consequence of the definition of the n-th derivative.

proof_graph.natural_language: Then  \eqref{eq:2.5.5} implies that $\lim_{x\to x_0}E_n(x)=E_n(x_0)=0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $E_n(x)$ is defined as $E_n(x) = \frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n}$ for $x \neq x_0$ and $E_n(x_0)=0$ [def_1].
• $\lim_{x\to x_0} \frac{f(x) - T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} = 0$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The limit of $E_n(x)$ as $x$ approaches $x_0$ is equal to its value at $x_0$, and both are zero: $\lim_{x\to x_0} E_n(x) = E_n(x_0) = 0$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [def_1], for $x \neq x_0$, $E_n(x)$ equals the expression in [l1]. Therefore, the limit of $E_n(x)$ is 0. Also from [def_1], $E_n(x_0)$ is 0. The conclusion follows.

proof_graph.natural_language: and it is straightforward to verify \eqref{eq:2.5.7}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $T_n(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r$ and $E_n(x)$ is defined piece-wise as $E_n(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{f(x)-T_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^n} & \text{if } x \neq x_0 \\ 0 & \text{if } x = x_0 \end{cases}$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For all $x \in D_f$, $f(x) = \sum_{r=0}^n\frac{f^{(r)}(x_0)}{ r!} (x-x_0)^r+E_n(x)(x-x_0)^n$ [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Verify the equality by cases. Case 1: $x \neq x_0$. The equation follows from algebraic rearrangement of the definition of $E_n(x)$ in [def_1]. Case 2: $x = x_0$. The equation becomes $f(x_0) = T_n(x_0) + E_n(x_0) \cdot 0^n$. This holds because $T_n(x_0) = f(x_0)$ and $E_n(x_0) = 0$ by definition.

nl_proof:
If $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$,  then both sides
of \eqref{eq:5.1.3} are $\mathbf{0}$, so \eqref{eq:5.1.3} holds, with equality.
In this case,  $\mathbf{Y}=0\mathbf{X}$.
Now suppose that   $\mathbf{Y}\ne\mathbf{0}$ and
 $t$ is any real number. Then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.1.4}
\begin{array}{rcl}
0\ar\le \dst{\sum^n_{i=1} (x_i-ty_i)^2}\\
\ar=\dst{\sum^n_{i=1} x^2_i-2t\sum^n_{i=1} x_iy_i+t^2\sum^n_{i=1}
y^2_i}\\\\
\ar=|\mathbf{X}|^2-2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})t+t^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2.
\end{array}
\end{equation}
The last expression is a second-degree polynomial $p$
in $t$. From the quadratic formula, the zeros of $p$ are
$$
t=\frac{(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})\pm\sqrt{(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2-
|\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2}}{ |\mathbf{Y}|^2}.
$$
Hence,
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.1.5}
(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2\le |\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2,
\end{equation}
because if not, then  $p$ would have two distinct real zeros  and
therefore
be negative between them (Figure~\ref{figure:5.1.1}), contradicting the
inequality \eqref{eq:5.1.4}. Taking square roots in \eqref{eq:5.1.5} yields
\eqref{eq:5.1.3} if $\mathbf{Y}\ne\mathbf{0}$.
If $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$, then
$|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}|=|\mathbf{X}||\mathbf{Y}|
=|t||\mathbf{Y}|^2$ (verify), so equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.3}.
Conversely, if equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.3}, then $p$ has the real
zero $t_0=(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})/|\mathbf{Y}\|^2$, and
$$
\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-t_0y_i)^2=0
$$
\nopagebreak
from \eqref{eq:5.1.4}; therefore, $\mathbf{X}=t_0\mathbf{Y}$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are any two vectors in $\R^n,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$,  then both sides of \eqref{eq:5.1.3} are $\mathbf{0}$, so \eqref{eq:5.1.3} holds, with equality.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute Y=0 into both sides of the equation. Use lemmas `dot_product_zero` and `norm_zero` and simplify.

proof_graph.natural_language: In this case,  $\mathbf{Y}=0\mathbf{X}$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].
• $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\mathbf{Y} = 0\mathbf{X}$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The zero vector is equal to the scalar 0 multiplied by any vector. `simp`.

proof_graph.natural_language: The last expression is a second-degree polynomial $p$ in $t$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• For vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ and a scalar $t \in \mathbb{R}$, we define the polynomial $p(t) = |\mathbf{X}|^2-2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})t+t^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: $0\le \dst{\sum^n_{i=1} (x_i-ty_i)^2} \ar=\dst{\sum^n_{i=1} x^2_i-2t\sum^n_{i=1} x_iy_i+t^2\sum^n_{i=1} y^2_i} \ar=|\mathbf{X}|^2-2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})t+t^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2.$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ and a scalar $t \in \mathbb{R}$, we have the polynomial $p(t) = |\mathbf{X}|^2-2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})t+t^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any real number $t$, $p(t) = \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - ty_i)^2$, and thus $p(t) \ge 0$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Expand the sum $\sum(x_i - ty_i)^2$ and use the definitions of dot product and squared norm to show it equals $p(t)$. The inequality $p(t) \ge 0$ follows from it being a sum of squares.

proof_graph.natural_language: because if not, then  $p$ would have two distinct real zeros  and therefore be negative between them (Figure~\ref{figure:5.1.1}), contradicting the inequality \eqref{eq:5.1.4}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p(t)$ is a quadratic polynomial in $t$ of the form $At^2+Bt+C$ with real coefficients [def_1].
• For all $t \in \mathbb{R}$, $p(t) \ge 0$ [l3].
• The leading coefficient $A = |\mathbf{Y}|^2$ is positive (assuming $\mathbf{Y} \neq \mathbf{0}$).
Therefore, we conclude:
• The discriminant of $p(t)$, $\Delta = B^2 - 4AC$, must be less than or equal to 0 [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: A quadratic polynomial that is always non-negative and opens upwards (positive leading coefficient) cannot have two distinct real roots, so its discriminant must be non-positive. Use a standard library lemma about quadratic inequalities.

proof_graph.natural_language: Hence, $(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2\le |\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2,$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $p(t) = |\mathbf{Y}|^2t^2 - 2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})t + |\mathbf{X}|^2$ [def_1].
• The discriminant of $p(t)$ is $\le 0$ (for $\mathbf{Y} \neq \mathbf{0}$) [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2 \le |\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Identify coefficients $A=|\mathbf{Y}|^2, B=-2(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}), C=|\mathbf{X}|^2$. Substitute them into the discriminant inequality $B^2 - 4AC \le 0$ and simplify.

proof_graph.natural_language: Taking square roots in \eqref{eq:5.1.5} yields \eqref{eq:5.1.3} if $\mathbf{Y}\ne\mathbf{0}$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2 \le |\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| \le |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Take the square root of both sides of the inequality. Use `sqrt_le_sqrt` after showing both sides are non-negative.

proof_graph.natural_language: The entire first part of the proof establishes the inequality.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• If $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$, then $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [l1].
• If $\mathbf{Y}\neq\mathbf{0}$, then $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| \le |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any two vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in \mathbb{R}^n$, we have $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| \le |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Proof by cases on $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$. If $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$, use `l1` (equality implies inequality). If $\mathbf{Y}\neq\mathbf{0}$, use `l6`.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$, then $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}|= |\mathbf{X}| |\mathbf{Y}| = |t| |\mathbf{Y}|^2$ (verify), so equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.3}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].
• There exists a scalar $t$ such that $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$ into both sides. For the left side, use `dot_product_smul` to get $|t(\mathbf{Y}\cdot\mathbf{Y})| = |t||\mathbf{Y}|^2$. For the right side, use `norm_smul` to get $|t| |\mathbf{Y}| |\mathbf{Y}| = |t||\mathbf{Y}|^2$. Both sides are equal.

proof_graph.natural_language: Conversely, if equality holds in \eqref{eq:5.1.3}, then $p$ has the real zero $t_0=(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})/|\mathbf{Y}\|^2$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The setup for the polynomial $p(t)$ with $\mathbf{Y} \neq \mathbf{0}$ [def_1, l3, l4, l5].
• Equality holds: $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The discriminant of $p(t)$ is 0, and it has exactly one real root $t_0 = (\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})/|\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [l8].
proof_graph.lean_hint: If $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$, then $(\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y})^2 = |\mathbf{X}|^2|\mathbf{Y}|^2$. From the definition of the discriminant in the proof of `l5`, this implies the discriminant is 0. Use the quadratic formula for a single root, $t_0 = -B/(2A)$, to find the value of the root.

proof_graph.natural_language: and $\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-t_0y_i)^2=0$ from \eqref{eq:5.1.4};
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any real number $t$, $p(t) = \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - ty_i)^2$ [l3].
• $t_0$ is a root of $p(t)$, meaning $p(t_0)=0$ [l8].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-t_0y_i)^2=0$ [l9].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute $t=t_0$ into the identity from `l3` and use the fact that $p(t_0)=0$ from `l8`.

proof_graph.natural_language: therefore, $\mathbf{X}=t_0\mathbf{Y}$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-t_0y_i)^2=0$ [l9].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\mathbf{X}=t_0\mathbf{Y}$ [l10].
proof_graph.lean_hint: A sum of squares of real numbers is zero if and only if each term is zero. Therefore, $x_i - t_0y_i = 0$ for all $i$. This is the definition of vector scalar multiplication $\mathbf{X}=t_0\mathbf{Y}$.

proof_graph.natural_language: with equality if and only if one of the vectors is a scalar multiple of the other.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• If $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$, then $\mathbf{Y}=0\mathbf{X}$ and equality holds [l1, l2].
• If one vector is a scalar multiple of the other (e.g. $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$), then equality holds [l7].
• If equality holds and $\mathbf{Y} \neq \mathbf{0}$, then $\mathbf{X}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{Y}$ [l10].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}\cdot\mathbf{Y}| = |\mathbf{X}|\,|\mathbf{Y}|$ if and only if one of $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}$ is a scalar multiple of the other [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Prove both directions of the 'iff'. The 'if' direction: assume one is a multiple of the other. If $\mathbf{Y}=t'\mathbf{X}$ or $\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{Y}$. Use `l7` for the main case and `l1` for the zero vector case. The 'only if' direction: assume equality. Use cases on $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{0}$ (using `l2`) or $\mathbf{Y}\neq\mathbf{0}$ (using `l10`).

nl_theorem:
If $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ are in $S_r(\mathbf{X}_0)$ for some $r>0$,
then so is every point on
the line segment from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2.$
nl_proof:
The line segment is given by
$$
\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1,\quad 0<t<1.
$$
Suppose that $r>0$. If
$$
|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,\quad |\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,
$$
and $0<t<1$, then
\begin{eqnarray*}
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|\ar=|t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-t\mathbf{X}_0-(1-t)\mathbf{X}_0|\\
\ar=|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|\\
\ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|\\
\ar< tr+(1-t)r=r.
\end{eqnarray*}
\vskip-2em

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ are in $S_r(\mathbf{X}_0)$...
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let V be a real normed vector space, and let $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ be points in V [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $r>0$.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let r be a real number such that r > 0 [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
If
$$
|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,\quad |\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let V be a real normed vector space, and let $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ be points in V [tc_1].
• Let r be a real number such that r > 0 [tc_2].
• The points $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ satisfy $|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ and $|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
The line segment is given by
$$
\mathbf{X}=t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1,\quad 0<t<1.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let t be a real number such that $0 < t < 1$. We define a point $\mathbf{X}$ on the line segment between $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ as $\mathbf{X} = t\mathbf{X}_2 + (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1$ [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: $$|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|\ar=|t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-t\mathbf{X}_0-(1-t)\mathbf{X}_0|\\ \ar=|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let V be a real normed vector space, and let $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ be points in V [tc_1].
• Let t be a real number such that $0 < t < 1$. We define a point $\mathbf{X}$ on the line segment between $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ as $\mathbf{X} = t\mathbf{X}_2 + (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0| = |t(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_0) + (1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1 - \mathbf{X}_0)|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definition of X from [def_1] into $|X - X_0|$. Then, use the identity $\mathbf{X}_0 = 1 \cdot \mathbf{X}_0 = (t + (1-t))\mathbf{X}_0 = t\mathbf{X}_0 + (1-t)\mathbf{X}_0$. Rewrite the expression inside the norm and regroup terms.

proof_graph.natural_language: $$\ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let V be a real normed vector space, and let $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ be points in V [tc_1].
• For any real number t such that $0 < t < 1$, we define a point $\mathbf{X}$ as $\mathbf{X} = t\mathbf{X}_2 + (1-t)\mathbf{X}_1$ [def_1].
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, the expression for $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0|$ is $|t(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_0) + (1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1 - \mathbf{X}_0)|$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $|t(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_0) + (1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1 - \mathbf{X}_0)| \le t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0| + (1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the triangle inequality (`norm_add_le`) to the right-hand side of the equality in [l1]. Then apply the homogeneity of the norm (`norm_smul`) and use the conditions $t>0$ and $1-t>0$ from [def_1] to simplify $|t|=t$ and $|1-t|=1-t$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let r be a real number such that r > 0 [tc_2].
• Let V be a real normed vector space, and let $\mathbf{X}_0, \mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$ be points in V [tc_1].
• The points $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ satisfy $|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ and $|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ [tc_3].
• For any real number t such that $0 < t < 1$ [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0| + (1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0| < tr + (1-t)r$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Start with the inequality $|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ from [tc_3]. Since $t>0$ (from [def_1]), multiply by $t$ to get $t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0| < tr$. Similarly, start with $|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|<r$ from [tc_3], and since $1-t>0$ (from [def_1]), multiply to get $(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0| < (1-t)r$. Add the two resulting inequalities.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let r be a real number [tc_2].
• Let t be a real number [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $tr + (1-t)r = r$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use `ring` or `field_simp` to prove the algebraic identity.

proof_graph.natural_language: $$|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|\ar=|t\mathbf{X}_2+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-t\mathbf{X}_0-(1-t)\mathbf{X}_0|\\ \ar=|t(\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0)+(1-t)\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0)|\\ \ar\le  t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0|+(1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|\\ \ar< tr+(1-t)r=r.$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0| = |t(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_0) + (1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1 - \mathbf{X}_0)|$ [l1].
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $|t(\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_0) + (1-t)(\mathbf{X}_1 - \mathbf{X}_0)| \le t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0| + (1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0|$ [l2].
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $t|\mathbf{X}_2-\mathbf{X}_0| + (1-t)|\mathbf{X}_1-\mathbf{X}_0| < tr + (1-t)r$ [l3].
• $tr + (1-t)r = r$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any t such that $0 < t < 1$, $|\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{X}_0| < r$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine the results from [l1], [l2], [l3], and [l4] using transitivity of equality and inequalities. A `calc` block in Lean would be appropriate to show: $|X - X_0| = ... \le ... < ... = r`.

nl_theorem:
Suppose that $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is continuously
differentiable on a neighborhood $N$ of $\mathbf{X}_0.$ Then$,$ for every
$\epsilon>0,$ there is a $\delta>0$ such that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.8}
|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})|<
(\|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_{0})\|
+\epsilon) |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|
\mbox{\quad if\quad}\mathbf{A},\mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta (\mathbf{X}_0).
\end{equation}

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

Let $f$ be continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1=(x_{11},x_{21}, \dots, x_{n1})$
and $\mathbf{X}_2=(x_{12},x_{22}, \dots,x_{n2})$ and differentiable on the
line segment $L$ from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2.$ Then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:5.4.21}
f(\mathbf{X}_2)-f(\mathbf{X}_1)=\sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i} (\mathbf{X}_0)(x_{i2}-x_{i1})=(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{X}_2
-\mathbf{X}_1)
\end{equation}
for some $\mathbf{X}_0$ on $L$ distinct
from $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$.
nl_proof:
Consider the auxiliary function
\begin{equation} \label{eq:6.2.9}
\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}.
\end{equation}
The components of $\mathbf{G}$ are
$$
g_i(\mathbf{X})=f_i(\mathbf{X})-\sum_{j=1}^n
\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_{0})
\partial x_j} x_j,
$$
so
$$
\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}=
\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X})}
{\partial x_j}-\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_0)}{\partial x_j}.
$$
\newpage
\noindent
Thus, $\partial g_i/\partial x_j$ is continuous on $N$ and zero at
$\mathbf{X}_0$. Therefore, there is a $\delta>0$ such that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.10}
\left|\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}\right|<\frac{\epsilon}{
\sqrt{mn}}\mbox{\quad for \quad}1\le i\le m,\quad 1\le j\le n,
\mbox{\quad if \quad}
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|<\delta.
\end{equation}
Now suppose that $\mathbf{X}$, $\mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$. By
Theorem~\ref{thmtype:5.4.5},
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.11}
g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y})=\sum_{j=1}^n
\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}(x_j-y_j),
\end{equation}
where $\mathbf{X}_i$ is on the line segment from $\mathbf{X}$ to $\mathbf{Y}$,
so  $\mathbf{X}_i\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$. From \eqref{eq:6.2.10},
\eqref{eq:6.2.11}, and Schwarz's inequality,
$$
(g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2\le\left(\sum_{j=1}^n\left[\frac{\partial
g_i
(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}\right]^2\right)
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2
<\frac{\epsilon^2}{ m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2.
$$
Summing this from $i=1$ to $i=m$ and taking square roots yields
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.12}
|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})|<\epsilon
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|
\mbox{\quad if\quad}\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0).
\end{equation}
To complete the proof, we note that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.13}
\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})=
\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})+\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}),
\end{equation}
 so \eqref{eq:6.2.12} and the triangle inequality imply \eqref{eq:6.2.8}.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood $N$ of $\mathbf{X}_0.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is a function that is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood $N$ of a point $\mathbf{X}_0 \in \R^n$ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: for every $\epsilon>0,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\epsilon$ is a positive real number [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let $f$ be continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1=(x_{11},x_{21}, \dots, x_{n1})$
and $\mathbf{X}_2=(x_{12},x_{22}, \dots,x_{n2})$ and differentiable on the
line segment $L$ from $\mathbf{X}_1$ to $\mathbf{X}_2.$ Then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:5.4.21}
f(\mathbf{X}_2)-f(\mathbf{X}_1)=\sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i} (\mathbf{X}_0)(x_{i2}-x_{i1})=(d_{\mathbf{X}_0}f)(\mathbf{X}_2
-\mathbf{X}_1)
\end{equation}
for some $\mathbf{X}_0$ on $L$ distinct
from $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Assumption (Mean Value Theorem for scalar functions): Let $f: \R^n \to \R$ be a function continuous at $\mathbf{X}_1$ and $\mathbf{X}_2$ and differentiable on the line segment $L$ between them. Then there exists a point $\mathbf{X}_c$ on $L$ (distinct from $\mathbf{X}_1, \mathbf{X}_2$) such that $f(\mathbf{X}_2) - f(\mathbf{X}_1) = \nabla f(\mathbf{X}_c) \cdot (\mathbf{X}_2 - \mathbf{X}_1)$, which is equivalent to $f(\mathbf{X}_2)-f(\mathbf{X}_1)=\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i} (\mathbf{X}_c)(x_{i2}-x_{i1})$ [def_1].

Definition:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood $N$ of $\mathbf{X}_0$ [tc_1].
• Define an auxiliary function $\mathbf{G}:\R^n\to\R^m$ as $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$, where $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is the Jacobian matrix of $\mathbf{F}$ at $\mathbf{X}_0$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
The components of $\mathbf{G}$ are
$$
g_i(\mathbf{X})=f_i(\mathbf{X})-\sum_{j=1}^n
\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_{0})
\partial x_j} x_j,
$$
so
$$
\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}=
\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X})}
{\partial x_j}-\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_0)}{\partial x_j}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The auxiliary function $\mathbf{G}$ is defined as $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The components $g_i$ of $\mathbf{G}$ and their partial derivatives are given by $g_i(\mathbf{X})=f_i(\mathbf{X})-\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_{0})}{\partial x_j} x_j$ and $\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j} = \frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}-\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_0)}{\partial x_j}$ for $i=1,\dots,m$ and $j=1,\dots,n$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Expand the definition of G into its components and apply the rules of differentiation.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Thus, $\partial g_i/\partial x_j$ is continuous on $N$ and zero at
$\mathbf{X}_0$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood $N$ of $\mathbf{X}_0$ [tc_1].
• The partial derivative is $\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j} = \frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}-\frac{\partial f_i(\mathbf{X}_0)}{\partial x_j}$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The partial derivative $\partial g_i/\partial x_j$ is continuous on $N$ and is equal to zero at $\mathbf{X}_0$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The continuity of $\partial g_i/\partial x_j$ follows from the continuity of $\partial f_i/\partial x_j$ (from tc_1). Evaluate the expression from l1 at $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{X}_0$ to show it is zero.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\epsilon$ is a positive real number [tc_2].
• The partial derivative $\partial g_i/\partial x_j$ is continuous on $N$ and is zero at $\mathbf{X}_0$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $\mathbf{X}$ with $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|<\delta$, we have $|\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X})}{\partial x_j}| < \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{mn}}$ for all $1\le i\le m$ and $1\le j\le n$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of continuity at a point. Since the function value is 0 at $\mathbf{X}_0$, for $\epsilon' = \epsilon/\sqrt{mn} > 0$, there exists a $\delta$ such that $|f(\mathbf{X}) - f(\mathbf{X}_0)| < \epsilon'$ when $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}_0|<\delta$, which simplifies to $|f(\mathbf{X})| < \epsilon'$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Now suppose that $\mathbf{X}$, $\mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$. By
Theorem~\ref{thmtype:5.4.5},
\begin{equation}
g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y})=\sum_{j=1}^n
\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}(x_j-y_j),
\end{equation}
where $\mathbf{X}_i$ is on the line segment from $\mathbf{X}$ to $\mathbf{Y}$,
so  $\mathbf{X}_i\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{F}$ is continuously differentiable on $N$ [tc_1].
• The Mean Value Theorem for scalar functions holds [def_1].
• The components of $\mathbf{G}$ are $g_i$ and are differentiable [l1].
• $\delta > 0$ is chosen as in [l3].
• $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $i \in \{1,\dots,m\}$, there exists a point $\mathbf{X}_i$ on the line segment from $\mathbf{X}$ to $\mathbf{Y}$ such that $g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y})=\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}(x_j-y_j)$. Furthermore, because the ball $B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is convex, $\mathbf{X}_i \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the Mean Value Theorem (def_1) to the function $g_i$, which is differentiable because F is (tc_1) and G is defined in terms of F (l1).

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \eqref{eq:6.2.10}, \eqref{eq:6.2.11}, and Schwarz's inequality,
$$
(g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2\le\left(\sum_{j=1}^n\left[\frac{\partial
g_i
(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}\right]^2\right)
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2
<\frac{\epsilon^2}{ m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists $\delta > 0$ s.t. for $|\mathbf{Z}-\mathbf{X}_0|<\delta$, $|\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{Z})}{\partial x_j}| < \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{mn}}$ [l3].
• For $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, $g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y})=\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j}(x_j-y_j)$ with $\mathbf{X}_i \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, we have $(g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2 < \frac{\epsilon^2}{m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2$ [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to the sum in l4, giving $(g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2 \le (\sum_{j=1}^n (\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j})^2) |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2$. Since $\mathbf{X}_i \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, apply the bound from l3 to each partial derivative term: $(\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j})^2 < (\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{mn}})^2 = \frac{\epsilon^2}{mn}$. Summing over $j=1..n$ gives $\sum_{j=1}^n (\frac{\partial g_i(\mathbf{X}_i)}{\partial x_j})^2 < n \frac{\epsilon^2}{mn} = \frac{\epsilon^2}{m}$.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, $(g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2 < \frac{\epsilon^2}{m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2$ for each component $i=1,\dots,m$ [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• If $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, then $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| < \epsilon |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Sum the inequality from l5 over all components $i=1,\dots,m$: $\sum_{i=1}^m (g_i(\mathbf{X})-g_i(\mathbf{Y}))^2 < \sum_{i=1}^m \frac{\epsilon^2}{m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2$. The left side is $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})|^2$. The right side is $m \frac{\epsilon^2}{m} |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2 = \epsilon^2 |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|^2$. Take the square root of both sides.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y}) = (\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})) + \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})$ [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From the definition of G, we have $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) = \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) + \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y}) = \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y}) + \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{Y}$. Subtract the second equation from the first and regroup terms.

proof_graph.natural_language: so \eqref{eq:6.2.12} and the triangle inequality imply \eqref{eq:6.2.8}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^m$ is a function with Jacobian matrix $\mathbf{F}'$ [tc_1].
• If $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, then $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| < \epsilon |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l6].
• $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y}) = (\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})) + \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})$ [l7].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, we have $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| < (\|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_{0})\| + \epsilon) |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Take the norm of both sides of the equation in l7. Apply the triangle inequality: $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| \le |\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| + |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})|$. Apply the bound from l6 to the first term and the definition of the operator norm ($|\mathbf{A}\mathbf{v}| \le \|\mathbf{A}\||\mathbf{v}|$) to the second term. Combine the terms.

nl_proof:
Let $\mathbf{X}$  and $\mathbf{Y}$ be arbitrary points in
$D_\mathbf{F}$  and let $\mathbf{G}$ be as in \eqref{eq:6.2.9}. From
\eqref{eq:6.2.13},
\begin{equation} \label{eq:6.2.16}
|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})|\ge\big|
|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}
-\mathbf{Y})|-|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})|\big|,
\end{equation}
Since
$$
\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}=[\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)]^{-1}
\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_{0})
(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}),
$$
\eqref{eq:6.2.14} implies that
$$
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|\le \frac{1}{ r} |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)
(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|,
$$
so
\begin{equation}\label{eq:6.2.17}
|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})|\ge r|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|.
\end{equation}
 Now choose $\delta>0$ so that \eqref{eq:6.2.12} holds.
Then \eqref{eq:6.2.16}  and \eqref{eq:6.2.17} imply \eqref{eq:6.2.15}.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood of $\mathbf{X}_0$ and $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular$.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is a function that is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood of a point $\mathbf{X}_0 \in \R^n$ [tc_1_part1]
• The Jacobian matrix $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular [tc_1_part2].

We assume:
• The Jacobian matrix $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular [tc_1_part2]
Definition:
• $r$ is a real number defined as $r = \frac{1}{\|(\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1}\|}$, where $\|\cdot\|$ is the operator norm [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: let $\mathbf{G}$ be as in \eqref{eq:6.2.9}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is a function that is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood of a point $\mathbf{X}_0 \in \R^n$ [tc_1_part1]
Definition:
• Define a function $\mathbf{G}:\R^n\to\R^n$ as $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) = \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ [def_2].

We assume:
• A function $\mathbf{G}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is defined as $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) = \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ [def_2]
Premise:
• For any $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in D_\mathbf{F}$, the following inequality holds: $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| \ge | |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{Y})| - |\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| |$ [def_3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since
$$
\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}=[\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)]^{-1}
\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_{0})
(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}),
$$
\eqref{eq:6.2.14} implies that
$$
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|\le \frac{1}{ r} |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)
(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The Jacobian matrix $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular [tc_1_part2]
• $r = \frac{1}{\|(\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1}\|}$ [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in \R^n$, $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}| \le \frac{1}{r} |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Start from the identity $\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y} = (\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1} (\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}))$, which is valid since $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular [tc_1_part2]. Apply the vector norm to both sides and use the operator norm inequality $|Av| \le ||A|||v|$ to get $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}| \le \| (\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1} \| |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})|$. Substitute $\|(\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1}\| = 1/r$ from [def_1].

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The Jacobian matrix $\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)$ is nonsingular [tc_1_part2]
• $r = \frac{1}{\|(\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1}\|}$ [def_1]
• For any vectors $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in \R^n$, $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}| \le \frac{1}{r} |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})|$ [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})| \ge r|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [def_1] and [tc_1_part2], $r > 0$. Multiply both sides of the inequality in [l1] by $r$ and rearrange.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now choose $\delta>0$ so that \eqref{eq:6.2.12} holds.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{F}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is continuously differentiable on a neighborhood of $\mathbf{X}_0$ [tc_1_part1]
• A function $\mathbf{G}:\R^n\to\R^n$ is defined as $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) = \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)\mathbf{X}$ [def_2]
Premise:
• For every $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that if $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, then $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| \le \epsilon |\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{Y}|$ [def_4].

proof_graph.natural_language: Then \eqref{eq:6.2.16}  and \eqref{eq:6.2.17} imply \eqref{eq:6.2.15}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $r = \frac{1}{\|(\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0))^{-1}\|}$ [def_1]
• For any $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in D_\mathbf{F}$, $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| \ge | |\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{Y})| - |\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| |$ [def_3]
• $|\mathbf{F}'(\mathbf{X}_0)(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})| \ge r|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l2]
• For every $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that if $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, then $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| \le \epsilon |\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{Y}|$ [def_4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For every $\epsilon > 0$, there is a $\delta > 0$ such that $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})|\ge (r-\epsilon) |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ if $\mathbf{X},\mathbf{Y}\in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_{0})$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let $\epsilon > 0$. WLOG, assume $\epsilon < r$. Use [def_4] to find a $\delta > 0$ corresponding to this $\epsilon$. For $\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in B_\delta(\mathbf{X}_0)$, start with [def_3]. Substitute the lower bound from [l2] into [def_3]: $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| \ge |r|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}| - |\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})||$. Use the property from [def_4] that $|\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X})-\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{Y})| \le \epsilon|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$. Then $|\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}) - \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{Y})| \ge |r|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}| - \epsilon|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|| = |(r-\epsilon)|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}||$. Since we assumed $r > \epsilon$, this simplifies to $(r-\epsilon)|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$.

nl_theorem:
Suppose that  $K$ is a bounded set with zero content and $\epsilon,$
$\rho>0.$  Then there are cubes $C_1,$ $C_2,$ \dots$,$
$C_r$ with edge lengths
$<\rho$ such that  $C_j\cap K\ne\emptyset,$ $1\le j\le r,$
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.5}
K\subset\bigcup_{j=1}^r C_j,
\end{equation}
and
$$
\sum_{j=1}^r V(C_j)<\epsilon.
$$
nl_proof:
Since $V(K)=0$,
$$
\int_C\psi_K(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=0
$$
if $C$ is any cube containing $K$. From this and the
definition of the integral, there is a $\delta>0$ such that if ${\bf
P}$ is any partition of $C$ with $\|{\bf P}\|\le\delta$ and $\sigma$
is any Riemann sum of $\psi_K$ over ${\bf P}$, then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.6}
0\le\sigma\le\epsilon.
\end{equation}
\newpage
\noindent
Now suppose that  ${\bf P}=\{C_1,C_2,\dots,C_k\}$ is a partition of $C$
into cubes with
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.7}
\|{\bf P}\|<\min (\rho,\delta),
\end{equation}
and let $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots, $C_k$ be numbered so that $C_j\cap K\ne
\emptyset$ if $1\le j\le r$  and
$C_j\cap K=\emptyset$ if $r+1\le j\le k$. Then \eqref{eq:7.3.5} holds, and
a typical Riemann sum of $\psi_K$ over ${\bf P}$ is of the form
$$
\sigma=\sum_{j=1}^r\psi_K(\mathbf{X}_j)V(C_j)
$$
with $\mathbf{X}_j\in C_j$, $1\le j\le r$. In particular, we
can choose
$\mathbf{X}_j$ from $K$, so that $\psi_K(\mathbf{X}_j)=1$,  and
$$
\sigma=\sum_{j=1}^r V(C_j).
$$
Now \eqref{eq:7.3.6} and \eqref{eq:7.3.7} imply that $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots,
$C_r$ have the required properties.

proof_graph.natural_language: K is a bounded set
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• K is a bounded set in ℝⁿ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: K is a bounded set with zero content
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• K has zero content, denoted as V(K) = 0 [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: ϵ, ρ > 0
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• ϵ is a positive real number (ϵ > 0) [tc_3].

proof_graph.natural_language: ϵ, ρ > 0
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• ρ is a positive real number (ρ > 0) [tc_4].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since V(K)=0, ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 if C is any cube containing K.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• K has zero content, V(K) = 0 [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any cube C that contains K, the Riemann integral of the characteristic function of K over C is zero: ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows from the definition of a set having zero content, where the volume is the integral of its characteristic function.

proof_graph.natural_language: From this and the definition of the integral, there is a δ>0 such that if P is any partition of C with ∥P∥≤δ and σ is any Riemann sum of ψ_K over P, then 0≤σ≤ϵ.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any cube C containing K, ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].
• ϵ > 0 [tc_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any cube C containing K, there exists a δ > 0 such that if P is any partition of C with norm ∥P∥ ≤ δ, then any Riemann sum σ of ψ_K over P satisfies 0 ≤ σ ≤ ϵ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the definition of the Riemann integral being equal to 0. For ψ_K ≥ 0, the sum is non-negative.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now suppose that P={C_1,C_2,…,C_k} is a partition of C into cubes with ∥P∥<min(ρ,δ)
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Since K is bounded [tc_1], let C be a cube containing K.
• Let δ > 0 be the number from [l2] corresponding to C and ϵ [tc_3].
• Let P = {C_1, C_2, ..., C_k} be a partition of C into cubes with partition norm ∥P∥ < min(ρ, δ), where ρ is from [tc_4] [def_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Define a specific partition P of a containing cube C, whose norm is smaller than both ρ and the δ obtained from the definition of the integral.

proof_graph.natural_language: and let C_1, C_2, …, C_k be numbered so that C_j∩K≠∅ if 1≤j≤r and C_j∩K=∅ if r+1≤j≤k.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Given the partition P from [def_1], we re-index its cubes {C_1, ..., C_k} and define an integer r such that C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ for 1 ≤ j ≤ r, and C_j ∩ K = ∅ for r+1 ≤ j ≤ k. This defines the sub-collection of cubes {C_1, ..., C_r} [def_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Partition the set of cubes from P into two groups based on whether they intersect K. This defines the set of cubes we are interested in.

proof_graph.natural_language: Then (7.3.5) holds,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• P={C_1,…,C_k} is a partition of a cube C that contains K [def_1].
• The cubes are indexed such that C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ for 1 ≤ j ≤ r and C_j ∩ K = ∅ for r+1 ≤ j ≤ k [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• K is a subset of the union of the first r cubes: K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Show that for any x in K, since K is in C and C is partitioned by {C_j}, x must be in some C_j. By the indexing, this C_j must have j ≤ r.

proof_graph.natural_language: and a typical Riemann sum of ψ_K over P is of the form σ=∑_{j=1}^r ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j) with X_j∈C_j, 1≤j≤r.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The cubes of partition P are indexed such that C_j ∩ K = ∅ for j > r [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• A Riemann sum σ = ∑_{j=1}^k ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j) over the partition P simplifies to σ = ∑_{j=1}^r ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j), because for j > r, any X_j ∈ C_j is not in K, making ψ_K(X_j) = 0 [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Expand the Riemann sum definition. For indices j > r, the term ψ_K(X_j) is 0 by the property of the characteristic function and the indexing scheme.

proof_graph.natural_language: In particular, we can choose X_j from K, so that ψ_K(X_j)=1, and σ=∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j).
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For 1 ≤ j ≤ r, C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ [def_2].
• A Riemann sum has the form σ = ∑_{j=1}^r ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j) [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a specific Riemann sum σ (by choosing sample points X_j ∈ C_j ∩ K) which is equal to ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For each j from 1 to r, choose X_j from the non-empty intersection C_j ∩ K. For these points, ψ_K(X_j) = 1. Substitute this into the simplified sum form.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now (7.3.6) and (7.3.7) imply that C_1, C_2, …, C_r have the required properties.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For the chosen partition P, its norm ∥P∥ < δ [def_1].
• For any partition with norm ≤ δ, any Riemann sum σ satisfies 0 ≤ σ ≤ ϵ [l2].
• There exists a particular Riemann sum σ equal to ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The sum of the volumes of the selected cubes is bounded by ϵ: ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Our specific partition P satisfies the condition ∥P∥ ≤ δ. Therefore, any Riemann sum, including the specific one we constructed, must be ≤ ϵ.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now suppose that P={C_1,C_2,…,C_k} is a partition of C into cubes with ∥P∥<min(ρ,δ)
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The partition P has norm ∥P∥ < min(ρ, δ) [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The edge length of each cube C_j in the partition is less than ρ [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The norm of a partition of cubes is the maximum edge length of any cube in it. Since the norm is less than ρ, so is each edge length.

proof_graph.natural_language: Now (7.3.6) and (7.3.7) imply that C_1, C_2, …, C_r have the required properties.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• A set of cubes {C_1, ..., C_r} is defined by selecting all cubes from a partition P that have a non-empty intersection with K [def_2].
• These cubes have edge lengths less than ρ [l7].
• The set K is contained in the union of these cubes, K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j [l3].
• The sum of the volumes of these cubes satisfies ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exist cubes C_1, ..., C_r with edge lengths < ρ such that C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ for 1 ≤ j ≤ r, K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j, and ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ, satisfying the theorem's conditions (with ≤ ϵ as proved) [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Combine the properties established in the preceding lemmas to show that the constructed set of cubes {C_1, ..., C_r} meets all the requirements of the theorem.

nl_theorem:
Suppose that  $S$ is Jordan measurable
and $\epsilon,$  $\rho>0.$  Then there are cubes
$C_1,$ $C_2,$ \dots$,$ $C_r$ in $S$ with edge lengths $<\rho,$ such
that  $C_j\subset  S,$ $1\le j\le r,$
$C_i^0\cap C_j^0=\emptyset$ if $i\ne j,$ and
\begin{equation} \label{eq:7.3.35}
V(S)\le\sum_{j=1}^r V(C_j)+\epsilon.
\end{equation}
nl_proof:
Since $S$ is Jordan measurable,
$$
\int_C\psi_S(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=V(S)
$$
if $C$ is any cube containing $S$. From this and the
definition of the integral, there is a $\delta>0$ such that if ${\bf
P}$ is any partition of $C$ with $\|{\bf P}\|<\delta$ and $\sigma$
is any Riemann sum of $\psi_S$ over ${\bf P}$, then
$\sigma>V(S)-\epsilon/2$. Therefore, if $s(P)$ is the lower sum of
$\psi_S$  over $\mathbf{P}$, then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:7.3.36}
s(\mathbf{P})>V(S)-\epsilon\mbox{\quad if \quad}\|\mathbf{P}\|<\delta.
\end{equation}
Now suppose that  ${\bf P}=\{C_1,C_2,\dots,C_k\}$ is a partition of $C$
into cubes with
$\|{\bf P}\|<\min (\rho,\delta)$,
and let $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots, $C_k$ be numbered so that $C_j\subset
S$ if
 $1\le j\le r$ and $C_j\cap S^c\ne\emptyset$ if $j>r$.
From \eqref{eq:7.3.4}, $s(\mathbf{P})=\sum_{j=1}^rV(C_k)$. This and
\eqref{eq:7.3.36} imply \eqref{eq:7.3.35}. Clearly, $C_i^0\cap
C_j^0=\emptyset$ if $i\ne j$.

proof_graph.natural_language: Suppose that S is Jordan measurable
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• S is a Jordan measurable set in ℝⁿ [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: and $\epsilon,$  $\rho>0.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• ε > 0 and ρ > 0 are real numbers [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $S$ is Jordan measurable,
$$
\int_C\psi_S(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=V(S)
$$
if $C$ is any cube containing $S$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• S is a Jordan measurable set in ℝⁿ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any cube C containing S, the integral of the characteristic function of S over C is equal to the volume of S, i.e., ∫_C ψ_S(X) dX = V(S) [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the definition of the volume of a Jordan measurable set.

proof_graph.natural_language:
From this and the
definition of the integral, there is a $\delta>0$ such that if ${\bf P}$ is any partition of $C$ with $\|{\bf P}\|<\delta$ and $\sigma$
is any Riemann sum of $\psi_S$ over ${\bf P}$, then
$\sigma>V(S)-\epsilon/2$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any cube C containing S, ∫_C ψ_S(X) dX = V(S) [l1].
• ε > 0 [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a δ > 0 such that for any cube C containing S and for any partition P of C with mesh ||P|| < δ, and for any Riemann sum σ of ψ_S over P, we have σ > V(S) - ε/2 [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the definition of the Riemann integral, which states that for any tolerance (here ε/2), there is a δ such that all Riemann sums for finer partitions are within that tolerance of the integral's value.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• There exists a δ > 0 such that for any partition P with ||P|| < δ, any Riemann sum σ of ψ_S over P satisfies σ > V(S) - ε/2 [l2].
• ε > 0 [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For the same δ, if a partition P has mesh ||P|| < δ, then its lower sum s(P) of ψ_S satisfies s(P) > V(S) - ε [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The lower sum is the infimum of all Riemann sums for a given partition. Since all Riemann sums are > V(S) - ε/2, the lower sum must be ≥ V(S) - ε/2. The statement s(P) > V(S) - ε follows because ε > 0 implies V(S) - ε < V(S) - ε/2.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Now suppose that  ${\bf P}=\{C_1,C_2,\dots,C_k\}$ is a partition of $C$
into cubes with
$\|{\bf P}\|<\min (\rho,\delta)$,
and let $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots, $C_k$ be numbered so that $C_j\subset
S$
 if
 $1\le j\le r$ and $C_j\cap S^c
e\emptyset$ if $j>r$.
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let C be a cube containing the Jordan measurable set S [tc_1].
• Let ρ > 0 [tc_2] and δ > 0 be the value from [l3].
• Let P = {C₁, C₂, ..., Cₖ} be a partition of C into cubes with mesh ||P|| < min(ρ, δ).
• The cubes are numbered such that {C₁, ..., Cᵣ} are the cubes in the partition that are subsets of S (Cⱼ ⊂ S), and {Cᵣ₊₁, ..., Cₖ} are the cubes that are not subsets of S (Cⱼ not⊂ S) [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: From \eqref{eq:7.3.4}, $s(\mathbf{P})=\sum_{j=1}^rV(C_k)$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let P = {C₁, ..., Cₖ} be the partition from [def_1], where Cⱼ ⊂ S for 1 ≤ j ≤ r and Cⱼ not⊂ S for j > r [def_1].
• The lower sum of ψ_S over P is defined as s(P)=∑_{j=1}ᵏ mⱼ V(Cⱼ), where mⱼ = inf_{X ∈ Cⱼ} ψ_S(X).
Therefore, we conclude:
• s(P) = ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For 1 ≤ j ≤ r, Cⱼ ⊂ S, so ψ_S(X) = 1 on Cⱼ, making mⱼ=1. For j > r, Cⱼ contains points not in S, so inf ψ_S = 0 and mⱼ=0. The sum reduces accordingly. Note the typo in the original text ($V(C_k)$ should be $V(C_j)$).

proof_graph.natural_language:
This and
\eqref{eq:7.3.36} imply \eqref{eq:7.3.35}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For the partition P defined in [def_1], its mesh satisfies ||P|| < δ [def_1].
• If ||P|| < δ, then s(P) > V(S) - ε [l3].
• For this partition, s(P) = ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• V(S) ≤ ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) + ε [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From [def_1], we know ||P|| < δ, which allows applying [l3] to get s(P) > V(S) - ε. Substitute s(P) with the expression from [l4] to get ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) > V(S) - ε. Rearranging this gives V(S) < ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) + ε, which implies the non-strict inequality.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Clearly, $C_i^0\cap
C_j^0=\emptyset$ if $i\ne j$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let P = {C₁, C₂, ..., Cₖ} be a partition of a cube C [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The interiors of the cubes in the partition are disjoint: Cᵢ⁰ ∩ Cⱼ⁰ = ∅ for i ≠ j [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a fundamental property of a partition.

proof_graph.natural_language:
This and
\eqref{eq:7.3.36} imply \eqref{eq:7.3.35}. Clearly, $C_i^0\cap
C_j^0=\emptyset$ if $i\ne j$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• S is a Jordan measurable set, and ε > 0, ρ > 0 [tc_1, tc_2].
• Cubes {C₁, ..., Cᵣ} are constructed as the subset of cubes in a partition P that are contained in S, where the partition has mesh ||P|| < min(ρ, δ) [def_1].
• V(S) ≤ ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) + ε [l5].
• Cᵢ⁰ ∩ Cⱼ⁰ = ∅ for i ≠ j [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exist cubes C₁, ..., Cᵣ such that:
  1. The edge length of each Cⱼ is less than ρ.
  2. Cⱼ ⊂ S for 1 ≤ j ≤ r.
  3. Cᵢ⁰ ∩ Cⱼ⁰ = ∅ for i ≠ j, where 1 ≤ i, j ≤ r.
  4. V(S) ≤ ∑_{j=1}ʳ V(Cⱼ) + ε. [ts_1]
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the cubes {Cⱼ}_{j=1..r} from [def_1] as the witnesses. Property 1 (edge length < ρ) and Property 2 (subset of S) follow from the construction in [def_1]. Property 3 (disjoint interiors) follows from [l6], as it applies to all cubes in the partition, including this subset. Property 4 (volume inequality) is proven in [l5].

nl_proof:
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be any two positive numbers, and
consider the function
$$
f(\beta)=\frac{\alpha^p}{p}+\frac{\beta^q}{q}-\alpha\beta,
$$
\newpage
\noindent
where we regard $\alpha$ as a constant. Since $f'(\beta)=\beta^{q-1}-\alpha$ and
$f''(\beta)=(q-1)\beta^{q-2}>0$  for $\beta>0$, $f$ assumes its minimum value
on $[0,\infty)$ at $\beta=\alpha^{1/(q-1)}=\alpha^{p-1}$. But
$$
f(\alpha^{p-1})=\frac{\alpha^p}{p}+\frac{\alpha^{(p-1)q}}{q}-\alpha^p
=\alpha^p\left(\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}-1\right)=0.
$$
Therefore,
\begin{equation} \label{eq:8.1.7}
\alpha\beta\le \frac{\alpha^p}{p}+\frac{\beta^q}{q}\mbox{\quad if \quad}
\alpha, \beta\ge0.
\end{equation}
Now let
$$
\alpha_i=\mu_i\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \mu_j^p\right)^{-1/p}
\mbox{\quad and \quad}
\beta_i=\nu_i\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \nu_j^q\right)^{-1/q}.
$$
From \eqref{eq:8.1.7},
$$
\alpha_i\beta_i\le\frac{\mu_i^p}{p}\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \mu_j^p\right)^{-1}
+\frac{\nu_i^q}{q}\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \nu_j^q\right)^{-1}.
$$
From \eqref{eq:8.1.5}, summing this from $i=1$ to $n$ yields $\sum_{i=1}^n
\alpha_i\beta_i\le1$, which implies
\eqref{eq:8.1.6}.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Suppose that  $\mu_1,$ $\mu_2,$ \dots$,$ $\mu_n$ and $
u_1,$ $
u_2,$ 
\dots$,$ $
u_n$ are nonnegative  numbers$.$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let (μ_i)_{i=1 to n} and (ν_i)_{i=1 to n} be sequences of n non-negative real numbers [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Let $p>1$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let p be a real number such that p > 1 [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: and $q=p/(p-1)$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let p be a real number such that p > 1 [tc_2]
• Let q be a real number such that q = p / (p-1) [tc_3].

We assume:
• p > 1 [tc_2]
• q = p / (p-1) [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• 1/p + 1/q = 1 [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute q = p/(p-1) into 1/p + 1/q and simplify the expression to show it equals 1.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be any two positive numbers, and
consider the function
$$
f(\beta)=\frac{\alpha^p}{p}+\frac{\beta^q}{q}-\alpha\beta,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p > 1 [tc_2]
• q = p / (p-1) [tc_3]
Definition:
• For any positive numbers α and β, define the function f(β) = (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) - αβ, where α is treated as a constant [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $f'(\beta)=\beta^{q-1}-\alpha$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• f(β) = (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) - αβ [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The first derivative of f with respect to β is f'(β) = β^(q-1) - α [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Differentiate f(β) with respect to β term by term.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since $f'(\beta)=\beta^{q-1}-\alpha$ and
$f''(\beta)=(q-1)\beta^{q-2}>0$  for $\beta>0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p > 1 [tc_2]
• q = p / (p-1) [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• q > 1 [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Since p > 1, p-1 > 0. Thus q = p/(p-1) can be written as (p-1+1)/(p-1) = 1 + 1/(p-1). Since 1/(p-1) > 0, q > 1.

proof_graph.natural_language: $f''(\beta)=(q-1)\beta^{q-2}>0$  for $\beta>0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• f'(β) = β^(q-1) - α [l2]
• q > 1 [l3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The second derivative f''(β) = (q-1)β^(q-2) is positive for all β > 0 [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Differentiate f'(β) = β^(q-1) - α. The result is positive because q-1 > 0 (from l3) and β^(q-2) > 0 for β > 0.

proof_graph.natural_language: at $\beta=\alpha^{1/(q-1)}=\alpha^{p-1}$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• q = p / (p-1) [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• 1 / (q-1) = p - 1 [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From q = p/(p-1), we have q-1 = p/(p-1) - 1 = (p - (p-1))/(p-1) = 1/(p-1). Invert both sides.

proof_graph.natural_language:
$f$ assumes its minimum value
on $[0,\infty)$ at $\beta=\alpha^{1/(q-1)}=\alpha^{p-1}$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• The first derivative is f'(β) = β^(q-1) - α [l2]
• The second derivative is positive, f''(β) > 0 [l4]
• The exponent identity 1/(q-1) = p-1 holds [l5]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The function f(β) has a unique minimum at β = α^(1/(q-1)), which simplifies to β = α^(p-1) [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Set f'(β) = 0 to find the critical point β = α^(1/(q-1)). Use f''>0 to confirm it is a minimum. Use l5 to rewrite the exponent.

proof_graph.natural_language:
But
$$
f(\alpha^{p-1})=\frac{\alpha^p}{p}+\frac{\alpha^{(p-1)q}}{q}-\alpha^p
=\alpha^p\left(\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}-1\right)=0.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• f(β) = (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) - αβ [def_1]
• 1/p + 1/q = 1 [l1]
• The minimum of f occurs at β = α^(p-1) [l6]
• q = p / (p-1), which implies (p-1)q = p [tc_3]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The minimum value of f is f(α^(p-1)) = 0 [l7].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute β = α^(p-1) into f(β). Use the identity (p-1)q = p (derived from tc_3) to simplify α^((p-1)q) to α^p. Factor out α^p and use l1 to show the result is 0.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• f(β) = (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) - αβ [def_1]
• The minimum value of f(β) for β > 0 is 0 [l7]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For all non-negative numbers α and β, we have αβ ≤ (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) (Young's Inequality) [l8].
proof_graph.lean_hint: From l7, the minimum of f(β) is 0. This means f(β) ≥ 0 for all β ≥ 0. Rearranging f(β) ≥ 0 gives the inequality. The case where α=0 or β=0 is trivial.

proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• (μ_i) and (ν_i) are non-negative sequences [tc_1]
• p > 1 [tc_2] and q = p/(p-1) [tc_3]
Definition:
• Define new sequences (α_i) and (β_i) as α_i = μ_i * (Σ_j μ_j^p)^(-1/p) and β_i = ν_i * (Σ_j ν_j^q)^(-1/q) for i=1 to n [def_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Handle the trivial cases where Σμ_j^p = 0 or Σν_j^q = 0 separately. If Σμ_j^p = 0, then all μ_j = 0, and Hölder's inequality is 0 ≤ 0. The main proof assumes these sums are non-zero.

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \eqref{eq:8.1.7},
$$
\alpha_i\beta_i\le\frac{\mu_i^p}{p}\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \mu_j^p\right)^{-1}
+\frac{\nu_i^q}{q}\left(\sum_{j=1}^n \nu_j^q\right)^{-1}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Young's inequality: αβ ≤ (α^p / p) + (β^q / q) [l8]
• The definitions of α_i and β_i [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• α_i * β_i ≤ (μ_i^p / p) * (Σ_j μ_j^p)^(-1) + (ν_i^q / q) * (Σ_j ν_j^q)^(-1) [l9].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply Young's inequality [l8] to α_i and β_i from [def_2]. Then, substitute the definitions of α_i and β_i into the right-hand side and simplify the exponents: (α_i)^p = μ_i^p * (Σ_j μ_j^p)^(-1) and (β_i)^q = ν_i^q * (Σ_j ν_j^q)^(-1).

proof_graph.natural_language:
From \eqref{eq:8.1.5}, summing this from $i=1$ to $n$ yields $\sum_{i=1}^n
\alpha_i\beta_i\le1$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For each i, α_i * β_i ≤ (μ_i^p / p) * (Σ_j μ_j^p)^(-1) + (ν_i^q / q) * (Σ_j ν_j^q)^(-1) [l9]
• 1/p + 1/q = 1 [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• Σ_{i=1 to n} α_i * β_i ≤ 1 [l10].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Sum the inequality from [l9] over i from 1 to n. On the RHS, split the sum and factor out the constant terms (the inverses of the sums). The sums Σ_i μ_i^p and Σ_i ν_i^q will cancel with their inverses, leaving 1/p + 1/q, which equals 1 by [l1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
which implies
\eqref{eq:8.1.6}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Σ_{i=1 to n} α_i * β_i ≤ 1 [l10]
• The definitions of α_i and β_i in terms of μ_i and ν_i [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• Σ_{i=1 to n} μ_i * ν_i ≤ (Σ_{i=1 to n} μ_i^p)^(1/p) * (Σ_{i=1 to n} ν_i^q)^(1/q) [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definitions of α_i and β_i from [def_2] into the left-hand side of the inequality Σ α_i * β_i ≤ 1. Factor out the denominators (Σμ^p)^(-1/p) and (Σν^q)^(-1/q). Then multiply both sides of the inequality by these terms to isolate Σ μ_i * ν_i.

nl_proof:
Again, let $q=p/(p-1)$. We write
\begin{equation} \label{eq:8.1.9}
\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p=\sum_{i=1}^n u_i(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}
+\sum_{i=1}^n v_i(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}.
\end{equation}
From H\"older's inequality with $\mu_i=u_i$ and
$\nu_i=(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}$,
\begin{equation} \label{eq:8.1.10}
\sum_{i=1}^n u_i(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}\le
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p\right)^{1/q},
\end{equation}
since $q(p-1)=p$. Similarly,
$$
\sum_{i=1}^n v_i(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}\le
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n v_i^p\right)^{1/p}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p\right)^{1/q}.
$$
This, \eqref{eq:8.1.9}, and \eqref{eq:8.1.10} imply that
$$
\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p
\le\left[\left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}
+\left(\sum_{i=1}^n v_i^p\right)^{1/p}\right]
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p\right)^{1/q}.
$$
\newpage
\noindent
Since $1-1/q=1/p$, this implies \eqref{eq:8.1.8}, which is
known as {\it Minkowski's inequality\/}.

proof_graph.natural_language: u_1, u_2, \dots, u_n and v_1, v_2, \dots, v_n are nonnegative numbers
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let n be a natural number. u and v are sequences of n nonnegative real numbers, denoted u_i and v_i for i from 1 to n [tc_1].

Premise:
• p is a real number such that p > 1 [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: Again, let q=p/(p-1).
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• p is a real number such that p > 1 [tc_2].
Definition:
• Let q be a real number defined as q = p / (p-1) [def_1].

We assume:
• Let n be a natural number. u and v are sequences of n nonnegative real numbers [tc_1].
• p is a real number such that p > 1 [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{i=1}^n (u_i+v_i)^p = ∑_{i=1}^n u_i(u_i+v_i)^(p-1) + ∑_{i=1}^n v_i(u_i+v_i)^(p-1) [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: For each i, expand (u_i+v_i)^p as (u_i+v_i) * (u_i+v_i)^(p-1) and distribute. Then use the linearity of summation (`sum_add_distrib`).

proof_graph.natural_language: since q(p-1)=p
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For p > 1, q is defined as q = p / (p-1) [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• q * (p - 1) = p [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definition of q from [def_1] and simplify. `field_simp` should work, given `p-1 ≠ 0` from the premise of [def_1].

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• u and v are sequences of n nonnegative real numbers [tc_1].
• For p > 1, q is defined as q = p / (p-1) [def_1].
• q * (p - 1) = p [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{i=1}^n u_i * (u_i+v_i)^(p-1) ≤ (∑_{i=1}^n u_i^p)^(1/p) * (∑_{i=1}^n (u_i+v_i)^p)^(1/q) [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply Hölder's inequality to the sequences (u_i) and ((u_i+v_i)^(p-1)). The conjugate exponents are p and q from [def_1]. The second factor in Hölder's simplifies using `(x^(p-1))^q = x^p` which follows from `q*(p-1)=p` [l2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Similarly,
$$
\sum_{i=1}^n v_i(u_i+v_i)^{p-1}\le
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n v_i^p\right)^{1/p}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p\right)^{1/q}.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• u and v are sequences of n nonnegative real numbers [tc_1].
• For p > 1, q is defined as q = p / (p-1) [def_1].
• q * (p - 1) = p [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• ∑_{i=1}^n v_i * (u_i+v_i)^(p-1) ≤ (∑_{i=1}^n v_i^p)^(1/p) * (∑_{i=1}^n (u_i+v_i)^p)^(1/q) [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply Hölder's inequality to the sequences (v_i) and ((u_i+v_i)^(p-1)). The reasoning is symmetric to the previous step [l3].

proof_graph.natural_language:
This, \eqref{eq:8.1.9}, and \eqref{eq:8.1.10} imply that
$$
\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p
\le\left[\left(\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^p\right)^{1/p}
+\left(\sum_{i=1}^n v_i^p\right)^{1/p}\right]
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n(u_i+v_i)^p\right)^{1/q}.
$$
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the left-hand side using [l1]. Apply the inequalities from [l3] and [l4] to bound the two terms on the right-hand side. Then, factor out the common term `(∑_{i=1}^n (u_i+v_i)^p)^(1/q)` using `left_distrib`.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since 1-1/q=1/p
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For p > 1, q is defined as q = p / (p-1) [def_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• 1 - 1/q = 1/p [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Substitute the definition of q from [def_1] and simplify. `field_simp` should work.

proof_graph.natural_language: this implies \eqref{eq:8.1.8}
proof_graph.lean_hint: Let `S = ∑_{i=1}^n (u_i+v_i)^p`. The inequality from [l5] is `S ≤ [ ... ] * S^(1/q)`. Handle the case `S = 0` separately (it's trivial). If `S > 0`, divide both sides by `S^(1/q)`. The left side becomes `S^(1 - 1/q)`. Use the identity `1 - 1/q = 1/p` from [l6] to get `S^(1/p)`, which yields the desired inequality.

nl_proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq:1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq:1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq:1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq:1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $a$ and $b$ are any two real numbers
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• a and b are any two real numbers [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: in \eqref{eq:1.1.3}
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• We assume the triangle inequality, referenced as (1.1.3): For any two real numbers x and y, |x+y| ≤ |x|+|y| [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are any two real numbers [tc_1]
• For any two real numbers x and y, |x+y| ≤ |x|+|y| [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |a| ≤ |a-b|+|b| [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the triangle inequality [def_1] with x=a-b and y=b.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• |a| ≤ |a-b|+|b| [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |a-b| ≥ |a|-|b| [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rearrange the inequality from [l1] by subtracting |b| from both sides. The `linarith` tactic should solve this.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are any two real numbers [tc_1]
• For any two real numbers x and y, |x+y| ≤ |x|+|y| [def_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |b-a| ≥ |b|-|a| [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows by symmetry from the argument for [l2]. Apply the triangle inequality [def_1] with x=b-a and y=a to get |b| ≤ |b-a|+|a|, then rearrange.

proof_graph.natural_language: since $|b-a|=|a-b|$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• a and b are real numbers [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |b-a| = |a-b| [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the library lemma `abs_sub_comm a b`.

proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• |b-a| ≥ |b|-|a| [l3]
• |b-a| = |a-b| [l4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |a-b| ≥ |b|-|a| [l5].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite the left-hand side of inequality [l3] using the equality [l4].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• For any real number x, |x| is defined as x if x ≥ 0 and -x if x < 0. This implies that for any real numbers a and b, ||a|-|b|| equals |a|-|b| if |a|≥|b|, and |b|-|a| if |a|<|b| [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: \eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq:1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq:1.1.4}.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• |a-b| ≥ |a|-|b| [l2]
• |a-b| ≥ |b|-|a| [l5]
• For any real numbers a and b, ||a|-|b|| equals |a|-|b| if |a|≥|b|, and |b|-|a| if |a|<|b| [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |a-b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is a proof by cases. Use [def_2] to split on the condition |a| ≥ |b|. If true, ||a|-|b|| = |a|-|b|, and the goal follows from [l2]. If false, ||a|-|b|| = |b|-|a|, and the goal follows from [l5].

proof_graph.natural_language:
since
$|-b|=|b|$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• b is a real number [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |-b| = |b| [l6].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the library lemma `abs_neg`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq:1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq:1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For any two real numbers a and b, |a-b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| [ts_1]
• For any real number b, |-b| = |b| [l6]
• a and b are any two real numbers [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• |a+b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| [ts_2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply theorem [ts_1] with b replaced by -b. This yields |a - (-b)| ≥ ||a| - |-b||. Simplify the expression using `sub_neg_eq_add` for the left side and the equality from [l6] for the right side.

nl_theorem:
If $\{F_n\}$ converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$ and each $F_n$ is
continuous on $S,$ then so is $F;$ that is$,$ a uniform limit of
continuous functions is continuous.
nl_proof:
Since
\begin{eqnarray*}
\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|\ar\le \int_a^b
|F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx\\
\ar\le  (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S
\end{eqnarray*}
and $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$, the conclusion follows.

proof_graph.natural_language: If {$F_n$} converges uniformly to $F$ on $S$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• {$F_n$ : ℕ → (S → ℝ)} is a sequence of real-valued functions on a set S that converges uniformly to a function F: S → ℝ on S [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: each $F_n$ is continuous on $S,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• {$F_n$} is a sequence of real-valued functions on a set S [tc_1]
• For each n ∈ ℕ, the function $F_n$ is continuous on S [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since 
\begin{eqnarray*}\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|...
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• Let S be a set from the premise [tc_1]
• Let $[a, b]$ be a closed real interval such that $[a, b] ⊆ S$ [def_1].

Definition:
• Let S be a set and g: S → ℝ be a function, as in the premise [tc_1]
• The supremum norm on S is defined as $||g||_S = \sup_{x∈S} |g(x)|$ [def_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: \begin{eqnarray*}\left|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx-\int_a^b F(x)\,dx\right|\ar\le \int_a^b |F_n(x)-F(x)|\,dx\\ \ar\le  (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S\end{eqnarray*}
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• {$F_n$} is a sequence of functions on S converging uniformly to F [tc_1]
• Each $F_n$ is continuous on S, which implies integrability on compact subsets [tc_2]
• $[a, b]$ is a closed real interval such that $[a, b] ⊆ S$ [def_1]
• The supremum norm on S is $||g||_S = \sup_{x∈S} |g(x)|$ [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each n, $|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx| \le (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: First, use the linearity of the integral and the property |∫g| ≤ ∫|g| to show |∫F_n - ∫F| ≤ ∫|F_n - F|. Second, use the definition of the supremum norm to state |F_n(x) - F(x)| ≤ ||F_n - F||_S for all x, then integrate this inequality over [a,b]. Combine the two inequalities via transitivity.

proof_graph.natural_language: $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• {$F_n$} converges uniformly to F on S [tc_1]
• The supremum norm on S is $||g||_S = \sup_{x∈S} |g(x)|$ [def_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This is the definition of uniform convergence expressed using the supremum norm.

proof_graph.natural_language: the conclusion follows.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• For each n, $|\int_a^b F_n(x)\,dx - \int_a^b F(x)\,dx| \le (b-a)\|F_n-F\|_S$ [l1]
• $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|F_n-F\|_S=0$ [l2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• The limit function F is continuous on S [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This step represents a logical gap in the proof. The premises (l1, l2) establish that ∫F_n → ∫F. This does not prove the continuity of F. The standard proof of continuity uses an epsilon-delta argument and the triangle inequality, not properties of integrals.

nl_theorem:
If $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are
 in $\R^n,$ then
$$
|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|\ge\left| |\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\right|.
$$

We can assume the following statement(s) without a proof. 

If $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are in $\R^n,$ then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:5.1.6}
|\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{Y}|\le |\mathbf{X}|+|\mathbf{Y}|,
\end{equation}
with equality if and only if one of the vectors is a nonnegative
multiple of the other$.$
nl_proof:
Since
$$
\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{Y}+(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}),
$$
Theorem~\ref{thmtype:5.1.6} implies that
$$
|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}|+|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|,
$$
which is equivalent to
$$
|\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|.
$$
Interchanging $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$  yields
$$
|\mathbf{Y}|-|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|.
$$
Since $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|=|\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$,
the last two inequalities imply the stated conclusion.

proof_graph.natural_language: If $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are in $\R^n,$
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1].

Premise:
• For any vectors $\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{V}$ in $\mathbb{R}^n$, the triangle inequality holds: $|\mathbf{U}+\mathbf{V}|\le |\mathbf{U}|+|\mathbf{V}|$ [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language:
Since
$$
\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{Y}+(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}),
$$
Theorem~\ref{thmtype:5.1.6} implies that
$$
|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}|+|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|,
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1]
• For any vectors $\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{V}$ in $\mathbb{R}^n$, the triangle inequality holds: $|\mathbf{U}+\mathbf{V}|\le |\mathbf{U}|+|\mathbf{V}|$ [tc_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}|+|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the triangle inequality [tc_2] to the vector identity $\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{Y}+(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})$, by setting $\mathbf{U} = \mathbf{Y}$ and $\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}$.

proof_graph.natural_language:
which is equivalent to
$$
|\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}|+|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rearrange the inequality by subtracting $|\mathbf{Y}|$ from both sides. This can be solved with `linarith`.

proof_graph.natural_language:
Interchanging $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$  yields
$$
|\mathbf{Y}|-|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|.
$$
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1]
• For any vectors $\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{V}$ in $\mathbb{R}^n$, the triangle inequality holds: $|\mathbf{U}+\mathbf{V}|\le |\mathbf{U}|+|\mathbf{V}|$ [tc_2]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{Y}|-|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$ [l3].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Apply the same reasoning as for [l1] and [l2], but with variables $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ swapped. Start with the identity $\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{X}+(\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X})$, apply the triangle inequality [tc_2], and rearrange.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|=|\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$,
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathbf{Y}$ are vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ [tc_1]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|=|\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$ [l4].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Use the property of norms that $|-\mathbf{v}| = |\mathbf{v}|$. Since $\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X} = -(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y})$, the equality holds. Use the library lemma `norm_sub_rev`.

proof_graph.natural_language: the last two inequalities imply the stated conclusion.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• $|\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$ [l2]
• $|\mathbf{Y}|-|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$ [l3]
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|=|\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{X}|$ [l4]
Therefore, we conclude:
• $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|\ge\left| |\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\right|$ [ts_1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: Rewrite [l3] using [l4] to get $|\mathbf{Y}|-|\mathbf{X}|\le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$, which is equivalent to $-(|\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|) \le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$. Together with [l2], this means that a value and its negation are both less than or equal to $|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|$. This is the definition of absolute value, so `abs_le` can be used to conclude that $\left| |\mathbf{X}|-|\mathbf{Y}|\right| \le |\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{Y}|`.

nl_theorem:
If $f$ is bounded and continuous on a
bounded Jordan measurable set $S,$ then $f$ is integrable on $S.$
nl_proof:
Since $V(K)=0$,
$$
\int_C\psi_K(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=0
$$
if $C$ is any cube containing $K$. From this and the
definition of the integral, there is a $\delta>0$ such that if ${\bf
P}$ is any partition of $C$ with $\|{\bf P}\|\le\delta$ and $\sigma$
is any Riemann sum of $\psi_K$ over ${\bf P}$, then
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.6}
0\le\sigma\le\epsilon.
\end{equation}
\newpage
\noindent
Now suppose that  ${\bf P}=\{C_1,C_2,\dots,C_k\}$ is a partition of $C$
into cubes with
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.7}
\|{\bf P}\|<\min (\rho,\delta),
\end{equation}
and let $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots, $C_k$ be numbered so that $C_j\cap K\ne
\emptyset$ if $1\le j\le r$  and
$C_j\cap K=\emptyset$ if $r+1\le j\le k$. Then \eqref{eq:7.3.5} holds, and
a typical Riemann sum of $\psi_K$ over ${\bf P}$ is of the form
$$
\sigma=\sum_{j=1}^r\psi_K(\mathbf{X}_j)V(C_j)
$$
with $\mathbf{X}_j\in C_j$, $1\le j\le r$. In particular, we
can choose
$\mathbf{X}_j$ from $K$, so that $\psi_K(\mathbf{X}_j)=1$,  and
$$
\sigma=\sum_{j=1}^r V(C_j).
$$
Now \eqref{eq:7.3.6} and \eqref{eq:7.3.7} imply that $C_1$, $C_2$, \dots,
$C_r$ have the required properties.

proof_graph.natural_language: Since V(K)=0
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• K is a set with Jordan content V(K)=0 [tc_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: 0\le\sigma\le\epsilon.
proof_graph.statement:
Premise:
• Let an arbitrary ϵ > 0 be given [tc_2].

proof_graph.natural_language: ∫_Cψ_K(X) dX=0
proof_graph.statement:
Definition:
• ψ_K(X) is the characteristic function of the set K, defined as ψ_K(X) = 1 if X ∈ K and ψ_K(X) = 0 if X ∉ K [def_1].

proof_graph.natural_language: Since V(K)=0, ∫_Cψ_K(\mathbf{X})\,d\mathbf{X}=0 if C is any cube containing K.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• K is a set with Jordan content V(K)=0 [tc_1].
• ψ_K(X) is the characteristic function of K [def_1].
• C is any cube containing K.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The Riemann integral of the characteristic function of K over C is zero: ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].
proof_graph.lean_hint: The integral of the characteristic function over a containing cube is the definition of the Jordan content V(K). Since V(K) is given as 0, the integral is 0.

proof_graph.natural_language: From this and the definition of the integral, there is a δ>0 such that if P is any partition of C with ||P||≤δ and σ is any Riemann sum of ψ_K over P, then 0≤σ≤ϵ.
proof_graph.statement:
We assume:
• Let an arbitrary ϵ > 0 be given [tc_2].
• The integral of the characteristic function of K over a cube C is zero: ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a δ > 0 such that if P is any partition of C with norm ||P|| ≤ δ, and σ is any Riemann sum of ψ_K over P, then 0 ≤ σ ≤ ϵ. This is referenced as equation (7.3.6) [l2].
proof_graph.lean_hint: This follows from the definition of the Riemann integral. If the integral of a non-negative function is 0, then for any ε > 0, there exists a δ > 0 such that all corresponding Riemann sums are bounded between 0 and ε.
